text: INTRODUCTION
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: WHILST engaged on the Translations contained in these volumes, and on the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Notes appended to the various Tales, I have found myself led unavoidably
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: into a much more extensive course of reading than I had originally
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: contemplated, and one which in great measure bears directly upon the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: earlier Mediæval Romance.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Before commencing these labours, I was aware, generally, that there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: existed a connexion between the Welsh Mabinogion and the Romance of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Continent; but as I advanced, I became better acquainted with the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: closeness and extent of that connexion, its history, and the proofs by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which it is supported.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: At the same time, indeed, I became aware, and still strongly feel, that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it is one thing to collect facts, and quite another to classify and draw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from them their legitimate conclusions; and though I am loth that what
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: has been collected with some pains, should be entirely thrown away, it is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unwillingly, and with diffidence, that I trespass beyond the acknowledged
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: province of a translator.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the twelfth and thirteenth centuries there arose into general
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: notoriety in Europe, a body of “Romance,” which in various forms retained
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: its popularity till the Reformation.  In it the plot, the incidents, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: characters, were almost wholly those of Chivalry, that bond which united
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the warriors of France, Spain, and Italy, with those of pure Teutonic
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: descent, and embraced more or less firmly all the nations of Europe,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: excepting only the Slavonic races, not yet risen to power, and the Celts,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: who had fallen from it.  It is not difficult to account for this latter
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: omission.  The Celts, driven from the plains into the mountains and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: islands, preserved their liberty, and hated their oppressors with fierce,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and not causeless, hatred.  A proud and free people, isolated both in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: country and language, were not likely to adopt customs which implied
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: brotherhood with their foes.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Such being the case, it is remarkable that when the chief romances are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: examined, the name of many of the heroes and their scenes of action are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: found to be Celtic, and those of persons and places famous in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: traditions of Wales and Brittany.  Of this the romances of Ywaine and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gawaine, Sir Perceval de Galles, Eric and Enide, Mort d’Arthur, Sir
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lancelot, Sir Tristan, the Graal, &c., may be cited as examples.  In some
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cases a tendency to triads, and other matters of internal evidence, point
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the same direction.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It may seem difficult to account for this.  Although the ancient dominion
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the Celts over Europe is not without enduring evidence in the names of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the mountains and streams, the great features of a country, yet the loss
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of their prior language by the great mass of the Celtic nations in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Southern Europe (if indeed their successors in territory be at all of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their blood), prevents us from clearly seeing, and makes us wonder, how
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stories, originally embodied in the Celtic dialects of Great Britain and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: France, could so influence the literature of nations to whom the Celtic
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: languages were utterly unknown.  Whence then came these internal marks,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and these proper names of persons and places, the features of a story
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: usually of earliest date and least likely to change?
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: These romances were found in England, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and even Iceland, as early as the beginning of the thirteenth and end of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the twelfth century.  The Germans, who propagated them through the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nations of the North, derived them certainly from France.  Robert Wace
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: published his Anglo-Norman Romance of the Brut d’Angleterre about 1155.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Sir Tristan was written in French prose in 1170; and The Chevalier au
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lion, Chevalier de l’Epée, and Sir Lancelot du Lac, in metrical French,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by Chrestien de Troyes, before 1200.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: From these facts it is to be argued that the further back these romances
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: are traced, the more clearly does it appear that they spread over the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Continent from the North-west of France.  The older versions, it may be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: remarked, are far more simple than the later corruptions.  In them there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: is less allusion to the habits and usages of Chivalry, and the Welsh
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: names and elements stand out in stronger relief.  It is a great step to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be able to trace the stocks of these romances back to Wace, or to his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: country and age.  For Wace’s work was not original.  He himself, a native
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Jersey, appears to have derived much of it from the “Historia
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Britonum” of Gruffydd ab Arthur, commonly known as “Geoffrey of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Monmouth,” born 1128, who himself professes to have translated from a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: British original.  It is, however, very possible that Wace may have had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: access, like Geoffrey, to independent sources of information.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To the claims set up on behalf of Wace and Geoffrey, to be regarded as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the channels by which the Cymric tales passed into the Continental
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Romance, may be added those of a third almost contemporary author.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Layamon, a Saxon priest, dwelling, about 1200, upon the banks of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upper Severn, acknowledges for the source of his British history, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: _English_ Bede, the _Latin_ Albin, and the _French_ Wace.  The last-named
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: however is by very much his chief, and, for Welsh matters, his only
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: avowed authority.  His book, nevertheless, contains a number of names and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stories relating to Wales, of which no traces appear in Wace, or indeed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in Geoffrey, but which he was certainly in a very favourable position to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: obtain for himself.  Layamon, therefore, not only confirms Geoffrey in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: some points, but it is clear, that, professing to follow Wace, he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: independent access to the great body of Welsh literature then current.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Sir F. Madden has put this matter very clearly, in his recent edition of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Layamon.  The Abbé de la Rue, also, was of opinion that Gaimar, an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Anglo-Norman, in the reign of Stephen, usually regarded as a translator
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Geoffrey of Monmouth, had access to a Welsh independent authority.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In addition to these, is to be mentioned the English version of Sir
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Tristrem, which Sir Walter Scott considered to be derived from a distinct
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Celtic source, and not, like the later Amadis, Palmerin, and Lord
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Berners’s Canon of Romance, imported into English literature by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: translation from the French.  For the Auntours of Arthur, recently
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: published by the Camden Society, their Editor, Mr. Robson, seems to hint
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: at a similar claim.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Here then are various known channels, by which portions of Welsh and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Armoric fiction crossed the Celtic border, and gave rise to the more
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ornate, and widely-spread romance of the Age of Chivalry.  It is not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: improbable that there may have existed many others.  It appears then that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a large portion of the stocks of Mediæval Romance proceeded from Wales.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: We have next to see in what condition they are still found in that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: country.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That Wales possessed an ancient literature, containing various lyric
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: compositions, and certain triads, in which are arranged historical facts
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: or moral aphorisms, has been shown by Sharon Turner, who has established
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the high antiquity of many of these compositions.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The more strictly Romantic Literature of Wales has been less fortunate,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: though not less deserving of critical attention.  Small portions only of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it have hitherto appeared in print, the remainder being still hidden in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the obscurity of ancient Manuscripts: of these the chief is supposed to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be the Red Book of Hergest, now in the Library of Jesus College, Oxford,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and of the fourteenth century.  This contains, besides poems, the prose
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: romances known as Mabinogion.  The Black Book of Caermarthen, preserved
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: at Hengwrt, and considered not to be of later date than the twelfth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: century, is said to contain poems only. {1}
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The Mabinogion, however, though thus early recorded in the Welsh tongue,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: are in their existing form by no means wholly Welsh.  They are of two
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tolerably distinct classes.  Of these, the older contains few allusions
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Norman customs, manners, arts, arms, and luxuries.  The other, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: less ancient, are full of such allusions, and of ecclesiastical terms.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Both classes, no doubt, are equally of Welsh root, but the former are not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more overlaid or corrupted, than might have been expected, from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: communication that so early took place between the Normans and the Welsh;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whereas the latter probably migrated from Wales, and were brought back
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and re-translated after an absence of centuries, with a load of Norman
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: additions.  Kilhwch and Olwen, and the dream of Rhonabwy, may be cited as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: examples of the older and purer class; the Lady of the Fountain, Peredur,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Geraint ab Erbin, of the later, or decorated.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Besides these, indeed, there are a few tales, as Amlyn and Amic, Sir
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Bevis of Hamtoun, the Seven Wise Masters, and the story of Charlemagne,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so obviously of foreign extraction, and of late introduction into Wales,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not presenting even a Welsh name, or allusion, and of such very slender
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: intrinsic merit, that although comprised in the Llyvr Coch, they have not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a shadow of claim to form part of the Canon of Welsh Romance.  Therefore,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: although I have translated and examined them, I have given them no place
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in these volumes.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There is one argument in favour of the high antiquity in Wales of many of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Mabinogion, which deserves to be mentioned here.  This argument is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: founded on the topography of the country.  It is found that Saxon names
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of places are very frequently definitions of the nature of the locality
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to which they are attached, as Clifton, Deepden, Bridge-ford, Thorpe,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Ham, Wick, and the like; whereas those of Wales are more frequently
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: commemorative of some event, real or supposed, said to have happened on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: or near the spot, or bearing allusion to some person renowned in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: story of the country or district.  Such are “Llyn y Morwynion,” the Lake
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the Maidens; “Rhyd y Bedd,” the Ford of the Grave; “Bryn Cyfergyr,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Hill of Assault; and so on.  But as these names could not have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: preceded the events to which they refer, the events themselves must be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not unfrequently as old as the early settlement in the country.  And as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: some of these events and fictions are the subjects of, and are explained
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by, existing Welsh legends, it follows that the legends must be, in some
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shape or other, of very remote antiquity.  It will be observed that this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: argument supports _remote_ antiquity only for such legends as are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: connected with the greater topographical features, as mountains, lakes,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rivers, seas, which must have been named at an early period in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: inhabitation of the country by man.  But there exist, also, legends
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: connected with the lesser features, as pools, hills, detached rocks,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: caves, fords, and the like, places not necessarily named by the earlier
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: settlers, but the names of which are, nevertheless, probably very old,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: since the words of which they are composed are in many cases not retained
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the colloquial tongue, in which they must once have been included, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: are in some instances lost from the language altogether, so much so as to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be only partially explicable even by scholars.  The argument applies
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: likewise, in their degree, to camps, barrows, and other artificial
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: earth-works.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Conclusions thus drawn, when established, rest upon a very firm basis.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: They depend upon the number and appositeness of the facts, and it would
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be very interesting to pursue this branch of evidence in detail.  In
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: following up this idea, the names to be sought for might thus be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: classed:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I.  Names of the great features, involving proper names and actions.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cadair Idris and Cadair Arthur both involve more than a mere name.  Idris
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Arthur must have been invested with heroic qualifications to have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: been placed in such “seats.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: II.  Names of lesser features, as “Bryn y Saeth,” Hill of the Dart; “Llyn
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Llyngclys,” Lake of the Engulphed Court; “Ceven y Bedd,” the Ridge of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Grave; “Rhyd y Saeson,” the Saxons’ Ford.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: III.  Names of mixed natural and artificial objects, as “Coeten Arthur,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur’s Coit; “Cerrig y Drudion,” the Crag of the Heroes; which involve
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: actions.  And such as embody proper names only, as “Cerrig Howell,” the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Crag of Howell; “Caer Arianrod,” the Camp of Arianrod; “Bron Goronwy,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Breast (of the Hill) of Goronwy; “Castell mab Wynion,” the Castle of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the son of Wynion; “Nant Gwrtheyrn,” the Rill of Vortigern.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The selection of names would demand much care and discretion.  The
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: translations should be indisputable, and, where known, the connexion of a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: name with a legend should be noted.  Such a name as “Mochdrev,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Swine-town, would be valueless unless accompanied by a legend.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It is always valuable to find a place or work called after an individual,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: because it may help to support some tradition of his existence or his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: actions.  But it is requisite that care be taken not to push the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: etymological dissection too far.  Thus, “Caer Arianrod” should be taken
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: simply as the “Camp of Arianrod,” and not rendered the “Camp of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: silver circle,” because the latter, though it might possibly have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: something to do with the reason for which the name was borne by Arianrod
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: herself, had clearly no reference to its application to her camp.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It appears to me, then, looking back upon what has been advanced:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I.  That we have throughout Europe, at an early period, a great body of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: literature, known as Mediæval Romance, which, amidst much that is wholly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Teutonic origin and character, includes certain well-marked traces of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: an older Celtic nucleus.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: II.  Proceeding backwards in time, we find these romances, their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ornaments falling away at each step, existing towards the twelfth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: century, of simpler structure, and with less encumbered Celtic features,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the works of Wace, and other Bards of the Langue d’Oil.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: III.  We find that Geoffrey of Monmouth, Layamon, and other early British
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Anglo-Saxon historians, and minstrels, on the one hand, transmitted
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Europe the rudiments of its after romance, much of which, on the other
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hand, they drew from Wales.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: IV.  Crossing into Wales we find, in the Mabinogion, the evident
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counterpart of the Celtic portion of the continental romance, mixed up,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: indeed, with various reflex additions from beyond the border, but still
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: containing ample internal evidence of a Welsh original.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: V.  Looking at the connexion between divers of the more ancient
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mabinogion, and the topographical nomenclature of part of the country, we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: find evidence of the great, though indefinite, antiquity of these tales,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and of an origin, which, if not indigenous, is certainly derived from no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: European nation.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It was with a general belief in some of these conclusions, that I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: commenced my labours, and I end them with my impressions strongly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: confirmed.  The subject is one not unworthy of the talents of a Llwyd or
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a Prichard.  It might, I think, be shown, by pursuing the inquiry, that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Cymric nation is not only, as Dr. Prichard has proved it to be, an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: early offshoot of the Indo-European family, and a people of unmixed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: descent, but that when driven out of their conquests by the later
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nations, the names and exploits of their heroes, and the compositions of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their bards, spread far and wide among the invaders, and affected
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: intimately their tastes and literature for many centuries, and that it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: has strong claims to be considered the cradle of European Romance.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: C. E. G.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: DOWLAIS, _August 29th_, _1848_.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: THE LADY OF THE FOUNTAIN
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: KING ARTHUR was at Caerlleon upon Usk; and one day he sat in his chamber;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and with him were Owain the son of Urien, and Kynon the son of Clydno,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Kai the son of Kyner; and Gwenhwyvar and her handmaidens at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: needlework by the window.  And if it should be said that there was a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: porter at Arthur’s palace, there was none.  Glewlwyd Gavaelvawr was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there, acting as porter, to welcome guests and strangers, and to receive
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them with honour, and to inform them of the manners and customs of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Court; and to direct those who came to the Hall or to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: presence-chamber, and those who came to take up their lodging.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the centre of the chamber King Arthur sat upon a seat of green rushes,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: over which was spread a covering of flame-coloured satin, and a cushion
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of red satin was under his elbow.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Arthur spoke, “If I thought you would not disparage me,” said he, “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: would sleep while I wait for my repast; and you can entertain one another
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with relating tales, and can obtain a flagon of mead and some meat from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kai.”  And the King went to sleep.  And Kynon the son of Clydno asked Kai
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for that which Arthur had promised them.  “I, too, will have the good
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tale which he promised to me,” said Kai.  “Nay,” answered Kynon, “fairer
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will it be for thee to fulfill Arthur’s behest, in the first place, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: then we will tell thee the best tale that we know.”  So Kai went to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kitchen and to the mead-cellar, and returned bearing a flagon of mead and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a golden goblet, and a handful of skewers, upon which were broiled
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: collops of meat.  Then they ate the collops and began to drink the mead.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Now,” said Kai, “it is time for you to give me my story.”  “Kynon,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Owain, “do thou pay to Kai the tale that is his due.”  “Truly,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kynon, “thou are older, and art a better teller of tales, and hast seen
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more marvellous things than I; do thou therefore pay Kai his tale.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Begin thyself,” quoth Owain, “with the best that thou knowest.”  “I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: do so,” answered Kynon.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “I was the only son of my mother and father, and I was exceedingly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: aspiring, and my daring was very great.  I thought there was no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: enterprise in the world too mighty for me, and after I had achieved all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the adventures that were in my own country, I equipped myself, and set
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forth to journey through deserts and distant regions.  And at length it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chanced that I came to the fairest valley in the world, wherein were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: trees of equal growth; and a river ran through the valley, and a path was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by the side of the river.  And I followed the path until mid-day, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: continued my journey along the remainder of the valley until the evening;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and at the extremity of a plain I came to a large and lustrous Castle, at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the foot of which was a torrent.  And I approached the Castle, and there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I beheld two youths with yellow curling hair, each with a frontlet of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gold upon his head, and clad in a garment of yellow satin, and they had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gold clasps upon their insteps.  In the hand of each of them was an ivory
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bow, strung with the sinews of the stag; and their arrows had shafts of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the bone of the whale, and were winged with peacock’s feathers; the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shafts also had golden heads.  And they had daggers with blades of gold,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and with hilts of the bone of the whale.  And they were shooting their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: daggers.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “And a little way from them I saw a man in the prime of life, with his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beard newly shorn, clad in a robe and a mantle of yellow satin; and round
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the top of his mantle was a band of gold lace.  On his feet were shoes of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: variegated leather, fastened by two bosses of gold.  When I saw him, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went towards him and saluted him, and such was his courtesy that he no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sooner received my greeting than he returned it.  And he went with me
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: towards the Castle.  Now there were no dwellers in the Castle except
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: those who were in one hall.  And there I saw four-and-twenty damsels,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: embroidering satin at a window.  And this I tell thee, Kai, that the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: least fair of them was fairer than the fairest maid thou hast ever beheld
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the Island of Britain, and the least lovely of them was more lovely
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than Gwenhwyvar, the wife of Arthur, when she has appeared loveliest at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Offering, on the day of the Nativity, or at the feast of Easter.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: They rose up at my coming, and six of them took my horse, and divested me
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of my armour; and six others took my arms, and washed them in a vessel
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: until they were perfectly bright.  And the third six spread cloths upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the tables and prepared meat.  And the fourth six took off my soiled
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: garments, and placed others upon me; namely, an under-vest and a doublet
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of fine linen, and a robe, and a surcoat, and a mantle of yellow satin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with a broad gold band upon the mantle.  And they placed cushions both
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beneath and around me, with coverings of red linen; and I sat down.  Now
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the six maidens who had taken my horse, unharnessed him, as well as if
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they had been the best squires in the Island of Britain.  Then, behold,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they brought bowls of silver wherein was water to wash, and towels of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: linen, some green and some white; and I washed.  And in a little while
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the man sat down to the table.  And I sat next to him, and below me sat
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: all the maidens, except those who waited on us.  And the table was of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: silver, and the cloths upon the table were of linen; and no vessel was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: served upon the table that was not either of gold or of silver, or of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: buffalo-horn.  And our meat was brought to us.  And verily, Kai, I saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there every sort of meat and every sort of liquor that I have ever seen
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: elsewhere; but the meat and the liquor were better served there than I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: have ever seen them in any other place.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Until the repast was half over, neither the man nor any one of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: damsels spoke a single word to me; but when the man perceived that it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: would be more agreeable to me to converse than to eat any more, he began
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to inquire of me who I was.  I said I was glad to find that there was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: some one who would discourse with me, and that it was not considered so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: great a crime at that Court for people to hold converse together.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ‘Chieftain,’ said the man, ‘we would have talked to thee sooner, but we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: feared to disturb thee during thy repast; now, however, we will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: discourse.’  Then I told the man who I was, and what was the cause of my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: journey; and said that I was seeking whether any one was superior to me,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: or whether I could gain the mastery over all.  The man looked upon me,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and he smiled and said, ‘If I did not fear to distress thee too much, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: would show thee that which thou seekest.’  Upon this I became anxious and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sorrowful, and when the man perceived it, he said, ‘If thou wouldest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rather that I should show thee thy disadvantage than thine advantage, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will do so.  Sleep here to-night, and in the morning arise early, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: take the road upwards through the valley until thou reachest the wood
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: through which thou camest hither.  A little way within the wood thou wilt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: meet with a road branching off to the right, by which thou must proceed,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: until thou comest to a large sheltered glade with a mound in the centre.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thou wilt see a black man of great stature on the top of the mound.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: He is not smaller in size than two of the men of this world.  He has but
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: one foot; and one eye in the middle of his forehead.  And he has a club
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of iron, and it is certain that there are no two men in the world who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: would not find their burden in that club.  And he is not a comely man,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: but on the contrary he is exceedingly ill-favoured; and he is the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: woodward of that wood.  And thou wilt see a thousand wild animals grazing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: around him.  Inquire of him the way out of the glade, and he will reply
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to thee briefly, and will point out the road by which thou shalt find
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that which thou art in quest of.’
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “And long seemed that night to me.  And the next morning I arose and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: equipped myself, and mounted my horse, and proceeded straight through the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: valley to the wood; and I followed the cross-road which the man had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pointed out to me, till at length I arrived at the glade.  And there was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I three times more astonished at the number of wild animals that I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld, than the man had said I should be.  And the black man was there,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sitting upon the top of the mound.  Huge of stature as the man had told
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me that he was, I found him to exceed by far the description he had given
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me of him.  As for the iron club which the man had told me was a burden
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for two men, I am certain, Kai, that it would be a heavy weight for four
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: warriors to lift; and this was in the black man’s hand.  And he only
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: spoke to me in answer to my questions.  Then I asked him what power he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: held over those animals. ‘I will show thee, little man,’ said he.  And he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: took his club in his hand, and with it he struck a stag a great blow so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that he brayed vehemently, and at his braying the animals came together,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as numerous as the stars in the sky, so that it was difficult for me to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: find room in the glade to stand among them.  There were serpents, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dragons, and divers sorts of animals.  And he looked at them, and bade
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them go and feed; and they bowed their heads, and did him homage as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: vassals to their lord.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Then the black man said to me, ‘Seest thou now, little man, what power I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hold over these animals?’  Then I inquired of him the way, and he became
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: very rough in his manner to me; however, he asked me whither I would go?
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when I told him who I was and what I sought, he directed me.  ‘Take,’
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said he, ‘that path that leads towards the head of the glade, and ascend
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the wooded steep until thou comest to its summit; and there thou wilt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: find an open space like to a large valley, and in the midst of it a tall
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tree, whose branches are greener than the greenest pine-trees.  Under
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this tree is a fountain, and by the side of the fountain a marble slab,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and on the marble slab a silver bowl, attached by a chain of silver, so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that it may not be carried away.  Take the bowl and throw a bowlful of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: water upon the slab, and thou wilt hear a mighty peal of thunder, so that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou wilt think that heaven and earth are trembling with its fury.  With
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the thunder there will come a shower so severe that it will be scarce
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: possible for thee to endure it and live.  And the shower will be of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hailstones; and after the shower, the weather will become fair, but every
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: leaf that was upon the tree will have been carried away by the shower.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then a flight of birds will come and alight upon the tree; and in thine
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: own country thou didst never hear a strain so sweet as that which they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will sing.  And at the moment thou art most delighted with the song of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the birds, thou wilt hear a murmuring and complaining coming towards thee
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: along the valley.  And thou wilt see a knight upon a coal-black horse,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: clothed in black velvet, and with a pennon of black linen upon his lance;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and he will ride unto thee to encounter thee with the utmost speed.  If
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou fleest from him he will overtake thee, and if thou abidest there, as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sure as thou art a mounted knight, he will leave thee on foot.  And if
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou dost not find trouble in that adventure, thou needest not seek it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: during the rest of thy life.’
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “So I journeyed on, until I reached the summit of the steep, and there I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: found everything as the black man had described it to me.  And I went up
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the tree, and beneath it I saw the fountain, and by its side the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: marble slab, and the silver bowl fastened by the chain.  Then I took the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bowl, and cast a bowlful of water upon the slab; and thereupon, behold,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the thunder came, much more violent than the black man had led me to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: expect; and after the thunder came the shower; and of a truth I tell
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee, Kai, that there is neither man nor beast that can endure that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shower and live.  For not one of those hailstones would be stopped,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: either by the flesh or by the skin, until it had reached the bone.  I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: turned my horse’s flank towards the shower, and placed the beak of my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shield over his head and neck, while I held the upper part of it over my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: own head.  And thus I withstood the shower.  When I looked on the tree
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there was not a single leaf upon it, and then the sky became clear, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with that, behold the birds lighted upon the tree, and sang.  And truly,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kai, I never heard any melody equal to that, either before or since.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when I was most charmed with listening to the birds, lo, a murmuring
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: voice was heard through the valley, approaching me and saying, ‘Oh,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Knight, what has brought thee hither?  What evil have I done to thee,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that thou shouldst act towards me and my possessions as thou hast this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: day?  Dost thou not know that the shower to-day has left in my dominions
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: neither man nor beast alive that was exposed to it?’  And thereupon,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: behold, a Knight on a black horse appeared, clothed in jet-black velvet,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and with a tabard of black linen about him.  And we charged each other,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and, as the onset was furious, it was not long before I was overthrown.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then the Knight passed the shaft of his lance through the bridle rein of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: my horse, and rode off with the two horses, leaving me where I was.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he did not even bestow so much notice upon me as to imprison me, nor did
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he despoil me of my arms.  So I returned along the road by which I had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: come.  And when I reached the glade where the black man was, I confess to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee, Kai, it is a marvel that I did not melt down into a liquid pool,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: through the shame that I felt at the black man’s derision.  And that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: night I came to the same castle where I had spent the night preceding.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And I was more agreeably entertained that night than I had been the night
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: before; and I was better feasted, and I conversed freely with the inmates
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the castle, and none of them alluded to my expedition to the fountain,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: neither did I mention it to any; and I remained there that night.  When I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: arose on the morrow, I found, ready saddled, a dark bay palfrey, with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nostrils as red as scarlet; and after putting on my armour, and leaving
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there my blessing, I returned to my own Court.  And that horse I still
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: possess, and he is in the stable yonder.  And I declare that I would not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: part with him for the best palfrey in the Island of Britain.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Now of a truth, Kai, no man ever before confessed to an adventure so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: much to his own discredit, and verily it seems strange to me, that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: neither before nor since have I heard of any person besides myself who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: knew of this adventure, and that the subject of it should exist within
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: King Arthur’s dominions, without any other person lighting upon it.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Now,” quoth Owain, “would it not be well to go and endeavour to discover
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that place?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “By the hand of my friend,” said Kai, “often dost thou utter that with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy tongue which thou wouldst not make good with thy deeds.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “In very truth,” said Gwenhwyvar, “it were better thou wert hanged, Kai,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than to use such uncourteous speech towards a man like Owain.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “By the hand of my friend, good Lady,” said Kai, “thy praise of Owain is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not greater than mine.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: With that Arthur awoke, and asked if he had not been sleeping a little.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Yes, Lord,” answered Owain, “thou hast slept awhile.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Is it time for us to go to meat?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “It is, Lord,” said Owain.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then the horn for washing was sounded, and the King and all his household
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sat down to eat.  And when the meal was ended, Owain withdrew to his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lodging, and made ready his horse and his arms.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On the morrow, with the dawn of day, he put on his armour, and mounted
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his charger, and travelled through distant lands and over desert
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mountains.  And at length he arrived at the valley which Kynon had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: described to him; and he was certain that it was the same that he sought.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And journeying along the valley by the side of the river, he followed its
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: course till he came to the plain and within sight of the Castle.  When he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: approached the Castle, he saw the youths shooting their daggers in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: place where Kynon had seen them, and the yellow man, to whom the Castle
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: belonged, standing hard by.  And no sooner had Owain saluted the yellow
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: man than he was saluted by him in return.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he went forward towards the Castle, and there he saw the chamber, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when he had entered the chamber he beheld the maidens working at satin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: embroidery, in chairs of gold.  And their beauty and their comeliness
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seemed to Owain far greater than Kynon had represented to him.  And they
title: The Mabinogion

text: rose to wait upon Owain, as they had done to Kynon, and the meal which

text: sorrowful, but we have cause enough for sadness and care.”  “What is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that?” said Owain.  “I have two sons,” replied the Earl, “and yesterday
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they went to the mountains to hunt.  Now there is on the mountain a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: monster who kills men and devours them, and he seized my sons; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to-morrow is the time he has fixed to be here, and he threatens that he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will then slay my sons before my eyes, unless I will deliver into his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hands this my daughter.  He has the form of a man, but in stature he is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: no less than a giant.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Truly,” said Owain, “that is lamentable.  And which wilt thou do?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Heaven knows,” said the Earl, “it will be better that my sons should be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slain against my will, than that I should voluntarily give up my daughter
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to him to ill-treat and destroy.”  Then they talked about other things,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Owain stayed there that night.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The next morning they heard an exceeding great clamour, which was caused
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by the coming of the giant with the two youths.  And the Earl was anxious
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: both to protect his Castle and to release his two sons.  Then Owain put
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on his armour and went forth to encounter the giant, and the lion
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: followed him.  And when the giant saw that Owain was armed, he rushed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: towards him and attacked him.  And the lion fought with the giant much
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more fiercely than Owain did.  “Truly,” said the giant, “I should find no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: difficulty in fighting with thee, were it not for the animal that is with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee.”  Upon that Owain took the lion back to the Castle and shut the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gate upon him, and then he returned to fight the giant, as before.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the lion roared very loud, for he heard that it went hard with Owain.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he climbed up till he reached the top of the Earl’s hall, and thence
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he got to the top of the Castle, and he sprang down from the walls and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went and joined Owain.  And the lion gave the giant a stroke with his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: paw, which tore him from his shoulder to his hip, and his heart was laid
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bare, and the giant fell down dead.  Then Owain restored the two youths
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to their father.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The Earl besought Owain to remain with him, and he would not, but set
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forward towards the meadow where Luned was.  And when he came there he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saw a great fire kindled, and two youths with beautiful curling auburn
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hair were leading the maiden to cast her into the fire.  And Owain asked
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them what charge they had against her.  And they told him of the compact
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that was between them, as the maiden had done the night before.  “And,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said they, “Owain has failed her, therefore we are taking her to be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: burnt.”  “Truly,” said Owain, “he is a good knight, and if he knew that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the maiden was in such peril, I marvel that he came not to her rescue;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: but if you will accept me in his stead, I will do battle with you.”  “We
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will,” said the youths, “by him who made us.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they attacked Owain, and he was hard beset by them.  And with that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the lion came to Owain’s assistance, and they two got the better of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: young men.  And they said to him, “Chieftain, it was not agreed that we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should fight save with thyself alone, and it is harder for us to contend
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with yonder animal than with thee.”  And Owain put the lion in the place
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: where the maiden had been imprisoned, and blocked up the door with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stones, and he went to fight with the young men, as before.  But Owain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had not his usual strength, and the two youths pressed hard upon him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the lion roared incessantly at seeing Owain in trouble; and he burst
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: through the wall until he found a way out, and rushed upon the young men,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and instantly slew them.  So Luned was saved from being burned.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Owain returned with Luned to the dominions of the Countess of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Fountain.  And when he went thence he took the Countess with him to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur’s Court, and she was his wife as long as she lived.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And then he took the road that led to the Court of the savage black man,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Owain fought with him, and the lion did not quit Owain until he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: vanquished him.  And when he reached the Court of the savage black man he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: entered the hall, and beheld four-and-twenty ladies, the fairest that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: could be seen.  And the garments which they had on were not worth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: four-and twenty pence, and they were as sorrowful as death.  And Owain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: asked them the cause of their sadness.  And they said, “We are the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: daughters of Earls, and we all came here with our husbands, whom we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dearly loved.  And we were received with honour and rejoicing.  And we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were thrown into a state of stupor, and while we were thus, the demon who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: owns this Castle slew all our husbands, and took from us our horses, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: our raiment, and our gold, and our silver; and the corpses of our
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: husbands are still in this house, and many others with them.  And this,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Chieftain, is the cause of our grief, and we are sorry that thou art come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hither, lest harm should befall thee.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Owain was grieved when he heard this.  And he went forth from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Castle, and he beheld a knight approaching him, who saluted him in a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: friendly and cheerful manner, as if he had been a brother.  And this was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the savage black man.  “In very sooth,” said Owain, “it is not to seek
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy friendship that I am here.”  “In sooth,” said he, “thou shalt not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: find it then.”  And with that they charged each other, and fought
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: furiously.  And Owain overcame him, and bound his hands behind his back.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then the black savage besought Owain to spare his life, and spoke thus:
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “My lord Owain,” said he, “it was foretold that thou shouldst come hither
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and vanquish me, and thou hast done so.  I was a robber here, and my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: house was a house of spoil; but grant me my life, and I will become the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: keeper of an Hospice, and I will maintain this house as an Hospice for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: weak and for strong, as long as I live, for the good of thy soul.”  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Owain accepted this proposal of him, and remained there that night.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next day he took the four-and-twenty ladies, and their horses,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and their raiment, and what they possessed of goods and jewels, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: proceeded with them to Arthur’s Court.  And if Arthur was rejoiced when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he saw him, after he had lost him the first time, his joy was now much
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greater.  And of those ladies, such as wished to remain in Arthur’s Court
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: remained there, and such as wished to depart departed.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thenceforward Owain dwelt at Arthur’s Court greatly beloved, as the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: head of his household, until he went away with his followers; and those
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were the army of three hundred ravens which Kenverchyn had left him.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wherever Owain went with these he was victorious.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And this is the tale of THE LADY OF THE FOUNTAIN.
title: The Mabinogion

text: PEREDUR THE SON OF EVRAWC
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: EARL EVRAWC owned the Earldom of the North.  And he had seven sons.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Evrawc maintained himself not so much by his own possessions as by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: attending tournaments, and wars, and combats.  And, as it often befalls
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: those who join in encounters and wars, he was slain, and six of his sons
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: likewise.  Now the name of his seventh son was Peredur, and he was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: youngest of them.  And he was not of an age to go to wars and encounters,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: otherwise he might have been slain as well as his father and brothers.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: His mother was a scheming and thoughtful woman, and she was very
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: solicitous concerning this her only son and his possessions.  So she took
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsel with herself to leave the inhabited country, and to flee to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: deserts and unfrequented wildernesses.  And she permitted none to bear
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her company thither but women and boys, and spiritless men, who were both
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unaccustomed and unequal to war and fighting.  And none dared to bring
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: either horses or arms where her son was, lest he should set his mind upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them.  And the youth went daily to divert himself in the forest, by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: flinging sticks and staves.  And one day he saw his mother’s flock of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: goats, and near the goats two hinds were standing.  And he marvelled
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greatly that these two should be without horns, while the others had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them.  And he thought they had long run wild, and on that account they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had lost their horns.  And by activity and swiftness of foot, he drove
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the hinds and the goats together into the house which there was for the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: goats at the extremity of the forest.  Then Peredur returned to his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mother.  “Ah, mother,” said he, “a marvellous thing have I seen in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wood; two of thy goats have run wild, and lost their horns, through their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: having been so long missing in the wood.  And no man had ever more
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: trouble than I had to drive them in.”  Then they all arose and went to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: see.  And when they beheld the hinds they were greatly astonished.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And one day they saw three knights coming along the horse-road on the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: borders of the forest.  And the three knights were Gwalchmai the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwyar, and Geneir Gwystyl, and Owain the son of Urien.  And Owain kept on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the track of the knight who had divided the apples in Arthur’s Court,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whom they were in pursuit of.  “Mother,” said Peredur, “what are those
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: yonder?”  “They are angels, my son,” said she.  “By my faith,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur, “I will go and become an angel with them.”  And Peredur went to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the road, and met them.  “Tell me, good soul,” said Owain, “sawest thou a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: knight pass this way, either to-day or yesterday?”  “I know not,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered he, “what a knight is.”  “Such an one as I am,” said Owain.  “If
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou wilt tell me what I ask thee, I will tell thee that which thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: askest me.”  “Gladly will I do so,” replied Owain.  “What is this?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: demanded Peredur, concerning the saddle.  “It is a saddle,” said Owain.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then he asked about all the accoutrements which he saw upon the men, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the horses, and the arms, and what they were for, and how they were used.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Owain shewed him all these things fully, and told him what use was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: made of them.  “Go forward,” said Peredur, “for I saw such an one as thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: inquirest for, and I will follow thee.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Peredur returned to his mother and her company, and he said to her,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Mother, those were not angels, but honourable knights.”  Then his mother
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: swooned away.  And Peredur went to the place where they kept the horses
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that carried firewood, and that brought meat and drink from the inhabited
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: country to the desert.  And he took a bony piebald horse, which seemed to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saddle, and with twisted twigs he imitated the trappings which he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seen upon the horses.  And when Peredur came again to his mother, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Countess had recovered from her swoon.  “My son,” said she, “desirest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou to ride forth?”  “Yes, with thy leave,” said he.  “Wait, then, that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I may counsel thee before thou goest.”  “Willingly,” he answered; “speak
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: quickly.”  “Go forward, then,” she said, “to the Court of Arthur, where
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there are the best, and the boldest, and the most bountiful of men.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wherever thou seest a church, repeat there thy Paternoster unto it.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: if thou see meat and drink, and have need of them, and none have the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kindness or the courtesy to give them to thee, take them thyself.  If
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou hear an outcry, proceed towards it, especially if it be the outcry
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of a woman.  If thou see a fair jewel, possess thyself of it, and give it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to another, for thus thou shalt obtain praise.  If thou see a fair woman,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pay thy court to her, whether she will or no; for thus thou wilt render
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thyself a better and more esteemed man than thou wast before.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After this discourse, Peredur mounted the horse, and taking a handful of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sharp-pointed forks in his hand, he rode forth.  And he journeyed two
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: without food and without drink.  And then he came to a vast wild wood,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and far within the wood he saw a fair even glade, and in the glade he saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a tent, and the tent seeming to him to be a church, he repeated his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Paternoster to it.  And he went towards it, and the door of the tent was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: open.  And a golden chair was near the door.  And on the chair sat a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lovely auburn-haired maiden, with a golden frontlet on her forehead, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sparkling stones in the frontlet, and with a large gold ring on her hand.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Peredur dismounted, and entered the tent.  And the maiden was glad at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his coming, and bade him welcome.  At the entrance of the tent he saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: food, and two flasks full of wine, and two loaves of fine wheaten flour,

author: NA

text: and collops of the flesh of the wild boar.  “My mother told me,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and welcome, chieftain,” said she.  So Peredur took half of the meat and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the liquor himself, and left the rest to the maiden.  And when Peredur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had finished eating, he bent upon his knee before the maiden.  “My
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mother,” said he, “told me, wheresoever I saw a fair jewel, to take it.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his horse, and proceeded on his journey.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After this, behold the knight came to whom the tent belonged; and he was

author: NA

text: the Lord of the Glade.  And he saw the track of the horse, and he said to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she, “of wonderful demeanour.”  And she described to him what Peredur’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “By my faith, I do not believe thee; and until I can meet with him, and

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

text: and set forth to seek Peredur.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Meanwhile Peredur journeyed on towards Arthur’s Court.  And before he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

author: NA

author: NA

text: upon it; and in this way he traversed the whole length of the Hall.  In
