text: them; but they refused him, saying, “If thou shouldst be slain there,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou hast none to bring thee back to life again.”  And they rode forward,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Peredur followed after them; and, after they had disappeared out of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his sight, he came to a mound, whereon sat the fairest lady he had ever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld.  “I know thy quest,” said she; “thou art going to encounter the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Addanc, and he will slay thee, and that not by courage, but by craft.  He
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: has a cave, and at the entrance of the cave there is a stone pillar, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he sees every one that enters, and none see him; and from behind the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pillar he slays every one with a poisonous dart.  And if thou wouldst
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pledge me thy faith to love me above all women, I would give thee a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stone, by which thou shouldst see him when thou goest in, and he should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not see thee.”  “I will, by my troth,” said Peredur, “for when first I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld thee I loved thee; and where shall I seek thee?”  “When thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seekest me, seek towards India.”  And the maiden vanished, after placing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the stone in Peredur’s hand.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he came towards a valley, through which ran a river; and the borders
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the valley were wooded, and on each side of the river were level
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: meadows.  And on one side of the river he saw a flock of white sheep, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on the other a flock of black sheep.  And whenever one of the white sheep
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bleated, one of the black sheep would cross over and become white; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when one of the black sheep bleated, one of the white sheep would cross
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: over and become black.  And he saw a tall tree by the side of the river,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: one half of which was in flames from the root to the top, and the other
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: half was green and in full leaf.  And nigh thereto he saw a youth sitting
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon a mound, and two greyhounds, white-breasted and spotted, in leashes,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lying by his side.  And certain was he that he had never seen a youth of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so royal a bearing as he.  And in the wood opposite he heard hounds
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: raising a herd of deer.  And Peredur saluted the youth, and the youth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greeted him in return.  And there were three roads leading from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mound; two of them were wide roads, and the third was more narrow.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur inquired where the three roads went.  “One of them goes to my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: palace,” said the youth; “and one of two things I counsel thee to do;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: either to proceed to my palace, which is before thee, and where thou wilt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: find my wife, or else to remain here to see the hounds chasing the roused
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: deer from the wood to the plain.  And thou shalt see the best greyhounds
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou didst ever behold, and the boldest in the chase, kill them by the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: water beside us; and when it is time to go to meat, my page will come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with my horse to meet me, and thou shalt rest in my palace to-night.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Heaven reward thee; but I cannot tarry, for onward must I go.”  “The
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: other road leads to the town, which is near here, and wherein food and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: liquor may be bought; and the road which is narrower than the others goes
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: towards the cave of the Addanc.”  “With thy permission, young man, I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: go that way.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Peredur went towards the cave.  And he took the stone in his left
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hand, and his lance in his right.  And as he went in he perceived the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Addanc, and he pierced him through with his lance, and cut off his head.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And as he came from the cave, behold the three companions were at the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: entrance; and they saluted Peredur, and told him that there was a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prediction that he should slay that monster.  And Peredur gave the head
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the young men, and they offered him in marriage whichever of the three
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sisters he might choose, and half their kingdom with her.  “I came not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hither to woo,” said Peredur, “but if peradventure I took a wife, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should prefer your sister to all others.”  And Peredur rode forward, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he heard a noise behind him.  And he looked back, and saw a man upon a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: red horse, with red armour upon him; and the man rode up by his side, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saluted him, and wished him the favour of Heaven and of man.  And Peredur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greeted the youth kindly.  “Lord, I come to make a request unto thee.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “What wouldest thou?”  “That thou shouldest take me as thine attendant.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Whom then should I take as my attendant, if I did so?”  “I will not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: conceal from thee what kindred I am of.  Etlym Gleddyv Coch am I called,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: an Earl from the East Country.”  “I marvel that thou shouldest offer to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: become attendant to a man whose possessions are no greater than thine
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: own; for I have but an earldom like thyself.  But since thou desirest to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be my attendant, I will take thee joyfully.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they went forward to the Court of the Countess, and all they of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Court were glad at their coming; and they were told it was not through
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: disrespect they were placed below the household, but that such was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: usage of the Court.  For, whoever should overthrow the three hundred men
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of her household, would sit next the Countess, and she would love him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: above all men.  And Peredur having overthrown the three hundred men of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her household, sat down beside her, and the Countess said, “I thank
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Heaven that I have a youth so fair and so valiant as thou, since I have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not obtained the man whom best I love.”  “Who is he whom best thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lovest?”  “By my faith, Etlym Gleddyv Coch is the man whom I love best,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and I have never seen him.”  “Of a truth, Etlym is my companion; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: behold here he is, and for his sake did I come to joust with thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: household.  And he could have done so better than I, had it pleased him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And I do give thee unto him.”  “Heaven reward thee, fair youth, and I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will take the man whom I love above all others.”  And the Countess became
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Etlym’s bride from that moment.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next day Peredur set forth towards the Mound of Mourning.  “By
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy hand, lord, but I will go with thee,” said Etlym.  Then they went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forwards till they came in sight of the mound and the tents.  “Go unto
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: yonder men,” said Peredur to Etlym, “and desire them to come and do me
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: homage.”  So Etlym went unto them, and said unto them thus,—“Come and do
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: homage to my lord.”  “Who is thy lord?” said they.  “Peredur with the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: long lance is my lord,” said Etlym.  “Were it permitted to slay a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: messenger, thou shouldest not go back to thy lord alive, for making unto
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kings, and Earls, and Barons so arrogant a demand as to go and do him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: homage.”  Peredur desired him to go back to them, and to give them their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: choice, either to do him homage, or to do battle with him.  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chose rather to do battle.  And that day Peredur overthrew the owners of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a hundred tents; and the next day he overthrew the owners of a hundred
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more; and the third day the remaining hundred took counsel to do homage
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Peredur.  And Peredur inquired of them, wherefore they were there.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they told him they were guarding the serpent until he should die.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “For then should we fight for the stone among ourselves, and whoever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should be conqueror among us would have the stone.”  “Await here,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur, “and I will go to encounter the serpent.”  “Not so, lord,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they; “we will go altogether to encounter the serpent.”  “Verily,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur, “that will I not permit; for if the serpent be slain, I shall
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: derive no more fame therefrom than one of you.”  Then he went to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: place where the serpent was, and slew it, and came back to them, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said, “Reckon up what you have spent since you have been here, and I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: repay you to the full.”  And he paid to each what he said was his claim.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he required of them only that they should acknowledge themselves his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: vassals.  And he said to Etlym, “Go back unto her whom thou lovest best,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and I will go forwards, and I will reward thee for having been my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: attendant.”  And he gave Etlym the stone.  “Heaven repay thee and prosper
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee,” said Etlym.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Peredur rode thence, and he came to the fairest valley he had ever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seen, through which ran a river; and there he beheld many tents of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: various colours.  And he marvelled still more at the number of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: water-mills and of wind-mills that he saw.  And there rode up with him a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tall auburn-haired man, in workman’s garb, and Peredur inquired of him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: who he was.  “I am the chief miller,” said he, “of all the mills yonder.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Wilt thou give me lodging?” said Peredur.  “I will, gladly,” he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered.  And Peredur came to the miller’s house, and the miller had a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fair and pleasant dwelling.  And Peredur asked money as a loan from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: miller, that he might buy meat and liquor for himself and for the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: household, and he promised that he would pay him again ere he went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thence.  And he inquired of the miller, wherefore such a multitude was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there assembled.  Said the miller to Peredur, “One thing is certain:
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: either thou art a man from afar, or thou art beside thyself.  The Empress
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Cristinobyl the Great is here; and she will have no one but the man
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: who is most valiant; for riches does she not require.  And it was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: impossible to bring food for so many thousands as are here, therefore
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were all these mills constructed.”  And that night they took their rest.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next day Peredur arose, and he equipped himself and his horse for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the tournament.  And among the other tents he beheld one, which was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fairest he had ever seen.  And he saw a beauteous maiden leaning her head
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: out of a window of the tent, and he had never seen a maiden more lovely
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than she.  And upon her was a garment of satin.  And he gazed fixedly on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the maiden, and began to love her greatly.  And he remained there, gazing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon the maiden from morning until mid-day, and from mid-day until
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: evening; and then the tournament was ended and he went to his lodging and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: drew off his armour.  Then he asked money of the miller as a loan, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the miller’s wife was wroth with Peredur; nevertheless, the miller lent
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him the money.  And the next day he did in like manner as he had done the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: day before.  And at night he came to his lodging, and took money as a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: loan from the miller.  And the third day, as he was in the same place,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gazing upon the maiden, he felt a hard blow between the neck and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shoulder, from the edge of an axe.  And when he looked behind him, he saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that it was the miller; and the miller said to him, “Do one of two
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: things: either turn thy head from hence, or go to the tournament.”  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur smiled on the miller, and went to the tournament; and all that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: encountered him that day he overthrew.  And as many as he vanquished he

author: NA

text: sent as a gift to the Empress, and their horses and arms he sent as a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gift to the wife of the miller, in payment of the borrowed money.

author: NA

text: Peredur attended the tournament until all were overthrown, and he sent
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: all the men to the prison of the Empress, and the horses and arms to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wife of the miller, in payment of the borrowed money.  And the Empress

author: NA

text: sent to the Knight of the Mill, to ask him to come and visit her.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

author: NA

author: NA

text: fought well with them, and caused them to be bound like stags, and thrown

author: NA

text: into the mill-dyke.  And the Empress sought advice of a wise man who was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in her counsel; and he said to her, “With thy permission, I will go to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him myself.”  So he came to Peredur, and saluted him, and besought him,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for the sake of the lady of his love, to come and visit the Empress.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they went, together with the miller.  And Peredur went and sat down in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the outer chamber of the tent, and she came and placed herself by his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: side.  And there was but little discourse between them.  And Peredur took
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his leave, and went to his lodging.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next day he came to visit her, and when he came into the tent
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there was no one chamber less decorated than the others.  And they knew
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not where he would sit.  And Peredur went and sat beside the Empress, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: discoursed with her courteously.  And while they were thus, they beheld a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

text: upon his knee before the Empress, and besought her to give it to no one

author: NA

text: who would not fight with him for it.  And she looked upon Peredur.

author: NA

text: “Lady,” said he, “bestow on me the goblet.”  And Peredur drank the wine,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and gave the goblet to the miller’s wife.  And while they were thus,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: behold there entered a black man of larger stature than the other, with a

author: NA

text: wild beast’s claw in his hand, wrought into the form of a goblet and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: filled with wine.  And he presented it to the Empress, and besought her

author: NA

text: to give it to no one but the man who would fight with him.  “Lady,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the wine, and sent the goblet to the wife of the miller.  And while they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were thus, behold a rough-looking, crisp-haired man, taller than either

author: NA

text: of the others, came in with a bowl in his hand full of wine; and he bent

author: NA

text: upon his knee, and gave it into the hands of the Empress, and he besought

author: NA

text: her to give it to none but him who would fight with him for it; and she

author: NA

author: NA

author: NA

text: and his horse, and went to the meadow and slew the three men.  Then

author: NA

text: Peredur proceeded to the tent, and the Empress said to him, “Goodly

author: NA

text: Peredur, remember the faith thou didst pledge me when I gave thee the

author: NA

text: stone, and thou didst kill the Addanc.”  “Lady,” answered he, “thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sayest truth, I do remember it.”  And Peredur was entertained by the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Empress fourteen years, as the story relates.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur was at Caerlleon upon Usk, his principal palace; and in the centre
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the floor of the hall were four men sitting on a carpet of velvet,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Owain the son of Urien, and Gwalchmai the son of Gwyar, and Howel the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Emyr Llydaw, and Peredur of the long lance.  And thereupon they saw a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: black curly-headed maiden enter, riding upon a yellow mule, with jagged
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thongs in her hand to urge it on; and having a rough and hideous aspect.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Blacker were her face and her two hands than the blackest iron covered
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with pitch; and her hue was not more frightful than her form.  High
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cheeks had she, and a face lengthened downwards, and a short nose with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: distended nostrils.  And one eye was of a piercing mottled grey, and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: other was as black as jet, deep-sunk in her head.  And her teeth were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: long and yellow, more yellow were they than the flower of the broom.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her stomach rose from the breast-bone, higher than her chin.  And her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: back was in the shape of a crook, and her legs were large and bony.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her figure was very thin and spare, except her feet and her legs, which
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were of huge size.  And she greeted Arthur and all his household except
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur.  And to Peredur she spoke harsh and angry words.  “Peredur, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greet thee not, seeing that thou dost not merit it.  Blind was fate in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: giving thee fame and favour.  When thou wast in the Court of the Lame
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: King, and didst see there the youth bearing the streaming spear, from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: points of which were drops of blood flowing in streams, even to the hand
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the youth, and many other wonders likewise, thou didst not inquire
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their meaning nor their cause.  Hadst thou done so, the King would have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: been restored to health, and his dominions to peace.  Whereas from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: henceforth, he will have to endure battles and conflicts, and his knights

author: NA

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur, “May it please thee, lord, my dwelling is far hence, in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stately castle of which thou hast heard, and therein are five hundred and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sixty-six knights of the order of Chivalry, and the lady whom best he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: loves with each; and whoever would acquire fame in arms, and encounters,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and conflicts, he will gain it there, if he deserve it.  And whoso would
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: reach the summit of fame and of honour, I know where he may find it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There is a castle on a lofty mountain, and there is a maiden therein, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she is detained a prisoner there, and whoever shall set her free will

author: NA

text: is there any way by which I can obtain thy friendship?”  “There is,” she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: replied.  “Go thou forward unto yonder mountain, and there thou wilt find
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a grove; and in the grove there is a cromlech; do thou there challenge a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: man three times to fight, and thou shalt have my friendship.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So Peredur proceeded onward, and came to the side of the grove, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: challenged any man to fight.  And a black man arose from beneath the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cromlech, mounted upon a bony horse, and both he and his horse were clad
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in huge rusty armour.  And they fought.  And as often as Peredur cast the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: black man to the earth, he would jump again into his saddle.  And Peredur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dismounted, and drew his sword; and thereupon the black man disappeared
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with Peredur’s horse and his own, so that he could not gain sight of him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a second time.  And Peredur went along the mountain, and on the other
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: side of the mountain he beheld a castle in the valley, wherein was a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: river.  And he went to the castle; and as he entered it, he saw a hall,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and the door of the hall was open, and he went in.  And there he saw a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lame grey-headed man sitting on one side of the hall, with Gwalchmai
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beside him.  And Peredur beheld his horse, which the black man had taken,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the same stall with that of Gwalchmai.  And they were glad concerning
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur.  And he went and seated himself on the other side of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hoary-headed man.  Then, behold a yellow-haired youth came, and bent upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the knee before Peredur, and besought his friendship.  “Lord,” said the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: youth, “it was I that came in the form of the black maiden to Arthur’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Court, and when thou didst throw down the chessboard, and when thou didst
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slay the black man of Ysbidinongyl, and when thou didst slay the stag,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and when thou didst go to fight the black man of the cromlech.  And I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came with the bloody head in the salver, and with the lance that streamed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with blood from the point to the hand, all along the shaft; and the head
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was thy cousin’s, and he was killed by the sorceresses of Gloucester, who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: also lamed thine uncle; and I am thy cousin.  And there is a prediction
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that thou art to avenge these things.”  Then Peredur and Gwalchmai took
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsel, and sent to Arthur and his household, to beseech them to come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: against the sorceresses.  And they began to fight with them; and one of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the sorceresses slew one of Arthur’s men before Peredur’s face, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Peredur bade her forbear.  And the sorceress slew a man before Peredur’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: face a second time, and a second time he forbad her.  And the third time
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the sorceress slew a man before the face of Peredur; and then Peredur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: drew his sword, and smote the sorceress on the helmet; and all her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: head-armour was split in two parts.  And she set up a cry, and desired
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the other sorceresses to flee, and told them that this was Peredur, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: man who had learnt Chivalry with them, and by whom they were destined to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be slain.  Then Arthur and his household fell upon the sorceresses, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slew the sorceresses of Gloucester every one.  And thus is it related
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: concerning the Castle of Wonders.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: GERAINT THE SON OF ERBIN
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ARTHUR was accustomed to hold his Court at Caerlleon upon Usk.  And there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he held it seven Easters and five Christmases.  And once upon a time he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: held his Court there at Whitsuntide.  For Caerlleon was the place most
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: easy of access in his dominions, both by sea and by land.  And there were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: assembled nine crowned kings, who were his tributaries, and likewise
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: earls and barons.  For they were his invited guests at all the high
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: festivals, unless they were prevented by any great hindrance.  And when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he was at Caerlleon, holding his Court, thirteen churches were set apart
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for mass.  And thus were they appointed: one church for Arthur, and his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kings, and his guests; and the second for Gwenhwyvar and her ladies; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the third for the Steward of the Household and the suitors; and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fourth for the Franks and the other officers; and the other nine churches
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were for the nine Masters of the Household and chiefly for Cwalchmai; for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he, from the eminence of his warlike fame, and from the nobleness of his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: birth, was the most exalted of the nine.  And there was no other
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: arrangement respecting the churches than that which we have mentioned
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: above.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Glewlwyd Gavaelvawr was the chief porter; but he did not himself perform
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the office, except at one of the three high festivals, for he had seven
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: men to serve him, and they divided the year amongst them.  They were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Grynn, and Pen Pighon, and Llaes Cymyn, and Gogyfwlch, and Gwrdnei with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cat’s eyes, who could see as well by night as by day, and Drem the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Dremhitid, and Clust the son of Clustveinyd; and these were Arthur’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: guards.  And on Whit-Tuesday, as the King sat at the banquet, lo! there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: entered a tall, fair-headed youth, clad in a coat and a surcoat of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: diapered satin, and a golden-hilted sword about his neck, and low shoes
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of leather upon his feet.  And he came, and stood before Arthur.  “Hail
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to thee, Lord!” said he.  “Heaven prosper thee,” he answered, “and be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou welcome.  Dost thou bring any new tidings?”  “I do, Lord,” he said.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “I know thee not,” said Arthur.  “It is a marvel to me that thou dost not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: know me.  I am one of thy foresters, Lord, in the Forest of Dean, and my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: name is Madawc, the son of Twrgadarn.”  “Tell me thine errand,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur.  “I will do so, Lord,” said he.  “In the Forest I saw a stag, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: like of which beheld I never yet.”  “What is there about him,” asked
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur, “that thou never yet didst see his like?”  “He is of pure white,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lord, and he does not herd with any other animal through stateliness and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pride, so royal is his bearing.  And I come to seek thy counsel, Lord,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and to know thy will concerning him.”  “It seems best to me,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur, “to go and hunt him to-morrow at break of day; and to cause
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: general notice thereof to be given to-night in all quarters of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Court.”  And Arryfuerys was Arthur’s chief huntsman, and Arelivri was his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chief page.  And all received notice; and thus it was arranged.  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sent the youth before them.  Then Gwenhwyvar said to Arthur, “Wilt thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: permit me, Lord,” said she, “to go to-morrow to see and hear the hunt of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the stag of which the young man spoke?”  “I will gladly,” said Arthur.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Then will I go,” said she.  And Gwalchmai said to Arthur, “Lord, if it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seem well to thee, permit that into whose hunt soever the stag shall
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: come, that one, be he a knight, or one on foot, may cut off his head, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: give it to whom he pleases, whether to his own lady-love, or to the lady
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of his friend.”  “I grant it gladly,” said Arthur, “and let the Steward
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the Household be chastised, if all are not ready to-morrow for the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chase.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they passed the night with songs, and diversions, and discourse, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ample entertainment.  And when it was time for them all to go to sleep,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they went.  And when the next day came, they arose; and Arthur called the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: attendants, who guarded his couch.  And these were four pages, whose
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: names were Cadyrnerth the son of Porthawr Gandwy, and Ambreu the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Bedwor, and Amhar the son of Arthur, and Goreu the son of Custennin.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: these men came to Arthur and saluted him, and arrayed him in his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: garments.  And Arthur wondered that Gwenhwyvar did not awake, and did not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: move in her bed; and the attendants wished to awaken her.  “Disturb her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not,” said Arthur, “for she had rather sleep than go to see the hunting.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Arthur went forth, and he heard two horns sounding, one from near
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the lodging of the chief huntsman, and the other from near that of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chief page.  And the whole assembly of the multitudes came to Arthur, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they took the road to the Forest.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And after Arthur had gone forth from the palace, Gwenhwyvar awoke, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: called to her maidens, and apparelled herself.  “Maidens,” said she, “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had leave last night to go and see the hunt.  Go one of you to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stable, and order hither a horse such as a woman may ride.”  And one of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them went, and she found but two horses in the stable, and Gwenhwyvar and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: one of her maidens mounted them, and went through the Usk, and followed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the track of the men and the horses.  And as they rode thus, they heard a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: loud and rushing sound; and they looked behind them, and beheld a knight
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon a hunter foal of mighty size; and the rider was a fair-haired youth,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bare-legged, and of princely mien, and a golden-hilted sword was at his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: side, and a robe and a surcoat of satin were upon him, and two low shoes
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of leather upon his feet; and around him was a scarf of blue purple, at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: each corner of which was a golden apple.  And his horse stepped stately,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and swift, and proud; and he overtook Gwenhwyvar, and saluted her.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Heaven prosper thee, Geraint,” said she, “I knew thee when first I saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee just now.  And the welcome of Heaven be unto thee.  And why didst
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou not go with thy lord to hunt?”  “Because I knew not when he went,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said he.  “I marvel, too,” said she, “how he could go unknown to me.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Indeed, lady,” said he.  “I was asleep, and knew not when he went; but
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou, O young man, art the most agreeable companion I could have in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whole kingdom; and it may be, that I shall be more amused with the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hunting than they; for we shall hear the horns when they sound, and we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shall hear the dogs when they are let loose, and begin to cry.”  So they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went to the edge of the Forest, and there they stood.  “From this place,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said she, “we shall hear when the dogs are let loose.”  And thereupon,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they heard a loud noise, and they looked towards the spot whence it came,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and they beheld a dwarf riding upon a horse, stately, and foaming, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prancing, and strong, and spirited.  And in the hand of the dwarf was a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whip.  And near the dwarf they saw a lady upon a beautiful white horse,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of steady and stately pace; and she was clothed in a garment of gold
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: brocade.  And near her was a knight upon a warhorse of large size, with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heavy and bright armour both upon himself and upon his horse.  And truly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they never before saw a knight, or a horse, or armour, of such remarkable
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: size.  And they were all near to each other.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Geraint,” said Gwenhwyvar, “knowest thou the name of that tall knight
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: yonder?”  “I know him not,” said he, “and the strange armour that he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wears prevents my either seeing his face or his features.”  “Go, maiden,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Gwenhwyvar, “and ask the dwarf who that knight is.”  Then the maiden
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went up to the dwarf; and the dwarf waited for the maiden, when he saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her coming towards him.  And the maiden inquired of the dwarf who the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: knight was.  “I will not tell thee,” he answered.  “Since thou art so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: churlish as not to tell me,” said she, “I will ask him himself.”  “Thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shalt not ask him, by my faith,” said he.  “Wherefore?” said she.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Because thou art not of honour sufficient to befit thee to speak to my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lord.”  Then the maiden turned her horse’s head towards the knight, upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which the dwarf struck her with the whip that was in his hand across the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: face and the eyes, until the blood flowed forth.  And the maiden, through
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the hurt she received from the blow, returned to Gwenhwyvar, complaining
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the pain.  “Very rudely has the dwarf treated thee,” said Geraint.  “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will go myself to know who the knight is.”  “Go,” said Gwenhwyvar.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Geraint went up to the dwarf.  “Who is yonder knight?” said Geraint.  “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will not tell thee,” said the dwarf.  “Then will I ask him himself,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he.  “That wilt thou not, by my faith,” said the dwarf, “thou art not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: honourable enough to speak with my Lord.”  Said Geraint, “I have spoken
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with men of equal rank with him.”  And he turned his horse’s head towards
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the knight; but the dwarf overtook him, and struck him as he had done the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: maiden, so that the blood coloured the scarf that Geraint wore.  Then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Geraint put his hand upon the hilt of his sword, but he took counsel with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: himself, and considered that it would be no vengeance for him to slay the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dwarf, and to be attacked unarmed by the armed knight, so he returned to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: where Gwenhwyvar was.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Thou hast acted wisely and discreetly,” said she.  “Lady,” said he, “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will follow him yet, with thy permission; and at last he will come to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: some inhabited place, where I may have arms either as a loan or for a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pledge, so that I may encounter the knight.”  “Go,” said she, “and do not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: attack him until thou hast good arms, and I shall be very anxious
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: concerning thee, until I hear tidings of thee.”  “If I am alive,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he, “thou shalt hear tidings of me by to-morrow afternoon;” and with that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he departed.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the road they took was below the palace of Caerlleon, and across the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ford of the Usk; and they went along a fair, and even, and lofty ridge of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ground, until they came to a town, and at the extremity of the town they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saw a Fortress and a Castle.  And they came to the extremity of the town.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And as the knight passed through it, all the people arose, and saluted
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him, and bade him welcome.  And when Geraint came into the town, he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: looked at every house, to see if he knew any of those whom he saw.  But
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he knew none, and none knew him to do him the kindness to let him have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

text: of men, and arms, and horses.  And they were polishing shields, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: burnishing swords, and washing armour, and shoeing horses.  And the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: knight, and the lady, and the dwarf rode up to the Castle that was in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: town, and every one was glad in the Castle.  And from the battlements and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and to show their joy.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Geraint stood there to see whether the knight would remain in the Castle;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and when he was certain that he would do so, he looked around him; and at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: palace, he saw but one chamber, and a bridge of marble-stone leading to

author: NA

text: it.  And upon the bridge he saw sitting a hoary-headed man, upon whom

author: NA

text: were tattered garments.  And Geraint gazed steadfastly upon him for a

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: preceded him into the hall.  And in the hall he dismounted, and he left
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there his horse.  Then he went on to the upper chamber with the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hoary-headed man.  And in the chamber he beheld an old decrepit woman,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sitting on a cushion, with old, tattered garments of satin upon her; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

author: NA

author: NA

text: herd of swine.  And through fear of the swine the queen was delivered.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the swineherd took the boy, and brought him to the palace; and he was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: christened, and they called him Kilhwch, because he had been found in a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: swine’s burrow.  Nevertheless the boy was of gentle lineage, and cousin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto Arthur; and they put him out to nurse.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After this the boy’s mother, Goleuddydd, the daughter of Prince Anlawdd,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fell sick.  Then she called her husband unto her, and said to him, “Of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this sickness I shall die, and thou wilt take another wife.  Now wives
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: are the gift of the Lord, but it would be wrong for thee to harm thy son.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Therefore I charge thee that thou take not a wife until thou see a briar
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with two blossoms upon my grave.”  And this he promised her.  Then she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: besought him to dress her grave every year, that nothing might grow
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thereon.  So the queen died.  Now the king sent an attendant every
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: morning to see if anything were growing upon the grave.  And at the end
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the seventh year the master neglected that which he had promised to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the queen.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: One day the king went to hunt, and he rode to the place of burial to see
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the grave, and to know if it were time that he should take a wife; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the king saw the briar.  And when he saw it, the king took counsel where
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he should find a wife.  Said one of his counsellors, “I know a wife that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will suit thee well, and she is the wife of King Doged.”  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: resolved to go to seek her; and they slew the king, and brought away his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wife and one daughter that she had along with her.  And they conquered
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the king’s lands.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On a certain day, as the lady walked abroad, she came to the house of an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: old crone that dwelt in the town, and that had no tooth in her head.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the queen said to her, “Old woman, tell me that which I shall ask thee,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for the love of Heaven.  Where are the children of the man who has
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: carried me away by violence?”  Said the crone, “He has not children.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Said the queen, “Woe is me, that I should have come to one who is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: childless!”  Then said the hag, “Thou needest not lament on account of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that, for there is a prediction he shall have an heir by thee, and by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: none other.  Moreover, be not sorrowful, for he has one son.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The lady returned home with joy; and she asked her consort, “Wherefore
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hast thou concealed thy children from me?”  The king said, “I will do so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: no longer.”  And he sent messengers for his son, and he was brought to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Court.  His stepmother said unto him, “It were well for thee to have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a wife, and I have a daughter who is sought of every man of renown in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: world.”  “I am not yet of an age to wed,” answered the youth.  Then said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she unto him, “I declare to thee, that it is thy destiny not to be suited
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with a wife until thou obtain Olwen, the daughter of Yspaddaden Penkawr.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the youth blushed, and the love of the maiden diffused itself through
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: all his frame, although he had never seen her.  And his father inquired
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of him, “What has come over thee, my son, and what aileth thee?”  “My
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stepmother has declared to me that I shall never have a wife until I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: obtain Olwen, the daughter of Yspaddaden Penkawr.”  “That will be easy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for thee,” answered his father.  “Arthur is thy cousin.  Go, therefore,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto Arthur, to cut thy hair, and ask this of him as a boon.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the youth pricked forth upon a steed with head dappled grey, of four
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: winters old, firm of limb, with shell-formed hoofs, having a bridle of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: linked gold on his head, and upon him a saddle of costly gold.  And in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the youth’s hand were two spears of silver, sharp, well-tempered, headed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with steel, three ells in length, of an edge to wound the wind, and cause
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: blood to flow, and swifter than the fall of the dewdrop from the blade of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: reed-grass upon the earth when the dew of June is at the heaviest.  A
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gold-hilted sword was upon his thigh, the blade of which was of gold,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bearing a cross of inlaid gold of the hue of the lightning of heaven: his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: war-horn was of ivory.  Before him were two brindled white-breasted
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greyhounds, having strong collars of rubies about their necks, reaching
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from the shoulder to the ear.  And the one that was on the left side
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bounded across to the right side, and the one on the right to the left,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and like two sea-swallows sported around him.  And his courser cast up
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: four sods with his four hoofs, like four swallows in the air, about his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: head, now above, now below.  About him was a four-cornered cloth of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: purple, and an apple of gold was at each corner, and every one of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: apples was of the value of an hundred kine.  And there was precious gold
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the value of three hundred kine upon his shoes, and upon his stirrups,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from his knee to the tip of his toe.  And the blade of grass bent not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beneath him, so light was his courser’s tread as he journeyed towards the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gate of Arthur’s Palace.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Spoke the youth, “Is there a porter?”  “There is; and if thou holdest not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy peace, small will be thy welcome.  I am Arthur’s porter every first
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: day of January.  And during every other part of the year but this, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: office is filled by Huandaw, and Gogigwc, and Llaeskenym, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pennpingyon, who goes upon his head to save his feet, neither towards the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sky nor towards the earth, but like a rolling stone upon the floor of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: court.”  “Open the portal.”  “I will not open it.”  “Wherefore not?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “The knife is in the meat, and the drink is in the horn, and there is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: revelry in Arthur’s Hall, and none may enter therein but the son of a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: king of a privileged country, or a craftsman bringing his craft.  But
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there will be refreshment for thy dogs, and for thy horses; and for thee
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there will be collops cooked and peppered, and luscious wine and mirthful
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: songs, and food for fifty men shall be brought unto thee in the guest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chamber, where the stranger and the sons of other countries eat, who come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not unto the precincts of the Palace of Arthur.  Thou wilt fare no worse
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there than thou wouldest with Arthur in the Court.  A lady shall smooth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy couch, and shall lull thee with songs; and early to-morrow morning,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when the gate is open for the multitude that come hither to-day, for thee
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shall it be opened first, and thou mayest sit in the place that thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shalt choose in Arthur’s Hall, from the upper end to the lower.”  Said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the youth, “That will I not do.  If thou openest the gate, it is well.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: If thou dost not open it, I will bring disgrace upon thy Lord, and evil
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: report upon thee.  And I will set up three shouts at this very gate, than
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which none were ever more deadly, from the top of Pengwaed in Cornwall to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the bottom of Dinsol, in the North, and to Esgair Oervel, in Ireland.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And all the women in this Palace that are pregnant shall lose their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: offspring; and such as are not pregnant, their hearts shall be turned by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: illness, so that they shall never bear children from this day forward.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “What clamour soever thou mayest make,” said Glewlwyd Gavaelvawr,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “against the laws of Arthur’s Palace shalt thou not enter therein, until
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I first go and speak with Arthur.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Glewlwyd went into the Hall.  And Arthur said to him, “Hast thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: news from the gate?”—“Half of my life is past, and half of thine.  I was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heretofore in Kaer Se and Asse, in Sach and Salach, in Lotor and Fotor;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and I have been heretofore in India the Great and India the Lesser; and I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was in the battle of Dau Ynyr, when the twelve hostages were brought from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Llychlyn.  And I have also been in Europe, and in Africa, and in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: islands of Corsica, and in Caer Brythwch, and Brythach, and Verthach; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was present when formerly thou didst slay the family of Clis the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Merin, and when thou didst slay Mil Du the son of Ducum, and when thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: didst conquer Greece in the East.  And I have been in Caer Oeth and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Annoeth, and in Caer Nevenhyr; nine supreme sovereigns, handsome men, saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: we there, but never did I behold a man of equal dignity with him who is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: now at the door of the portal.”  Then said Arthur, “If walking thou didst
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: enter in here, return thou running.  And every one that beholds the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: light, and every one that opens and shuts the eye, let them shew him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: respect, and serve him, some with gold-mounted drinking-horns, others
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with collops cooked and peppered, until food and drink can be prepared
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for him.  It is unbecoming to keep such a man as thou sayest he is, in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the wind and the rain.”  Said Kai, “By the hand of my friend, if thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wouldest follow my counsel, thou wouldest not break through the laws of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Court because of him.”  “Not so, blessed Kai.  It is an honour to us
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to be resorted to, and the greater our courtesy the greater will be our
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: renown, and our fame, and our glory.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Glewlwyd came to the gate, and opened the gate before him; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: although all dismounted upon the horseblock at the gate, yet did he not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dismount, but rode in upon his charger.  Then said Kilhwch, “Greeting be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto thee, Sovereign Ruler of this Island; and be this greeting no less
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto the lowest than unto the highest, and be it equally unto thy guests,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and thy warriors, and thy chieftains—let all partake of it as completely
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as thyself.  And complete be thy favour, and thy fame, and thy glory,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: throughout all this Island.”  “Greeting unto thee also,” said Arthur;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “sit thou between two of my warriors, and thou shalt have minstrels
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: before thee, and thou shalt enjoy the privileges of a king born to a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: throne, as long as thou remainest here.  And when I dispense my presents
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the visitors and strangers in this Court, they shall be in thy hand at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: my commencing.”  Said the youth, “I came not here to consume meat and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: drink; but if I obtain the boon that I seek, I will requite it thee, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: extol thee; and if I have it not, I will bear forth thy dispraise to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: four quarters of the world, as far as thy renown has extended.”  Then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Arthur, “Since thou wilt not remain here, chieftain, thou shalt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: receive the boon whatsoever thy tongue may name, as far as the wind
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dries, and the rain moistens, and the sun revolves, and the sea
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: encircles, and the earth extends; save only my ship; and my mantle; and
title: The Mabinogion

text: Caledvwlch, my sword; and Rhongomyant, my lance; and Wynebgwrthucher, my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shield; and Carnwenhau, my dagger; and Gwenhwyvar, my wife.  By the truth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Heaven, thou shalt have it cheerfully, name what thou wilt.”  “I would
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that thou bless my hair.”  “That shall be granted thee.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Arthur took a golden comb, and scissors, whereof the loops were of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: silver, and he combed his hair.  And Arthur inquired of him who he was.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “For my heart warms unto thee, and I know that thou art come of my blood.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Tell me, therefore, who thou art.”  “I will tell thee,” said the youth.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “I am Kilhwch, the son of Kilydd, the son of Prince Kelyddon, by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shalt receive, be it what it may that thy tongue shall name.”  “Pledge
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

text: Then said Arthur, “Oh! chieftain, I have never heard of the maiden of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whom thou speakest, nor of her kindred, but I will gladly send messengers
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in search of her.  Give me time to seek her.”  And the youth said, “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will willingly grant from this night to that at the end of the year to do
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so.”  Then Arthur sent messengers to every land within his dominions to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seek for the maiden; and at the end of the year Arthur’s messengers
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: returned without having gained any knowledge or intelligence concerning
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Olwen more than on the first day.  Then said Kilhwch, “Every one has
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: received his boon, and I yet lack mine.  I will depart and bear away thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: honour with me.”  Then said Kai, “Rash chieftain! dost thou reproach
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur?  Go with us, and we will not part until thou dost either confess
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that the maiden exists not in the world, or until we obtain her.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thereupon Kai rose up.  Kai had this peculiarity, that his breath lasted
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nine nights and nine days under water, and he could exist nine nights and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nine days without sleep.  A wound from Kai’s sword no physician could
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heal.  Very subtle was Kai.  When it pleased him he could render himself
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as tall as the highest tree in the forest.  And he had another
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: peculiarity,—so great was the heat of his nature, that, when it rained
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hardest, whatever he carried remained dry for a handbreadth above and a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: handbreadth below his hand; and when his companions were coldest, it was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to them as fuel with which to light their fire.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Arthur called Bedwyr, who never shrank from any enterprise upon which
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kai was bound.  None was equal to him in swiftness throughout this island
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: except Arthur and Drych Ail Kibddar.  And although he was one-handed,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: three warriors could not shed blood faster than he on the field of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: battle.  Another property he had; his lance would produce a wound equal
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to those of nine opposing lances.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Arthur called to Kynddelig the Guide, “Go thou upon this expedition
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with the chieftain.”  For as good a guide was he in a land which he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: never seen as he was in his own.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: He called Gwrhyr Gwalstawt Ieithoedd, because he knew all tongues.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: He called Gwalchmai the son of Gwyar, because he never returned home
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: without achieving the adventure of which he went in quest.  He was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: best of footmen and the best of knights.  He was nephew to Arthur, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: son of his sister, and his cousin.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Arthur called Menw the son of Teirgwaedd, in order that if they went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: into a savage country, he might cast a charm and an illusion over them,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so that none might see them whilst they could see every one.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: They journeyed until they came to a vast open plain, wherein they saw a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: great castle, which was the fairest of the castles of the world.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they journeyed that day until the evening, and when they thought they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were nigh to the castle, they were no nearer to it than they had been in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the morning.  And the second and the third day they journeyed, and even
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: then scarcely could they reach so far.  And when they came before the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: castle, they beheld a vast flock of sheep, which was boundless and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: without an end.  And upon the top of a mound there was a herdsman,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: keeping the sheep.  And a rug made of skins was upon him; and by his side
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was a shaggy mastiff, larger than a steed nine winters old.  Never had he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lost even a lamb from his flock, much less a large sheep.  He let no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: occasion ever pass without doing some hurt and harm.  All the dead trees
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and bushes in the plain he burnt with his breath down to the very ground.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then said Kai, “Gwrhyr Gwalstawt Ieithoedd, go thou and salute yonder
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: man.”  “Kai,” said he, “I engaged not to go further than thou thyself.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Let us go then together,” answered Kai.  Said Menw the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Teirgwaedd, “Fear not to go thither, for I will cast a spell upon the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dog, so that he shall injure no one.”  And they went up to the mound
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whereon the herdsman was, and they said to him, “How dost thou fare, O
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: herdsman?”  “No less fair be it to you than to me.”  “Truly, art thou the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chief?”  “There is no hurt to injure me but my own.” {5}  “Whose are the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sheep that thou dost keep, and to whom does yonder castle belong?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Stupid are ye, truly!  Through the whole world is it known that this is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the castle of Yspaddaden Penkawr.”  “And who art thou?”  “I am called
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Custennin the son of Dyfnedig, and my brother Yspaddaden Penkawr
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: oppressed me because of my possessions.  And ye also, who are ye?”  “We
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: are an embassy from Arthur, come to seek Olwen the daughter of Yspaddaden
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Penkawr.”  “Oh men! the mercy of Heaven be upon you, do not that for all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the world.  None who ever came hither on this quest has returned alive.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the herdsman rose up.  And as he arose, Kilhwch gave unto him a ring
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of gold.  And he sought to put on the ring, but it was too small for him,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so he placed it in the finger of his glove.  And he went home, and gave
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the glove to his spouse to keep.  And she took the ring from the glove
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when it was given her, and she said, “Whence came this ring, for thou art
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not wont to have good fortune?”  “I went,” said he, “to the sea to seek
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for fish, and lo, I saw a corpse borne by the waves.  And a fairer corpse
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than it did I never behold.  And from its finger did I take this ring.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “O man! does the sea permit its dead to wear jewels?  Show me then this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: body.”  “Oh wife, him to whom this ring belonged thou shalt see here in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the evening.”  “And who is he?” asked the woman, “Kilhwch the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kilydd, the son of Prince Kelyddon, by Goleuddydd the daughter of Prince
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Anlawdd, his mother, who is come to seek Olwen as his wife.”  And when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she heard that, her feelings were divided between the joy that she had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that her nephew, the son of her sister, was coming to her, and sorrow
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: because she had never known any one depart alive who had come on that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: quest.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they went forward to the gate of Custennin the herdsman’s dwelling.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when she heard their footsteps approaching, she ran out with joy to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: meet them.  And Kai snatched a billet out of the pile.  And when she met
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them she sought to throw her arms about their necks.  And Kai placed the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: log between her two hands, and she squeezed it so that it became a

text: She entered the house, and sat beside Kilhwch upon the foremost bench;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and as soon as he saw her he knew her.  And Kilhwch said unto her, “Ah!
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsel, for his life will last only until the time of my espousals.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

text: obtain me, and it will be well for thee if thou escape with thy life.”

text: All that day they journeyed until the evening, and then they beheld a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: vast castle, which was the largest in the world.  And lo, a black man,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: huger than three of the men of this world, came out from the castle.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they spoke unto him, “Whence comest thou, O man?”  “From the castle which
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: you see yonder.”  “Whose castle is that?” asked they.  “Stupid are ye
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: truly, O men.  There is no one in the world that does not know to whom
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this castle belongs.  It is the castle of Gwrnach the Giant.”  “What
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: treatment is there for guests and strangers that alight in that castle?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Oh!  Chieftain, Heaven protect thee.  No guest ever returned thence
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: alive, and no one may enter therein unless he brings with him his craft.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then they proceeded towards the gate.  Said Gwrhyr Gwalstawt Ieithoedd,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Is there a porter?”  “There is.  And thou, if thy tongue be not mute in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy head, wherefore dost thou call?”  “Open the gate.”  “I will not open
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it.”  “Wherefore wilt thou not?”  “The knife is in the meat, and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: drink is in the horn, and there is revelry in the hall of Gwrnach the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Giant, and except for a craftsman who brings his craft, the gate will not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be opened to-night.”  “Verily, porter,” then said Kai, “my craft bring I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with me.”  “What is thy craft?”  “The best burnisher of swords am I in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the world.”  “I will go and tell this unto Gwrnach the Giant, and I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bring thee an answer.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So the porter went in, and Gwrnach said to him, “Hast thou any news from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the gate?”  “I have.  There is a party at the door of the gate who desire
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to come in.”  “Didst thou inquire of them if they possessed any art?”  “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: did inquire,” said he, “and one told me that he was well skilled in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: burnishing of swords.”  “We have need of him then.  For some time have I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sought for some one to polish my sword, and could find no one.  Let this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: man enter, since he brings with him his craft.”  The porter thereupon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: returned and opened the gate.  And Kai went in by himself, and he saluted
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwrnach the Giant.  And a chair was placed for him opposite to Gwrnach.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Gwrnach said to him, “Oh man! is it true that is reported of thee,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that thou knowest how to burnish swords?”  “I know full well how to do
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so,” answered Kai.  Then was the sword of Gwrnach brought to him.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kai took a blue whetstone from under his arm, and asked him whether he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: would have it burnished white or blue.  “Do with it as it seems good to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee, and as thou wouldest if it were thine own.”  Then Kai polished one
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: half of the blade and put it in his hand.  “Will this please thee?” asked
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he.  “I would rather than all that is in my dominions that the whole of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it were like unto this.  It is a marvel to me that such a man as thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should be without a companion.”  “Oh! noble sir, I have a companion,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: albeit he is not skilled in this art.”  “Who may he be?”  “Let the porter
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: go forth, and I will tell him whereby he may know him.  The head of his
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

text: descend upon its shaft again.”  Then the gate was opened, and Bedwyr

text: this art.”

text: Giant, to see if he were pleased with his work.  And the Giant said, “The

author: NA

text: Now, when they told Arthur how they had sped, Arthur said, “Which of

author: NA

author: NA

text: unless we first find Eidoel the son of Aer, his kinsman.”  Then Arthur

author: NA

text: rose up, and the warriors of the Islands of Britain with him, to seek for
