author: NA

text: where Eidoel was imprisoned.  Glivi stood on the summit of his castle,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and he said, “Arthur, what requirest thou of me, since nothing remains to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me in this fortress, and I have neither joy nor pleasure in it; neither
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wheat nor oats?  Seek not therefore to do me harm.”  Said Arthur, “Not to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: injure thee came I hither, but to seek for the prisoner that is with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee.”  “I will give thee my prisoner, though I had not thought to give
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him up to any one; and therewith shalt thou have my support and my aid.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: His followers said unto Arthur, “Lord, go thou home, thou canst not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: proceed with thy host in quest of such small adventures as these.”  Then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Arthur, “It were well for thee, Gwrhyr Gwalstawt Ieithoedd, to go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon this quest, for thou knowest all languages, and art familiar with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: those of the birds and the beasts.  Thou, Eidoel, oughtest likewise to go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with my men in search of thy cousin.  And as for you, Kai and Bedwyr, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: have hope of whatever adventure ye are in quest of, that ye will achieve
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it.  Achieve ye this adventure for me.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: They went forward until they came to the Ousel of Cilgwri.  And Gwrhyr
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: adjured her for the sake of Heaven, saying, “Tell me if thou knowest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: aught of Mabon the son of Modron, who was taken when three nights old
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from between his mother and the wall.”  And the Ousel answered, “When I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: first came here, there was a smith’s anvil in this place, and I was then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a young bird; and from that time no work has been done upon it, save the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pecking of my beak every evening, and now there is not so much as the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: size of a nut remaining thereof; yet the vengeance of Heaven be upon me,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: if during all that time I have ever heard of the man for whom you
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: inquire.  Nevertheless I will do that which is right, and that which it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: is fitting that I should do for an embassy from Arthur.  There is a race
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of animals who were formed before me, and I will be your guide to them.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they proceeded to the place where was the Stag of Redynvre.  “Stag of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Redynvre, behold we are come to thee, an embassy from Arthur, for we have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not heard of any animal older than thou.  Say, knowest thou aught of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mabon the son of Modron, who was taken from his mother when three nights
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: old?”  The Stag said, “When first I came hither, there was a plain all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: around me, without any trees save one oak sapling, which grew up to be an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: oak with an hundred branches.  And that oak has since perished, so that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: now nothing remains of it but the withered stump; and from that day to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this I have been here, yet have I never heard of the man for whom you
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: inquire.  Nevertheless, being an embassy from Arthur, I will be your
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: guide to the place where there is an animal which was formed before I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they proceeded to the place where was the Owl of Cwm Cawlwyd.  “Owl of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cwm Cawlwyd, here is an embassy from Arthur; knowest thou aught of Mabon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the son of Modron, who was taken after three nights from his mother?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “If I knew I would tell you.  When first I came hither, the wide valley
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: you see was a wooded glen.  And a race of men came and rooted it up.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there grew there a second wood; and this wood is the third.  My wings,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: are they not withered stumps?  Yet all this time, even until to-day, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: have never heard of the man for whom you inquire.  Nevertheless, I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be the guide of Arthur’s embassy until you come to the place where is the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: oldest animal in this world, and the one that has travelled most, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Eagle of Gwern Abwy.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwrhyr said, “Eagle of Gwern Abwy, we have come to thee an embassy from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur, to ask thee if thou knowest aught of Mabon the son of Modron, who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was taken from his mother when he was three nights old.”  The Eagle said,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “I have been here for a great space of time, and when I first came hither
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there was a rock here, from the top of which I pecked at the stars every
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: evening; and now it is not so much as a span high.  From that day to this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been here, and I have never heard of the man for whom you inquire,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: except once when I went in search of food as far as Llyn Llyw.  And when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I came there, I struck my talons into a salmon, thinking he would serve
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me as food for a long time.  But he drew me into the deep, and I was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: scarcely able to escape from him.  After that I went with my whole
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kindred to attack him, and to try to destroy him, but he sent messengers,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and made peace with me; and came and besought me to take fifty fish
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: spears out of his back.  Unless he know something of him whom you seek, I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cannot tell who may.  However, I will guide you to the place where he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: is.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they went thither; and the Eagle said, “Salmon of Llyn Llyw, I have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: come to thee with an embassy from Arthur, to ask thee if thou knowest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: aught concerning Mabon the son of Modron, who was taken away at three
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nights old from his mother.”  “As much as I know I will tell thee.  With
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: every tide I go along the river upwards, until I come near to the walls
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Gloucester, and there have I found such wrong as I never found
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: elsewhere; and to the end that ye may give credence thereto, let one of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: you go thither upon each of my two shoulders.”  So Kai and Gwrhyr
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwalstawt Ieithoedd went upon the two shoulders of the salmon, and they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: proceeded until they came unto the wall of the prison, and they heard a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: great wailing and lamenting from the dungeon.  Said Gwrhyr, “Who is it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that laments in this house of stone?”  “Alas, there is reason enough for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whoever is here to lament.  It is Mabon the son of Modron who is here
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: imprisoned; and no imprisonment was ever so grievous as mine, neither
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that of Llud Llaw Ereint, nor that of Greid the son of Eri.”  “Hast thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hope of being released for gold or for silver, or for any gifts of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wealth, or through battle and fighting?”  “By fighting will whatever I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: may gain be obtained.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then they went thence, and returned to Arthur, and they told him where
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mabon the son of Modron was imprisoned.  And Arthur summoned the warriors
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the Island, and they journeyed as far as Gloucester, to the place
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: where Mabon was in prison.  Kai and Bedwyr went upon the shoulders of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fish, whilst the warriors of Arthur attacked the castle.  And Kai broke
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: through the wall into the dungeon, and brought away the prisoner upon his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: back, whilst the fight was going on between the warriors.  And Arthur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: returned home, and Mabon with him at liberty.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Said Arthur, “Which of the marvels will it be best for us now to seek
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: first?”  “It will be best to seek for the two cubs of Gast Rhymhi.”  “Is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it known,” asked Arthur, “where she is?”  “She is in Aber Deu Cleddyf,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said one.  Then Arthur went to the house of Tringad, in Aber Cleddyf, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he inquired of him whether he had heard of her there.  “In what form may
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she be?”  “She is in the form of a she-wolf,” said he; “and with her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there are two cubs.”  “She has often slain my herds, and she is there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: below in a cave in Aber Cleddyf.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So Arthur went in his ship Prydwen by sea, and the others went by land,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to hunt her.  And they surrounded her and her two cubs, and God did
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: change them again for Arthur into their own form.  And the host of Arthur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dispersed themselves into parties of one and two.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On a certain day, as Gwythyr the son of Greidawl was walking over a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mountain, he heard a wailing and a grievous cry.  And when he heard it,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he sprang forward, and went towards it.  And when he came there, he drew
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his sword, and smote off an ant-hill close to the earth, whereby it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: escaped being burned in the fire.  And the ants said to him, “Receive
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from us the blessing of Heaven, and that which no man can give we will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: give thee.”  Then they fetched the nine bushels of flax-seed which
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Yspaddaden Penkawr had required of Kilhwch, and they brought the full
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: measure without lacking any, except one flax-seed, and that the lame
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pismire brought in before night.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: As Kai and Bedwyr sat on a beacon carn on the summit of Plinlimmon, in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the highest wind that ever was in the world, they looked around them, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saw a great smoke towards the south, afar off, which did not bend with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the wind.  Then said Kai, “By the hand of my friend, behold, yonder is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the fire of a robber!”  Then they hastened towards the smoke, and they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came so near to it, that they could see Dillus Varvawc scorching a wild
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boar.  “Behold, yonder is the greatest robber that ever fled from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur,” said Bedwyr unto Kai.  “Dost thou know him?”  “I do know him,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered Kai, “he is Dillus Varvawc, and no leash in the world will be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: able to hold Drudwyn, the cub of Greid the son of Eri, save a leash made
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from the beard of him thou seest yonder.  And even that will be useless,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unless his beard be plucked alive with wooden tweezers; for if dead, it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will be brittle.”  “What thinkest thou that we should do concerning
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this?” said Bedwyr.  “Let us suffer him,” said Kai, “to eat as much as he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will of the meat, and after that he will fall asleep.”  And during that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: time they employed themselves in making the wooden tweezers.  And when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kai knew certainly that he was asleep, he made a pit under his feet, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: largest in the world, and he struck him a violent blow, and squeezed him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: into the pit.  And there they twitched out his beard completely with the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wooden tweezers; and after that they slew him altogether.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And from thence they both went to Gelli Wic, in Cornwall, and took the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: leash made of Dillus Varvawc’s beard with them, and they gave it into
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur’s hand.  Then Arthur composed this Englyn—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kai made a leash
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Of Dillus son of Eurei’s beard.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Were he alive, thy death he’d be.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thereupon Kai was wroth, so that the warriors of the Island could
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: scarcely make peace between Kai and Arthur.  And thenceforth, neither in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur’s troubles, nor for the slaying of his men, would Kai come forward
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to his aid for ever after.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Said Arthur, “Which of the marvels is it best for us now to seek?”  “It
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: is best for us to seek Drudwyn, the cub of Greid the son of Eri.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: A little while before this, Creiddylad the daughter of Lludd Llaw Ereint,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Gwythyr the son of Greidawl, were betrothed.  And before she had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: become his bride, Gwyn ap Nudd came and carried her away by force; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwythyr the son of Greidawl gathered his host together, and went to fight
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with Gwyn ap Nudd.  But Gwyn overcame him, and captured Greid the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Eri, and Glinneu the son of Taran, and Gwrgwst Ledlwm, and Dynvarth his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: son.  And he captured Penn the son of Nethawg, and Nwython, and Kyledyr
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Wyllt his son.  And they slew Nwython, and took out his heart, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: constrained Kyledyr to eat the heart of his father.  And therefrom
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kyledyr became mad.  When Arthur heard of this, he went to the North, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: summoned Gwyn ap Nudd before him, and set free the nobles whom he had put
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in prison, and made peace between Gwyn ap Nudd and Gwythyr the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Griedawl.  And this was the peace that was made:—that the maiden should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: remain in her father’s house, without advantage to either of them, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that Gwyn ap Nudd and Gwythyr the son of Greidawl should fight for her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: every first of May, from thenceforth until the day of doom, and that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whichever of them should then be conqueror should have the maiden.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when Arthur had thus reconciled these chieftains, he obtained Mygdwn,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gweddw’s horse, and the leash of Cwrs Cant Ewin.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And after that Arthur went into Armorica, and with him Mabon the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mellt, and Gware Gwallt Euryn, to seek the two dogs of Glythmyr Ledewic.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when he had got them, he went to the West of Ireland, in search of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwrgi Seven; and Odgar the son of Aedd king of Ireland went with him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thence went Arthur into the North, and captured Kyledyr Wyllt; and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went after Yskithyrwyn Penbaedd.  And Mabon the son of Mellt came with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the two dogs of Glythmyr Ledewic in his hand, and Drudwyn, the cub of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Greid the son of Eri.  And Arthur went himself to the chase, leading his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: own dog Cavall.  And Kaw, of North Britain, mounted Arthur’s mare
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Llamrei, and was first in the attack.  Then Kaw, of North Britain,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wielded a mighty axe, and absolutely daring he came valiantly up to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boar, and clave his head in twain.  And Kaw took away the tusk.  Now the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boar was not slain by the dogs that Yspaddaden had mentioned, but by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cavall, Arthur’s own dog.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And after Yskithyrwyn Penbaedd was killed, Arthur and his host departed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Gelli Wic in Cornwall.  And thence he sent Menw the son of Teirgwaedd
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to see if the precious things were between the two ears of Twrch Trwyth,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: since it were useless to encounter him if they were not there.  Albeit it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was certain where he was, for he had laid waste the third part of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Ireland.  And Menw went to seek for him, and he met with him in Ireland,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in Esgeir Oervel.  And Menw took the form of a bird; and he descended
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon the top of his lair, and strove to snatch away one of the precious
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: things from him, but he carried away nothing but one of his bristles.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the boar rose up angrily and shook himself so that some of his venom
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fell upon Menw, and he was never well from that day forward.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After this Arthur sent an embassy to Odgar, the son of Aedd king of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Ireland, to ask for the cauldron of Diwrnach Wyddel, his purveyor.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Odgar commanded him to give it.  But Diwrnach said, “Heaven is my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: witness, if it would avail him anything even to look at it, he should not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: do so.”  And the embassy of Arthur returned from Ireland with this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: denial.  And Arthur set forward with a small retinue, and entered into
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Prydwen, his ship, and went over to Ireland.  And they proceeded into the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: house of Diwrnach Wyddel.  And the hosts of Odgar saw their strength.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When they had eaten and drunk as much as they desired, Arthur demanded to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: have the cauldron.  And he answered, “If I would have given it to any
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: one, I would have given it at the word of Odgar king of Ireland.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When he had given them this denial, Bedwyr arose and seized hold of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cauldron, and placed it upon the back of Hygwyd, Arthur’s servant, who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was brother, by the mother’s side, to Arthur’s servant, Cachamwri.  His
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: office was always to carry Arthur’s cauldron, and to place fire under it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Llenlleawg Wyddel seized Caledvwlch, and brandished it.  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slew Diwrnach Wyddel and his company.  Then came the Irish and fought
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with them.  And when he had put them to flight, Arthur with his men went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forward to the ship, carrying away the cauldron full of Irish money.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he disembarked at the house of Llwydden the son of Kelcoed, at Porth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kerddin in Dyved.  And there is the measure of the cauldron.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Arthur summoned unto him all the warriors that were in the three
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Islands of Britain, and in the three Islands adjacent, and all that were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in France and in Armorica, in Normandy and in the Summer Country, and all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that were chosen footmen and valiant horsemen.  And with all these he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went into Ireland.  And in Ireland there was great fear and terror
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: concerning him.  And when Arthur had landed in the country, there came
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto him the saints of Ireland and besought his protection.  And he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: granted his protection unto them, and they gave him their blessing.  Then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the men of Ireland came unto Arthur, and brought him provisions.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur went as far as Esgeir Oervel in Ireland, to the place where the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Boar Trwyth was with his seven young pigs.  And the dogs were let loose
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon him from all sides.  That day until evening the Irish fought with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him, nevertheless he laid waste the fifth part of Ireland.  And on the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: day following the household of Arthur fought with him, and they were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: worsted by him, and got no advantage.  And the third day Arthur himself
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: encountered him, and he fought with him nine nights and nine days without
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so much as killing even one little pig.  The warriors inquired of Arthur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: what was the origin of that swine; and he told them that he was once a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: king, and that God had transformed him into a swine for his sins.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Arthur sent Gwrhyr Gwalstawt Ieithoedd, to endeavour to speak with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him.  And Gwrhyr assumed the form of a bird, and alighted upon the top of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the lair, where he was with the seven young pigs.  And Gwrhyr Gwalstawt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Ieithoedd asked him, “By him who turned you into this form, if you can
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: speak, let some one of you, I beseech you, come and talk with Arthur.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Grugyn Gwrych Ereint made answer to him.  (Now his bristles were like
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: silver wire, and whether he went through the wood or through the plain,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he was to be traced by the glittering of his bristles.)  And this was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answer that Grugyn made: “By him who turned us into this form, we will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not do so, and we will not speak with Arthur.  That we have been
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: transformed thus is enough for us to suffer, without your coming here to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fight with us.”  “I will tell you.  Arthur comes but to fight for the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: comb, and the razor, and the scissors which are between the two ears of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Twrch Trwyth.”  Said Grugyn, “Except he first take his life, he will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: never have those precious things.  And to-morrow morning we will rise up
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hence, and we will go into Arthur’s country, and there will we do all the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mischief that we can.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they set forth through the sea towards Wales.  And Arthur and his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hosts, and his horses and his dogs, entered Prydwen, that they might
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: encounter them without delay.  Twrch Trwyth landed in Porth Cleis in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Dyved, and Arthur came to Mynyw.  The next day it was told to Arthur that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they had gone by, and he overtook them as they were killing the cattle of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kynnwas Kwrr y Vagyl, having slain all that were at Aber Gleddyf, of man
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and beast, before the coming of Arthur.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now when Arthur approached, Twrch Trwyth went on as far as Preseleu, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur and his hosts followed him thither, and Arthur sent men to hunt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him; Eli and Trachmyr, leading Drudwyn the whelp of Greid the son of Eri,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Gwarthegyd the son of Kaw, in another quarter, with the two dogs of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Glythmyr Ledewic, and Bedwyr leading Cavall, Arthur’s own dog.  And all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the warriors ranged themselves around the Nyver.  And there came there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the three sons of Cleddyf Divwlch, men who had gained much fame at the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slaying of Yskithyrwyn Penbaedd; and they went on from Glyn Nyver, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came to Cwm Kerwyn.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And there Twrch Trwyth made a stand, and slew four of Arthur’s champions,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwarthegyd the son of Kaw, and Tarawc of Allt Clwyd, and Rheidwn the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Eli Atver, and Iscovan Hael.  And after he had slain these men, he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: made a second stand in the same place.  And there he slew Gwydre the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Arthur, and Garselit Wyddel, and Glew the son of Ysgawd, and Iscawyn
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the son of Panon; and there he himself was wounded.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next morning before it was day, some of the men came up with him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he slew Huandaw, and Gogigwr, and Penpingon, three attendants upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Glewlwyd Gavaelvawr, so that Heaven knows he had not an attendant
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: remaining, excepting only Llaesgevyn, a man from whom no one ever derived
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: any good.  And together with these he slew many of the men of that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: country, and Gwlydyn Saer, Arthur’s chief Architect.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Arthur overtook him at Pelumyawc, and there he slew Madawc the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Teithyon, and Gwyn the son of Tringad, the son of Neved, and Eiryawn
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Penllorau.  Thence he went to Aberteivi, where he made another stand, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: where he slew Kyflas the son of Kynan, and Gwilenhin king of France.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then he went as far as Glyn Ystu, and there the men and the dogs lost
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Arthur summoned unto him Gwyn ab Nudd, and he asked him if he knew
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: aught of Twrch Trwyth.  And he said that he did not.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And all the huntsmen went to hunt the swine as far as Dyffryn Llychwr.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Grugyn Gwallt Ereint and Llwydawg Govynnyad closed with them and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: killed all the huntsmen, so that there escaped but one man only.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur and his hosts came to the place where Grugyn and Llwydawg were.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And there he let loose the whole of the dogs upon them, and with the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shout and barking that was set up, Twrch Trwyth came to their assistance.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And from the time that they came across the Irish sea, Arthur had never
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: got sight of him until then.  So he set men and dogs upon him, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thereupon he started off and went to Mynydd Amanw.  And there one of his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: young pigs was killed.  Then they set upon him life for life, and Twrch
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Llawin was slain, and then there was slain another of the swine, Gwys was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his name.  After that he went on to Dyffryn Amanw, and there Banw and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Bennwig were killed.  Of all his pigs there went with him alive from that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: place none save Grugyn Gwallt Ereint and Llwydawg Govynnyad.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thence he went on to Llwch Ewin, and Arthur overtook him there, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: made a stand.  And there he slew Echel Forddwytwll, and Garwyli the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Gwyddawg Gwyr, and many men and dogs likewise.  And thence they went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Llwch Tawy.  Grugyn Gwrych Ereint parted from them there, and went to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Din Tywi.  And thence he proceeded to Ceredigiawn, and Eli and Trachmyr
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with him, and a multitude likewise.  Then he came to Garth Gregyn, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there Llwydawg Govynnyad fought in the midst of them, and slew Rhudvyw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhys and many others with him.  Then Llwydawg went thence to Ystrad Yw,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and there the men of Armorica met him, and there he slew Hirpeissawg the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: king of Armorica, and Llygatrudd Emys, and Gwrbothu, Arthur’s uncles, his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mother’s brothers, and there was he himself slain.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Twrch Trwyth went from there to between Tawy and Euyas, and Arthur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: summoned all Cornwall and Devon unto him, to the estuary of the Severn,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and he said to the warriors of this Island, “Twrch Trwyth has slain many
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of my men, but, by the valour of warriors, while I live he shall not go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: into Cornwall.  And I will not follow him any longer, but I will oppose
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him life to life.  Do ye as ye will.”  And he resolved that he would send
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a body of knights, with the dogs of the Island, as far as Euyas, who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should return thence to the Severn, and that tried warriors should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: traverse the Island, and force him into the Severn.  And Mabon the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Modron came up with him at the Severn, upon Gwynn Mygdwn, the horse of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gweddw, and Goreu the son of Custennin, and Menw the son of Teirgwaedd;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this was betwixt Llyn Lliwan and Aber Gwy.  And Arthur fell upon him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: together with the champions of Britain.  And Osla Kyllellvawr drew near,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Manawyddan the son of Llyr, and Kacmwri the servant of Arthur, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwyngelli, and they seized hold of him, catching him first by his feet,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and plunged him in the Severn, so that it overwhelmed him.  On the one
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: side, Mabon the son of Modron spurred his steed and snatched his razor
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from him, and Kyledyr Wyllt came up with him on the other side, upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: another steed, in the Severn, and took from him the scissors.  But before
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they could obtain the comb, he had regained the ground with his feet, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from the moment that he reached the shore, neither dog, nor man, nor
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: horse could overtake him until he came to Cornwall.  If they had had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: trouble in getting the jewels from him, much more had they in seeking to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: save the two men from being drowned.  Kacmwri, as they drew him forth,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was dragged by two millstones into the deep.  And as Osla Kyllellvawr was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: running after the boar, his knife had dropped out of the sheath, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had lost it, and after that, the sheath became full of water, and its
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: weight drew him down into the deep, as they were drawing him forth.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Arthur and his hosts proceeded until they overtook the boar in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cornwall, and the trouble which they had met with before was mere play to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: what they encountered in seeking the comb.  But from one difficulty to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: another, the comb was at length obtained.  And then he was hunted from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cornwall, and driven straight forward into the deep sea.  And thenceforth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it was never known whither he went; and Aned and Aethlem with him.  Then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went Arthur to Gelli Wic, in Cornwall, to anoint himself, and to rest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from his fatigues.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Said Arthur, “Is there any one of the marvels yet unobtained?”  Said one
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of his men, “There is—the blood of the witch Orddu, the daughter of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: witch Orwen, of Pen Nant Govid, on the confines of Hell.”  Arthur set
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forth towards the North, and came to the place where was the witch’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cave.  And Gwyn ab Nudd, and Gwythyr the son of Greidawl, counselled him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to send Kacmwri, and Hygwyd his brother, to fight with the witch.  And as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they entered the cave, the witch seized upon them, and she caught Hygwyd
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by the hair of his head, and threw him on the floor beneath her.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kacmwri caught her by the hair of her head, and dragged her to the earth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from off Hygwyd, but she turned again upon them both, and drove them both
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: out with kicks and with cuffs.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Arthur was wroth at seeing his two attendants almost slain, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sought to enter the cave; but Gwyn and Gwythyr said unto him, “It would
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not be fitting or seemly for us to see thee squabbling with a hag.  Let
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Hiramreu and Hireidil go to the cave.”  So they went.  But if great was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the trouble of the first two that went, much greater was that of these
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: two.  And Heaven knows that not one of the four could move from the spot,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: until they placed them all upon Llamrei, Arthur’s mare.  And then Arthur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rushed to the door of the cave, and at the door he struck at the witch,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with Carnwennan his dagger, and clove her in twain, so that she fell in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: two parts.  And Kaw, of North Britain, took the blood of the witch and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kept it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Kilhwch set forward, and Goreu the son of Custennin with him, and as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: many as wished ill to Yspaddaden Penkawr.  And they took the marvels with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them to his court.  And Kaw of North Britain came and shaved his beard,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: skin, and flesh clean off to the very bone from ear to ear.  “Art thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shaved, man?” said Kilhwch.  “I am shaved,” answered he.  “Is thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: daughter mine now?”  “She is thine,” said he, “but therefore needest thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not thank me, but Arthur who hath accomplished this for thee.  By my free
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will thou shouldest never have had her, for with her I lose my life.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Goreu the son of Custennin seized him by the hair of his head, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dragged him after him to the keep, and cut off his head and placed it on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a stake on the citadel.  Then they took possession of his castle, and of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his treasures.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And that night Olwen became Kilhwch’s bride, and she continued to be his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wife as long as she lived.  And the hosts of Arthur dispersed themselves,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: each man to his own country.  And thus did Kilhwch obtain Olwen, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: daughter of Yspaddaden Penkawr.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: THE DREAM OF RHONABWY
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: MADAWC the son of Maredudd possessed Powys within its boundaries, from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Porfoed to Gwauan in the uplands of Arwystli.  And at that time he had a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: brother, Iorwerth the son of Maredudd, in rank not equal to himself.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Iorwerth had great sorrow and heaviness because of the honour and power
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that his brother enjoyed, which he shared not.  And he sought his fellows
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and his foster-brothers, and took counsel with them what he should do in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this matter.  And they resolved to dispatch some of their number to go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and seek a maintenance for him.  Then Madawc offered him to become Master
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the Household and to have horses, and arms, and honour, and to fare
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: like as himself.  But Iorwerth refused this.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Iorwerth made an inroad into Loegria, slaying the inhabitants, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: burning houses, and carrying away prisoners.  And Madawc took counsel
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with the men of Powys, and they determined to place an hundred men in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: each of the three Commots of Powys to seek for him.  And thus did they in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the plains of Powys from Aber Ceirawc, and in Allictwn Ver, and in Rhyd
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Wilure, on the Vyrnwy, the three best Commots of Powys.  So he was none
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the better, he nor his household, in Powys, nor in the plains thereof.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they spread these men over the plains as far as Nillystwn Trevan.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now one of the men who was upon this quest was called Rhonabwy.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhonabwy and Kynwrig Vrychgoch, a man of Mawddwy, and Cadwgan Vras, a man
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Moelvre in Kynlleith, came together to the house of Heilyn Goch the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: son of Cadwgan the son of Iddon.  And when they came near to the house,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they saw an old hall, very black and having an upright gable, whence
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: issued a great smoke; and on entering, they found the floor full of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: puddles and mounds; and it was difficult to stand thereon, so slippery
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was it with the mire of cattle.  And where the puddles were, a man might
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: go up to his ankles in water and dirt.  And there were boughs of holly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: spread over the floor, whereof the cattle had browsed the sprigs.  When
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they came to the hall of the house, they beheld cells full of dust, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: very gloomy, and on one side an old hag making a fire.  And whenever she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: felt cold, she cast a lapful of chaff upon the fire, and raised such a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: smoke, that it was scarcely to be borne, as it rose up the nostrils.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on the other side was a yellow calf-skin on the floor; a main privilege
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was it to any one who should get upon that hide.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when they had sat down, they asked the hag where were the people of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the house.  And the hag spoke not, but muttered.  Thereupon behold the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: people of the house entered; a ruddy, clownish, curly-headed man, with a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: burthen of faggots on his back, and a pale slender woman, also carrying a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bundle under her arm.  And they barely welcomed the men, and kindled a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fire with the boughs.  And the woman cooked something, and gave them to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: eat, barley bread, and cheese, and milk and water.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And there arose a storm of wind and rain, so that it was hardly possible
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to go forth with safety.  And being weary with their journey, they laid
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: themselves down and sought to sleep.  And when they looked at the couch,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it seemed to be made but of a little coarse straw full of dust and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: vermin, with the stems of boughs sticking up there-through, for the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cattle had eaten all the straw that was placed at the head and the foot.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And upon it was stretched an old russet-coloured rug, threadbare and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ragged; and a coarse sheet, full of slits, was upon the rug, and an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ill-stuffed pillow, and a worn-out cover upon the sheet.  And after much
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: suffering from the vermin, and from the discomfort of their couch, a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heavy sleep fell on Rhonabwy’s companions.  But Rhonabwy, not being able
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: either to sleep or to rest, thought he should suffer less if he went to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lie upon the yellow calf-skin that was stretched out on the floor.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there he slept.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: As soon as sleep had come upon his eyes, it seemed to him that he was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: journeying with his companions across the plain of Argyngroeg, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thought that he went towards Rhyd y Groes on the Severn.  As he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: journeyed, he heard a mighty noise, the like whereof heard he never
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: before; and looking behind him, he beheld a youth with yellow curling
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hair, and with his beard newly trimmed, mounted on a chestnut horse,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whereof the legs were grey from the top of the forelegs, and from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bend of the hindlegs downwards.  And the rider wore a coat of yellow
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: satin sewn with green silk, and on his thigh was a gold-hilted sword,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with a scabbard of new leather of Cordova, belted with the skin of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: deer, and clasped with gold.  And over this was a scarf of yellow satin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wrought with green silk, the borders whereof were likewise green.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the green of the caparison of the horse, and of his rider, was as green
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as the leaves of the fir-tree, and the yellow was as yellow as the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: blossom of the broom.  So fierce was the aspect of the knight, that fear
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seized upon them, and they began to flee.  And the knight pursued them.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when the horse breathed forth, the men became distant from him, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when he drew in his breath, they were drawn near to him, even to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: horse’s chest.  And when he had overtaken them, they besought his mercy.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “You have it gladly,” said he, “fear nought.”  “Ha, chieftain, since thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hast mercy upon me, tell me also who thou art,” said Rhonabwy.  “I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not conceal my lineage from thee, I am Iddawc the son of Mynyo, yet not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by my name, but by my nickname am I best known.”  “And wilt thou tell us
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: what thy nickname is?”  “I will tell you; it is Iddawc Cordd Prydain.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Ha, chieftain,” said Rhonabwy, “why art thou called thus?”  “I will tell
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee.  I was one of the messengers between Arthur and Medrawd his nephew,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: at the battle of Camlan; and I was then a reckless youth, and through my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: desire for battle, I kindled strife between them, and stirred up wrath,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when I was sent by Arthur the Emperor to reason with Medrawd, and to show
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him, that he was his foster-father and his uncle, and to seek for peace,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lest the sons of the Kings of the Island of Britain, and of the nobles,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should be slain.  And whereas Arthur charged me with the fairest sayings
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he could think of, I uttered unto Medrawd the harshest I could devise.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And therefore am I called Iddawc Cordd Prydain, for from this did the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: battle of Camlan ensue.  And three nights before the end of the battle of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Camlan I left them, and went to the Llech Las in North Britain to do
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: penance.  And there I remained doing penance seven years, and after that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I gained pardon.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then lo! they heard a mighty sound which was much louder than that which
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they had heard before, and when they looked round towards the sound, they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld a ruddy youth, without beard or whiskers, noble of mien, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mounted on a stately courser.  And from the shoulders and the front of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the knees downwards the horse was bay.  And upon the man was a dress of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: red satin wrought with yellow silk, and yellow were the borders of his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: scarf.  And such parts of his apparel and of the trappings of his horse
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as were yellow, as yellow were they as the blossom of the broom, and such
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as were red, were as ruddy as the ruddiest blood in the world.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then, behold the horseman overtook them, and he asked of Iddawc a share
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the little men that were with him.  “That which is fitting for me to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grant I will grant, and thou shalt be a companion to them as I have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: been.”  And the horseman went away.  “Iddawc,” inquired Rhonabwy, “who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was that horseman?”  “Rhuvawn Pebyr the son of Prince Deorthach.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they journeyed over the plain of Argyngroeg as far as the ford of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhyd y Groes on the Severn.  And for a mile around the ford on both sides
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the road, they saw tents and encampments, and there was the clamour of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a mighty host.  And they came to the edge of the ford, and there they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld Arthur sitting on a flat island below the ford, having Bedwini the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Bishop on one side of him, and Gwarthegyd the son of Kaw on the other.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And a tall, auburn-haired youth stood before him, with his sheathed sword
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in his hand, and clad in a coat and cap of jet-black satin.  And his face
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was white as ivory, and his eyebrows black as jet, and such part of his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wrist as could be seen between his glove and his sleeve, was whiter than
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the lily, and thicker than a warrior’s ankle.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then came Iddawc and they that were with him, and stood before Arthur and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saluted him.  “Heaven grant thee good,” said Arthur.  “And where, Iddawc,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: didst thou find these little men?”  “I found them, lord, up yonder on the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: road.”  Then the Emperor smiled.  “Lord,” said Iddawc, “wherefore dost
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou laugh?”  “Iddawc,” replied Arthur, “I laugh not; but it pitieth me
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that men of such stature as these should have this island in their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: keeping, after the men that guarded it of yore.”  Then said Iddawc,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Rhonabwy, dost thou see the ring with a stone set in it, that is upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Emperor’s hand?”  “I see it,” he answered.  “It is one of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: properties of that stone to enable thee to remember that thou seest here
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to-night, and hadst thou not seen the stone, thou wouldest never have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: been able to remember aught thereof.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After this they saw a troop coming towards the ford.  “Iddawc,” inquired
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhonabwy, “to whom does yonder troop belong?”  “They are the fellows of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhuvawn Pebyr the son of Prince Deorthach.  And these men are honourably
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: served with mead and bragget, and are freely beloved by the daughters of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the kings of the Island of Britain.  And this they merit, for they were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ever in the front and the rear in every peril.”  And he saw but one hue
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon the men and the horses of this troop, for they were all as red as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: blood.  And when one of the knights rode forth from the troop, he looked
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: like a pillar of fire glancing athwart the sky.  And this troop encamped
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: above the ford.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then they beheld another troop coming towards the ford, and these from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their horses’ chests upwards were whiter than the lily, and below blacker
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than jet.  And they saw one of these knights go before the rest, and spur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his horse into the ford in such a manner that the water dashed over
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Arthur and the Bishop, and those holding counsel with them, so that they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were as wet as if they had been drenched in the river.  And as he turned
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the head of his horse, the youth who stood before Arthur struck the horse
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: over the nostrils with his sheathed sword, so that, had it been with the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bare blade, it would have been a marvel if the bone had not been wounded
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as well as the flesh.  And the knight drew his sword half out of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: scabbard, and asked of him, “Wherefore didst thou strike my horse?
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Whether was it in insult or in counsel unto me?”  “Thou dost indeed lack
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsel.  What madness caused thee to ride so furiously as to dash the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: water of the ford over Arthur, and the consecrated Bishop, and their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsellors, so that they were as wet as if they had been dragged out of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the river?”  “As counsel then will I take it.”  So he turned his horse’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: head round towards his army.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Iddawc,” said Rhonabwy, “who was yonder knight?”  “The most eloquent and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the wisest youth that is in this island; Adaon, the son of Taliesin.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Who was the man that struck his horse?”  “A youth of froward nature;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Elphin, the son of Gwyddno.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then spake a tall and stately man, of noble and flowing speech, saying
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that it was a marvel that so vast a host should be assembled in so narrow
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a space, and that it was a still greater marvel that those should be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there at that time who had promised to be by mid-day in the battle of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Badon, fighting with Osla Gyllellvawr.  “Whether thou mayest choose to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: proceed or not, I will proceed.”  “Thou sayest well,” said Arthur, “and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: we will go altogether.”  “Iddawc,” said Rhonabwy, “who was the man who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: spoke so marvellously unto Arthur erewhile?”  “A man who may speak as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boldly as he listeth, Caradawc Vreichvras, the son of Llyr Marini, his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chief counsellor and his cousin.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Iddawc took Rhonabwy behind him on his horse, and that mighty host
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: moved forward, each troop in its order, towards Cevndigoll.  And when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they came to the middle of the ford of the Severn, Iddawc turned his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: horse’s head, and Rhonabwy looked along the valley of the Severn.  And he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld two fair troops coming towards the ford.  One troop there came of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: brilliant white, whereof every one of the men had a scarf of white satin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with jet-black borders.  And the knees and the tops of the shoulders of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their horses were jet-black, though they were of a pure white in every
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: other part.  And their banners were pure white, with black points to them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: all.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Iddawc,” said Rhonabwy, “who are yonder pure white troop?”  “They are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the men of Norway, and March the son of Meirchion is their prince.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he is cousin unto Arthur.”  And further on he saw a troop, whereof each
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: man wore garments of jet-black, with borders of pure white to every
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: scarf; and the tops of the shoulders and the knees of their horses were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pure white.  And their banners were jet-black with pure white at the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: point of each.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Iddawc,” said Rhonabwy, “who are the jet-black troop yonder?”  “They are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the men of Denmark, and Edeyrn the son of Nudd is their prince.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when they had overtaken the host, Arthur and his army of mighty ones
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dismounted below Caer Badou, and he perceived that he and Iddawc
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: journeyed the same road as Arthur.  And after they had dismounted he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heard a great tumult and confusion amongst the host, and such as were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: then at the flanks turned to the centre, and such as had been in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: centre moved to the flanks.  And then, behold, he saw a knight coming,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: clad, both he and his horse, in mail, of which the rings were whiter than
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the whitest lily, and the rivets redder than the ruddiest blood.  And he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rode amongst the host.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Iddawc,” said Rhonabwy, “will yonder host flee?”  “King Arthur never
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fled, and if this discourse of thine were heard, thou wert a lost man.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: But as to the knight whom thou seest yonder, it is Kai.  The fairest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: horseman is Kai in all Arthur’s Court; and the men who are at the front
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the army hasten to the rear to see Kai ride, and the men who are in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the centre flee to the side, from the shock of his horse.  And this is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the cause of the confusion of the host.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thereupon they heard a call made for Kadwr, Earl of Cornwall, and behold
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he arose with the sword of Arthur in his hand.  And the similitude of two
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: serpents was upon the sword in gold.  And when the sword was drawn from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: its scabbard, it seemed as if two flames of fire burst forth from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: jaws of the serpents, and then, so wonderful was the sword, that it was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hard for any one to look upon it.  And the host became still, and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tumult ceased, and the Earl returned to the tent.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Iddawc,” said Rhonabwy, “who is the man who bore the sword of Arthur?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Kadwr, the Earl of Cornwall, whose duty it is to arm the King on the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: days of battle and warfare.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they heard a call made for Eirynwych Amheibyn, Arthur’s servant, a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: red, rough, ill-favoured man, having red whiskers with bristly hairs.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And behold he came upon a tall red horse with the mane parted on each
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: side, and he brought with him a large and beautiful sumpter pack.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the huge red youth dismounted before Arthur, and he drew a golden chair
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: out of the pack, and a carpet of diapered satin.  And he spread the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: carpet before Arthur, and there was an apple of ruddy gold at each corner
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thereof, and he placed the chair upon the carpet.  And so large was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chair that three armed warriors might have sat therein.  Gwenn was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: name of the carpet, and it was one of its properties that whoever was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon it no one could see him, and he could see every one.  And it would
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: retain no colour but its own.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Arthur sat within the carpet, and Owain the son of Urien was standing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: before him.  “Owain,” said Arthur, “wilt thou play chess?”  “I will,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lord,” said Owain.  And the red youth brought the chess for Arthur and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Owain; golden pieces and a board of silver.  And they began to play.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And while they were thus, and when they were best amused with their game,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: behold they saw a white tent with a red canopy, and the figure of a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: jet-black serpent on the top of the tent, and red glaring venomous eyes
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the head of the serpent, and a red flaming tongue.  And there came a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: young page with yellow curling hair, and blue eyes, and a newly-springing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beard, wearing a coat and a surcoat of yellow satin, and hose of thin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greenish-yellow cloth upon his feet, and over his hose shoes of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: parti-coloured leather, fastened at the insteps with golden clasps.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he bore a heavy three-edged sword with a golden hilt, in a scabbard of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: black leather tipped with fine gold.  And he came to the place where the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Emperor and Owain were playing at chess.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the youth saluted Owain.  And Owain marvelled that the youth should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: salute him and should not have saluted the Emperor Arthur.  And Arthur
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: knew what was in Owain’s thought.  And he said to Owain, “Marvel not that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the youth salutes thee now, for he saluted me erewhile; and it is unto
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee that his errand is.”  Then said the youth unto Owain, “Lord, is it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with thy leave that the young pages and attendants of the Emperor harass
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and torment and worry thy Ravens?  And if it be not with thy leave, cause
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Emperor to forbid them.”  “Lord,” said Owain, “thou hearest what the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: youth says; if it seem good to thee, forbid them from my Ravens.”  “Play
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy game,” said he.  Then the youth returned to the tent.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That game did they finish, and another they began, and when they were in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the midst of the game, behold, a ruddy young man with auburn curling hair
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and large eyes, well-grown, and having his beard new-shorn, came forth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bright red lion.  And he was clad in a coat of yellow satin, falling as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: low as the small of his leg, and embroidered with threads of red silk.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: leather were over his hose, whereon were golden clasps.  And in his hand
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a huge, heavy, three-edged sword, with a scabbard of red deer-hide,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tipped with gold.  And he came to the place where Arthur and Owain were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: playing at chess.  And he saluted him.  And Owain was troubled at his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: salutation, but Arthur minded it no more than before.  And the youth said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto Owain, “Is it not against thy will that the attendants of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Emperor harass thy Ravens, killing some and worrying others?  If against
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy will it be, beseech him to forbid them.”  “Lord,” said Owain, “forbid
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy men, if it seem good to thee.”  “Play thy game,” said the Emperor.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the youth returned to the tent.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of gold upon it, and a precious stone on the eagle’s head.  And coming
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the scarf upon his right shoulder as large as a warrior’s middle
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: finger.  And upon his feet were hose of fine Totness, and shoes of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: parti-coloured leather, clasped with gold, and the youth was of noble
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bearing, fair of face, with ruddy cheeks and large hawk’s eyes.  In the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: newly-sharpened head; and upon the lance a banner displayed.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Fiercely angry, and with rapid pace, came the youth to the place where
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wroth.  And thereupon he saluted Owain, and told him that his Ravens had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there lift up the banner, and let come what pleases Heaven.”

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon the Ravens, and he lifted up the banner; and as he did so they all

text: PWYLL PRINCE OF DYVED
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: PWYLL PRINCE OF DYVED was lord of the seven Cantrevs of Dyved; and once
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon a time he was at Narberth his chief palace, and he was minded to go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and hunt, and the part of his dominions in which it pleased him to hunt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was Glyn Cuch.  So he set forth from Narbeth that night, and went as far
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as Llwyn Diarwyd.  And that night he tarried there, and early on the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: morrow he rose and came to Glyn Cuch, when he let loose the dogs in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wood, and sounded the horn, and began the chase.  And as he followed the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dogs, he lost his companions; and whilst he listened to the hounds, he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heard the cry of other hounds, a cry different from his own, and coming
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the opposite direction.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he beheld a glade in the wood forming a level plain, and as his dogs
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came to the edge of the glade, he saw a stag before the other dogs.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lo, as it reached the middle of the glade, the dogs that followed the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stag overtook it and brought it down.  Then looked he at the colour of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the dogs, staying not to look at the stag, and of all the hounds that he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had seen in the world, he had never seen any that were like unto these.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For their hair was of a brilliant shining white, and their ears were red;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and as the whiteness of their bodies shone, so did the redness of their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ears glisten.  And he came towards the dogs, and drove away those that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had brought down the stag, and set his own dogs upon it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And as he was setting on his dogs he saw a horseman coming towards him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon a large light-grey steed, with a hunting horn round his neck, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: clad in garments of grey woollen in the fashion of a hunting garb.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the horseman drew near and spoke unto him thus.  “Chieftain,” said he, “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: know who thou art, and I greet thee not.”  “Peradventure,” said Pwyll,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “thou art of such dignity that thou shouldest not do so.”  “Verily,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered he, “it is not my dignity that prevents me.”  “What is it then,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: O Chieftain?” asked he.  “By Heaven, it is by reason of thine own
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ignorance and want of courtesy.”  “What discourtesy, Chieftain, hast thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seen in me?”  “Greater discourtesy saw I never in man,” said he, “than to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: drive away the dogs that were killing the stag and to set upon it thine
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: own.  This was discourteous, and though I may not be revenged upon thee,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: yet I declare to Heaven that I will do thee more dishonour than the value
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of an hundred stags.”  “O Chieftain,” he replied, “if I have done ill I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will redeem thy friendship.”  “How wilt thou redeem it?”  “According as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy dignity may be, but I know not who thou art?”  “A crowned king am I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the land whence I come.”  “Lord,” said he, “may the day prosper with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee, and from what land comest thou?”  “From Annwvyn,” {2} answered he;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Arawn, a King of Annwvyn, am I.”  “Lord,” said he, “how may I gain thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: friendship?”  “After this manner mayest thou,” he said.  “There is a man
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whose dominions are opposite to mine, who is ever warring against me, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he is Havgan, a King of Annwvyn, and by ridding me of this oppression,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which thou canst easily do, shalt thou gain my friendship.”  “Gladly will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I do this,” said he.  “Show me how I may.”  “I will show thee.  Behold
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thus it is thou mayest.  I will make firm friendship with thee; and this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will I do.  I will send thee to Annwvyn in my stead, and I will give thee
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the fairest lady thou didst ever behold to be thy companion, and I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: put my form and semblance upon thee, so that not a page of the chamber,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nor an officer, nor any other man that has always followed me shall know
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that it is not I.  And this shall be for the space of a year from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to-morrow, and then we will meet in this place.”  “Yes,” said he; “but
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when I shall have been there for the space of a year, by what means shall
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I discover him of whom thou speakest?”  “One year from this night,” he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered, “is the time fixed between him and me that we should meet at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Ford; be thou there in my likeness, and with one stroke that thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: givest him, he shall no longer live.  And if he ask thee to give him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: another, give it not, how much soever he may entreat thee, for when I did
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so, he fought with me next day as well as ever before.”  “Verily,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pwyll, “what shall I do concerning my kingdom?”  Said Arawn, “I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cause that no one in all thy dominions, neither man nor woman, shall know
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that I am not thou, and I will go there in thy stead.”  “Gladly then,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Pwyll, “will I set forward.”  “Clear shall be thy path, and nothing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shall detain thee, until thou come into my dominions, and I myself will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be thy guide!”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So he conducted him until he came in sight of the palace and its
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

author: NA

text: beheld.  And she had on a yellow robe of shining satin; and they washed

text: and went to the table, and sat, the Queen upon one side of him, and one

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

author: NA

text: supplied with food and drink, and vessels of gold and royal jewels.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the year he spent in hunting, and minstrelsy, and feasting, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: diversions, and discourse with his companions until the night that was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fixed for the conflict.  And when that night came, it was remembered even
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by those who lived in the furthest part of his dominions, and he went to
title: The Mabinogion
