text: the meeting, and the nobles of the kingdom with him.  And when he came to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Ford, a knight arose and spake thus.  “Lords,” said he, “listen well.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It is between two kings that this meeting is, and between them only.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stand aside and leave the fight to be between them.”
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

text: Arawn struck Havgan on the centre of the boss of his shield, so that it
title: The Mabinogion

text: was cloven in twain, and his armour was broken, and Havgan himself was
title: The Mabinogion

text: horse, and he received a deadly blow.  “O Chieftain,” said Havgan, “what
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

text: and I know not wherefore thou wouldest slay me.  But, for the love of
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: who may, I will not do so.”  “My trusty Lords,” said Havgan, “bear me

text: hence.  My death has come.  I shall be no more able to uphold you.”  “My
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and know who ought to be my subjects.”  “Lord,” said the Nobles, “all
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

author: NA

text: And when he came there, the King of Annwvyn was there to meet him, and
title: The Mabinogion

text: each of them was rejoiced to see the other.  “Verily,” said Arawn, “may
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When thou comest thyself to thy dominions,” said he, “thou wilt see that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

text: Once upon a time, Pwyll was at Narberth his chief palace, where a feast

text: “Lord,” said the man in the bag, “if thou wouldest but hear me, I merit
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not to be slain in a bag.”  Said Heveydd Hên, “Lord, he speaks truth.  It
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were fitting that thou listen to him, for he deserves not this.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Verily,” said Pwyll, “I will do thy counsel concerning him.”  “Behold
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this is my counsel then,” said Rhiannon; “thou art now in a position in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which it behoves thee to satisfy suitors and minstrels; let him give unto
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them in thy stead, and take a pledge from him that he will never seek to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: revenge that which has been done to him.  And this will be punishment
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: enough.”  “I will do this gladly,” said the man in the bag.  “And gladly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will I accept it,” said Pwyll, “since it is the counsel of Heveydd and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhiannon.”  “Such then is our counsel,” answered they.  “I accept it,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Pwyll.  “Seek thyself sureties.”  “We will be for him,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Heveydd, “until his men be free to answer for him.”  And upon this he was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: let out of the bag, and his liegemen were liberated.  “Demand now of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwawl his sureties,” said Heveydd, “we know which should be taken for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him.”  And Heveydd numbered the sureties.  Said Gwawl, “Do thou thyself
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: draw up the covenant.”  “It will suffice me that it be as Rhiannon said,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered Pwyll.  So unto that covenant were the sureties pledged.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Verily, Lord,” said Gwawl, “I am greatly hurt, and I have many bruises.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have need to be anointed; with thy leave I will go forth.  I will leave
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nobles in my stead, to answer for me in all that thou shalt require.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Willingly,” said Pwyll, “mayest thou do thus.”  So Gwawl went towards
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his own possessions.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the hall was set in order for Pwyll and the men of his host, and for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them also of the palace, and they went to the tables and sat down.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as they had sat that time twelvemonth, so sat they that night.  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ate, and feasted, and spent the night in mirth and tranquillity.  And the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: time came that they should sleep, and Pwyll and Rhiannon went to their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chamber.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And next morning at the break of day, “My Lord,” said Rhiannon, “arise
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and begin to give thy gifts unto the minstrels.  Refuse no one to-day
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that may claim thy bounty.”  “Thus shall it be gladly,” said Pwyll, “both
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to-day and every day while the feast shall last.”  So Pwyll arose, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: caused silence to be proclaimed, and desired all the suitors and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: minstrels to show and to point out what gifts were to their wish and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: desire.  And this being done, the feast went on, and he denied no one
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: while it lasted.  And when the feast was ended, Pwyll said unto Heveydd,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “My Lord, with thy permission I will set out for Dyved to-morrow.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Certainly,” said Heveydd, “may Heaven prosper thee.  Fix also a time
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when Rhiannon may follow thee.”  “By Heaven,” said Pwyll, “we will go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hence together.”  “Willest thou this, Lord?” said Heveydd.  “Yes, by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Heaven,” answered Pwyll.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next day, they set forward towards Dyved, and journeyed to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: palace of Narberth, where a feast was made ready for them.  And there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came to them great numbers of the chief men and the most noble ladies of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the land, and of these there was none to whom Rhiannon did not give some
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rich gift, either a bracelet, or a ring, or a precious stone.  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ruled the land prosperously both that year and the next.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And in the third year the nobles of the land began to be sorrowful at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seeing a man whom they loved so much, and who was moreover their lord and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their foster-brother, without an heir.  And they came to him.  And the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: place where they met was Preseleu, in Dyved.  “Lord,” said they, “we know
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that thou art not so young as some of the men of this country, and we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fear that thou mayest not have an heir of the wife whom thou hast taken.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Take therefore another wife of whom thou mayest have heirs.  Thou canst
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not always continue with us, and though thou desire to remain as thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: art, we will not suffer thee.”  “Truly,” said Pwyll, “we have not long
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: been joined together, and many things may yet befall.  Grant me a year
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from this time, and for the space of a year we will abide together, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: after that I will do according to your wishes.”  So they granted it.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: before the end of a year a son was born unto him.  And in Narberth was he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: born; and on the night that he was born, women were brought to watch the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mother and the boy.  And the women slept, as did also Rhiannon, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mother of the boy.  And the number of the women that were brought into
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the chamber was six.  And they watched for a good portion of the night,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and before midnight every one of them fell asleep, and towards break of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: day they awoke; and when they awoke, they looked where they had put the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boy, and behold he was not there.  “Oh,” said one of the women, “the boy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: is lost?”  “Yes,” said another, “and it will be small vengeance if we are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: burnt or put to death because of the child.”  Said one of the women, “Is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there any counsel for us in the world in this matter?”  “There is,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered another, “I offer you good counsel.”  “What is that?” asked
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they.  “There is here a stag-hound bitch, and she has a litter of whelps.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Let us kill some of the cubs, and rub the blood on the face and hands of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhiannon, and lay the bones before her, and assert that she herself hath
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: devoured her son, and she alone will not be able to gainsay us six.”  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: according to this counsel it was settled.  And towards morning Rhiannon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: awoke, and she said, “Women, where is my son?”  “Lady,” said they, “ask
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: us not concerning thy son, we have nought but the blows and the bruises
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: we got by struggling with thee, and of a truth we never saw any woman so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: violent as thou, for it was of no avail to contend with thee.  Hast thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not thyself devoured thy son?  Claim him not therefore of us.”  “For
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pity’s sake,” said Rhiannon; “the Lord God knows all things.  Charge me
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not falsely.  If you tell me this from fear, I assert before Heaven that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I will defend you.”  “Truly,” said they, “we would not bring evil on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ourselves for any one in the world.”  “For pity’s sake,” said Rhiannon,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “you will receive no evil by telling the truth.”  But for all her words,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whether fair or harsh, she received but the same answer from the women.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Pwyll the chief of Annwvyn arose, and his household, and his hosts.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And this occurrence could not be concealed, but the story went forth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: throughout the land, and all the nobles heard it.  Then the nobles came
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Pwyll, and besought him to put away his wife, because of the great
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: crime which she had done.  But Pwyll answered them, that they had no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cause wherefore they might ask him to put away his wife, save for her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: having no children.  “But children has she now had, therefore will I not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: put her away; if she has done wrong, let her do penance for it.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So Rhiannon sent for the teachers and the wise men, and as she preferred
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: doing penance to contending with the women, she took upon her a penance.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the penance that was imposed upon her was, that she should remain in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that palace of Narberth until the end of seven years, and that she should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sit every day near unto a horseblock that was without the gate.  And that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she should relate the story to all who should come there, whom she might
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: suppose not to know it already; and that she should offer the guests and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: strangers, if they would permit her, to carry them upon her back into the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: palace.  But it rarely happened that any would permit.  And thus did she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: spend part of the year.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now at that time Teirnyon Twryv Vliant was Lord of Gwent Is Coed, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was the best man in the world.  And unto his house there belonged a mare,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than which neither mare nor horse in the kingdom was more beautiful.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on the night of every first of May she foaled, and no one ever knew what
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: became of the colt.  And one night Teirnyon talked with his wife: “Wife,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said he, “it is very simple of us that our mare should foal every year,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and that we should have none of her colts.”  “What can be done in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: matter?” said she.  “This is the night of the first of May,” said he.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “The vengeance of Heaven be upon me, if I learn not what it is that takes
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: away the colts.”  So he caused the mare to be brought into a house, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he armed himself, and began to watch that night.  And in the beginning of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the night, the mare foaled a large and beautiful colt.  And it was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: standing up in the place.  And Teirnyon rose up and looked at the size of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the colt, and as he did so he heard a great tumult, and after the tumult
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: behold a claw came through the window into the house, and it seized the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: colt by the mane.  Then Teirnyon drew his sword, and struck off the arm
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: at the elbow, so that portion of the arm together with the colt was in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the house with him.  And then did he hear a tumult and wailing, both at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: once.  And he opened the door, and rushed out in the direction of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: noise, and he could not see the cause of the tumult because of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: darkness of the night, but he rushed after it and followed it.  Then he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: remembered that he had left the door open, and he returned.  And at the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: door behold there was an infant boy in swaddling-clothes, wrapped around
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in a mantle of satin.  And he took up the boy, and behold he was very
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: strong for the age that he was of.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then he shut the door, and went into the chamber where his wife was.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Lady,” said he, “art thou sleeping?”  “No, lord,” said she, “I was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: asleep, but as thou camest in I did awake.”  “Behold, here is a boy for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee if thou wilt,” said he, “since thou hast never had one.”  “My lord,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said she, “what adventure is this?”  “It was thus,” said Teirnyon; and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: told her how it all befell.  “Verily, lord,” said she, “what sort of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: garments are there upon the boy?”  “A mantle of satin,” said he.  “He is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: then a boy of gentle lineage,” she replied.  “My lord,” she said, “if
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou wilt, I shall have great diversion and mirth.  I will call my women
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto me, and tell them that I have been pregnant.”  “I will readily grant
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee to do this,” he answered.  And thus did they, and they caused the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boy to be baptized, and the ceremony was performed there; and the name
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which they gave unto him was Gwri Wallt Euryn, because what hair was upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his head was as yellow as gold.  And they had the boy nursed in the Court
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: until he was a year old.  And before the year was over he could walk
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stoutly.  And he was larger than a boy of three years old, even one of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: great growth and size.  And the boy was nursed the second year, and then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he was as large as a child six years old.  And before the end of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fourth year, he would bribe the grooms to allow him to take the horses to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: water.  “My lord,” said his wife unto Teirnyon, “where is the colt which
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou didst save on the night that thou didst find the boy?”  “I have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: commanded the grooms of the horses,” said he, “that they take care of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him.”  “Would it not be well, lord,” said she, “if thou wert to cause him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to be broken in, and given to the boy, seeing that on the same night that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou didst find the boy, the colt was foaled and thou didst save him?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “I will not oppose thee in this matter,” said Teirnyon.  “I will allow
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee to give him the colt.”  “Lord,” said she, “may Heaven reward thee; I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will give it him.”  So the horse was given to the boy.  Then she went to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the grooms and those who tended the horses, and commanded them to be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: careful of the horse, so that he might be broken in by the time that the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boy could ride him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And while these things were going forward, they heard tidings of Rhiannon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and her punishment.  And Teirnyon Twryv Vliant, by reason of the pity
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that he felt on hearing this story of Rhiannon and her punishment,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: inquired closely concerning it, until he had heard from many of those who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came to his court.  Then did Teirnyon, often lamenting the sad history,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ponder within himself, and he looked steadfastly on the boy, and as he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: looked upon him, it seemed to him that he had never beheld so great a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: likeness between father and son, as between the boy and Pwyll the Chief
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Annwvyn.  Now the semblance of Pwyll was well known to him, for he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of yore been one of his followers.  And thereupon he became grieved for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the wrong that he did, in keeping with him a boy whom he knew to be the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: son of another man.  And the first time that he was alone with his wife,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he told her that it was not right that they should keep the boy with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them, and suffer so excellent a lady as Rhiannon to be punished so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: greatly on his account, whereas the boy was the son of Pwyll the Chief of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Annwvyn.  And Teirnyon’s wife agreed with him, that they should send the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boy to Pwyll.  “And three things, lord,” said she, “shall we gain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thereby.  Thanks and gifts for releasing Rhiannon from her punishment;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and thanks from Pwyll for nursing his son and restoring him unto him; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thirdly, if the boy is of gentle nature, he will be our foster-son, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he will do for us all the good in his power.”  So it was settled
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: according to this counsel.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And no later than the next day was Teirnyon equipped, and two other
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: knights with him.  And the boy, as a fourth in their company, went with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them upon the horse which Teirnyon had given him.  And they journeyed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: towards Narberth, and it was not long before they reached that place.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And as they drew near to the palace, they beheld Rhiannon sitting beside
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the horseblock.  And when they were opposite to her, “Chieftain,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she, “go not further thus, I will bear every one of you into the palace,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and this is my penance for slaying my own son and devouring him.”  “Oh,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fair lady,” said Teirnyon, “think not that I will be one to be carried
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon thy back.”  “Neither will I,” said the boy.  “Truly, my soul,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Teirnyon, “we will not go.”  So they went forward to the palace, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there was great joy at their coming.  And at the palace a feast was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prepared, because Pywll was come back from the confines of Dyved.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they went into the hall and washed, and Pwyll rejoiced to see Teirnyon.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And in this order they sat.  Teirnyon between Pwyll and Rhiannon, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Teirnyon’s two companions on the other side of Pwyll, with the boy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: between them.  And after meat they began to carouse and to discourse.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Teirnyon’s discourse was concerning the adventure of the mare and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boy, and how he and his wife had nursed and reared the child as their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: own.  “And behold here is thy son, lady,” said Teirnyon.  “And whosoever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: told that lie concerning thee, has done wrong.  And when I heard of thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sorrow, I was troubled and grieved.  And I believe that there is none of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this host who will not perceive that the boy is the son of Pwyll,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Teirnyon.  “There is none,” said they all, “who is not certain thereof.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “I declare to Heaven,” said Rhiannon, “that if this be true, there is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: indeed an end to my trouble.”  “Lady,” said Pendaran Dyved, “well hast
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou named thy son Pryderi, {3} and well becomes him the name of Pryderi
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: son of Pwyll Chief of Annwvyn.”  “Look you,” said Rhiannon, “will not his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: own name become him better?”  “What name has he?” asked Pendaran Dyved.

author: NA

text: “Gwri Wallt Euryn is the name that we gave him.”  “Pryderi,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pendaran, “shall his name be.”  “It were more proper,” said Pwyll, “that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the boy should take his name from the word his mother spoke when she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: received the joyful tidings of him.”  And thus was it arranged.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Teirnyon,” said Pwyll, “Heaven reward thee that thou hast reared the boy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: up to this time, and, being of gentle lineage, it were fitting that he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: repay thee for it.”  “My lord,” said Teirnyon, “it was my wife who nursed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him, and there is no one in the world so afflicted as she at parting with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him.  It were well that he should bear in mind what I and my wife have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: done for him.”  “I call Heaven to witness,” said Pwyll, “that while I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: live I will support thee and thy possessions, as long as I am able to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: preserve my own.  And when he shall have power, he will more fitly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: maintain them than I.  And if this counsel be pleasing unto thee, and to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: my nobles, it shall be that, as thou hast reared him up to the present
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: time, I will give him to be brought up by Pendaran Dyved, from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: henceforth.  And you shall be companions, and shall both be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: foster-fathers unto him.”  “This is good counsel,” said they all.  So the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boy was given to Pendaran Dyved, and the nobles of the land were sent
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with him.  And Teirnyon Twryv Vliant, and his companions, set out for his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: country, and his possessions, with love and gladness.  And he went not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: without being offered the fairest jewels and the fairest horses, and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: choicest dogs; but he would take none of them.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thereupon they all remained in their own dominions.  And Pryderi, the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Pwyll the Chief of Annwvyn, was brought up carefully as was fit, so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that he became the fairest youth, and the most comely, and the best
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: skilled in all good games, of any in the kingdom.  And thus passed years
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and years, until the end of Pwyll the Chief of Annwvyn’s life came, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he died.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Pryderi ruled the seven Cantrevs of Dyved prosperously, and he was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beloved by his people, and by all around him.  And at length he added
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto them the three Cantrevs of Ystrad Tywi, and the four Cantrevs of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cardigan; and these were called the Seven Cantrevs of Seissyllwch.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when he made this addition, Pryderi the son of Pwyll the Chief of Annwvyn
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: desired to take a wife.  And the wife he chose was Kicva, the daughter of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwynn Gohoyw, the son of Gloyw Wallt Lydan, the son of Prince Casnar, one
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the nobles of this Island.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thus ends this portion of the Mabinogion.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: BRANWEN THE DAUGHTER OF LLYR
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: HERE IS THE SECOND PORTION OF THE MABINOGI
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: BENDIGEID VRAN, the son of Llyr, was the crowned king of this island, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he was exalted from the crown of London.  And one afternoon he was at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Harlech in Ardudwy, at his Court, and he sat upon the rock of Harlech,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: looking over the sea.  And with him were his brother Manawyddan the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Llyr, and his brothers by the mother’s side, Nissyen and Evnissyen,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and many nobles likewise, as was fitting to see around a king.  His two
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: brothers by the mother’s side were the sons of Eurosswydd, by his mother,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Penardun, the daughter of Beli son of Manogan.  And one of these youths
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was a good youth and of gentle nature, and would make peace between his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kindred, and cause his family to be friends when their wrath was at the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: highest; and this one was Nissyen; but the other would cause strife
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: between his two brothers when they were most at peace.  And as they sat
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thus, they beheld thirteen ships coming from the south of Ireland, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: making towards them, and they came with a swift motion, the wind being
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: behind them, and they neared them rapidly.  “I see ships afar,” said the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: king, “coming swiftly towards the land.  Command the men of the Court
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that they equip themselves, and go and learn their intent.”  So the men
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: equipped themselves and went down towards them.  And when they saw the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ships near, certain were they that they had never seen ships better
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: furnished.  Beautiful flags of satin were upon them.  And behold one of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the ships outstripped the others, and they saw a shield lifted up above
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the side of the ship, and the point of the shield was upwards, in token
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of peace.  And the men drew near that they might hold converse.  Then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they put out boats and came towards the land.  And they saluted the king.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now the king could hear them from the place where he was, upon the rock
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: above their heads.  “Heaven prosper you,” said he, “and be ye welcome.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To whom do these ships belong, and who is the chief amongst you?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Lord,” said they, “Matholwch, king of Ireland, is here, and these ships
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: belong to him.”  “Wherefore comes he?” asked the king, “and will he come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the land?”  “He is a suitor unto thee, lord,” said they, “and he will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not land unless he have his boon.”  “And what may that be?” inquired the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: king.  “He desires to ally himself with thee, lord,” said they, “and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: comes to ask Branwen the daughter of Llyr, that, if it seem well to thee,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Island of the Mighty may be leagued with Ireland, and both become
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more powerful.”  “Verily,” said he, “let him come to land, and we will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: take counsel thereupon.”  And this answer was brought to Matholwch.  “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will go willingly,” said he.  So he landed, and they received him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: joyfully; and great was the throng in the palace that night, between his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hosts and those of the Court; and next day they took counsel, and they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: resolved to bestow Branwen upon Matholwch.  Now she was one of the three
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chief ladies of this island, and she was the fairest damsel in the world.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they fixed upon Aberffraw as the place where she should become his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bride.  And they went thence, and towards Aberffraw the hosts proceeded;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Matholwch and his host in their ships; Bendigeid Vran and his host by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: land, until they came to Aberffraw.  And at Aberffraw they began the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: feast and sat down.  And thus sat they.  The King of the Island of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mighty and Manawyddan the son of Llyr on one side, and Matholwch on the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: other side, and Branwen the daughter of Llyr beside him.  And they were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not within a house, but under tents.  No house could ever contain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Bendigeid Vran.  And they began the banquet and caroused and discoursed.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when it was more pleasing to them to sleep than to carouse, they went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to rest, and that night Branwen became Matholwch’s bride.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And next day they arose, and all they of the Court, and the officers
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: began to equip and to range the horses and the attendants, and they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ranged them in order as far as the sea.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And behold one day, Evnissyen, the quarrelsome man of whom it is spoken
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: above, came by chance into the place, where the horses of Matholwch were,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and asked whose horses they might be.  “They are the horses of Matholwch
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: king of Ireland, who is married to Branwen, thy sister; his horses are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they.”  “And is it thus they have done with a maiden such as she, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: moreover my sister, bestowing her without my consent?  They could have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: offered no greater insult to me than this,” said he.  And thereupon he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rushed under the horses and cut off their lips at the teeth, and their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ears close to their heads, and their tails close to their backs, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wherever he could clutch their eyelids, he cut them to the very bone, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he disfigured the horses and rendered them useless.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they came with these tidings unto Matholwch, saying that the horses
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were disfigured, and injured so that not one of them could ever be of any
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: use again.  “Verily, lord,” said one, “it was an insult unto thee, and as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: such was it meant.”  “Of a truth, it is a marvel to me, that if they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: desire to insult me, they should have given me a maiden of such high rank
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and so much beloved of her kindred, as they have done.”  “Lord,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: another, “thou seest that thus it is, and there is nothing for thee to do
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: but to go to thy ships.”  And thereupon towards his ships he set out.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And tidings came to Bendigeid Vran that Matholwch was quitting the Court
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: without asking leave, and messengers were sent to inquire of him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wherefore he did so.  And the messengers that went were Iddic the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Anarawd, and Heveydd Hir.  And these overtook him and asked of him what
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he designed to do, and wherefore he went forth.  “Of a truth,” said he,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “if I had known I had not come hither.  I have been altogether insulted,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: no one had ever worse treatment than I have had here.  But one thing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: surprises me above all.”  “What is that?” asked they.  “That Branwen the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: daughter of Llyr, one of the three chief ladies of this island, and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: daughter of the King of the Island of the Mighty, should have been given
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me as my bride, and that after that I should have been insulted; and I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: marvel that the insult was not done me before they had bestowed upon me a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: maiden so exalted as she.”  “Truly, lord, it was not the will of any that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: are of the Court,” said they, “nor of any that are of the council, that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou shouldest have received this insult; and as thou hast been insulted,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the dishonour is greater unto Bendigeid Vran than unto thee.”  “Verily,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said he, “I think so.  Nevertheless he cannot recall the insult.”  These
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: men returned with that answer to the place where Bendigeid Vran was, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they told him what reply Matholwch had given them.  “Truly,” said he,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “there are no means by which we may prevent his going away at enmity with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: us, that we will not take.”  “Well, lord,” said they, “send after him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: another embassy.”  “I will do so,” said he.  “Arise, Manawyddan son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Llyr, and Heveydd Hir, and Unic Glew Ysgwyd, and go after him, and tell
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him that he shall have a sound horse for every one that has been injured.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And beside that, as an atonement for the insult, he shall have a staff of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: silver, as large and as tall as himself, and a plate of gold of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: breadth of his face.  And show unto him who it was that did this, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that it was done against my will; but that he who did it is my brother,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by the mother’s side, and therefore it would be hard for me to put him to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: death.  And let him come and meet me,” said he, “and we will make peace
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in any way he may desire.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The embassy went after Matholwch, and told him all these sayings in a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: friendly manner, and he listened thereunto.  “Men,” said he, “I will take
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsel.”  So to the council he went.  And in the council they considered
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that if they should refuse this, they were likely to have more shame
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rather than to obtain so great an atonement.  They resolved therefore to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: accept it, and they returned to the Court in peace.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then the pavilions and the tents were set in order after the fashion of a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hall; and they went to meat, and as they had sat at the beginning of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: feast, so sat they there.  And Matholwch and Bendigeid Vran began to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: discourse; and behold it seemed to Bendigeid Vran, while they talked,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that Matholwch was not so cheerful as he had been before.  And he thought
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that the chieftain might be sad, because of the smallness of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: atonement which he had, for the wrong that had been done him.  “Oh, man,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Bendigeid Vran, “thou dost not discourse to-night so cheerfully as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou wast wont.  And if it be because of the smallness of the atonement,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thou shalt add thereunto whatsoever thou mayest choose, and to-morrow I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will pay thee the horses.”  “Lord,” said he, “Heaven reward thee.”  “And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I will enhance the atonement,” said Bendigeid Vran, “for I will give unto
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee a cauldron, the property of which is, that if one of thy men be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slain to-day, and be cast therein, to-morrow he will be as well as ever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he was at the best, except that he will not regain his speech.”  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thereupon he gave him great thanks, and very joyful was he for that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cause.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next morning they paid Matholwch the horses as long as the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: trained horses lasted.  And then they journeyed into another commot,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: where they paid him with colts until the whole had been paid, and from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thenceforth that commot was called Talebolion.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And a second night sat they together.  “My lord,” said Matholwch, “whence
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hadst thou the cauldron which thou hast given me?”  “I had it of a man
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: who had been in thy land,” said he, “and I would not give it except to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: one from there.”  “Who was it?” asked he.  “Llassar Llaesgyvnewid; he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came here from Ireland with Kymideu Kymeinvoll, his wife, who escaped
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from the Iron House in Ireland, when it was made red hot around them, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fled hither.  And it is a marvel to me that thou shouldst know nothing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: concerning the matter.”  “Something I do know,” said he, “and as much as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I know I will tell thee.  One day I was hunting in Ireland, and I came to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the mound at the head of the lake, which is called the Lake of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cauldron.  And I beheld a huge yellow-haired man coming from the lake
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with a cauldron upon his back.  And he was a man of vast size, and of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: horrid aspect, and a woman followed after him.  And if the man was tall,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: twice as large as he was the woman, and they came towards me and greeted
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me.  ‘Verily,’ asked I, ‘wherefore are you journeying?’  ‘Behold, this,’
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said he to me, ‘is the cause that we journey.  At the end of a month and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a fortnight this woman will have a son; and the child that will be born
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: at the end of the month and the fortnight will be a warrior fully armed.’
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So I took them with me and maintained them.  And they were with me for a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: year.  And that year I had them with me not grudgingly.  But thenceforth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was there murmuring, because that they were with me.  For, from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beginning of the fourth month they had begun to make themselves hated and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to be disorderly in the land; committing outrages, and molesting and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: harassing the nobles and ladies; and thenceforward my people rose up and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: besought me to part with them, and they bade me to choose between them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and my dominions.  And I applied to the council of my country to know
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: what should be done concerning them; for of their own free will they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: would not go, neither could they be compelled against their will, through
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fighting.  And [the people of the country] being in this strait, they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: caused a chamber to be made all of iron.  Now when the chamber was ready,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there came there every smith that was in Ireland, and every one who owned
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tongs and hammer.  And they caused coals to be piled up as high as the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: top of the chamber.  And they had the man, and the woman, and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: children, served with plenty of meat and drink; but when it was known
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that they were drunk, they began to put fire to the coals about the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chamber, and they blew it with bellows until the house was red hot all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: around them.  Then was there a council held in the centre of the floor of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the chamber.  And the man tarried until the plates of iron were all of a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: white heat; and then, by reason of the great heat, the man dashed against
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the plates with his shoulder and struck them out, and his wife followed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him; but except him and his wife none escaped thence.  And then I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: suppose, lord,” said Matholwch unto Bendigeid Vran, “that he came over
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto thee.”  “Doubtless he came here,” said he, “and gave unto me the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cauldron.”  “In what manner didst thou receive them?”  “I dispersed them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: through every part of my dominions, and they have become numerous and are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prospering everywhere, and they fortify the places where they are with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: men and arms, of the best that were ever seen.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That night they continued to discourse as much as they would, and had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: minstrelsy and carousing, and when it was more pleasant to them to sleep
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than to sit longer, they went to rest.  And thus was the banquet carried
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on with joyousness; and when it was finished, Matholwch journeyed towards
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Ireland, and Branwen with him, and they went from Aber Menei with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thirteen ships, and came to Ireland.  And in Ireland was there great joy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: because of their coming.  And not one great man or noble lady visited
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Branwen unto whom she gave not either a clasp, or a ring, or a royal
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: jewel to keep, such as it was honourable to be seen departing with.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in these things she spent that year in much renown, and she passed her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: time pleasantly, enjoying honour and friendship.  And in the meanwhile it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chanced that she became pregnant, and in due time a son was born unto
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her, and the name that they gave him was Gwern the son of Matholwch, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they put the boy out to be foster-nursed, in a place where were the best
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: men of Ireland.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And behold in the second year a tumult arose in Ireland, on account of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the insult which Matholwch had received in Cambria, and the payment made
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him for his horses.  And his foster-brothers, and such as were nearest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unto him, blamed him openly for that matter.  And he might have no peace
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by reason of the tumult until they should revenge upon him this disgrace.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the vengeance which they took was to drive away Branwen from the same

text: from across the sea came to this island while the head was in that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: concealment.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thus is the story related of those who journeyed over from Ireland.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In Ireland none were left alive, except five pregnant women in a cave in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Irish wilderness; and to these five women in the same night were born
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: five sons, whom they nursed until they became grown-up youths.  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thought about wives, and they at the same time desired to possess them,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and each took a wife of the mothers of their companions, and they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: governed the country and peopled it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And these five divided it amongst them, and because of this partition are
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the five divisions of Ireland still so termed.  And they examined the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: land where the battles had taken place, and they found gold and silver
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: until they became wealthy.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thus ends this portion of the Mabinogi, concerning the blow given to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Branwen, which was the third unhappy blow of this island; and concerning
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the entertainment of Bran, when the hosts of sevenscore countries and ten
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went over to Ireland to revenge the blow given to Branwen; and concerning
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the seven years’ banquet in Harlech, and the singing of the birds of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhiannon, and the sojourning of the head for the space of fourscore
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: years.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: MANAWYDDAN THE SON OF LLYR
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: HERE IS THE THIRD PORTION OF THE MABINOGI
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: WHEN the seven men of whom we spoke above had buried the head of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Bendigeid Vran, in the White Mount an London, with its face towards
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: France; Manawyddan gazed upon the town of London, and upon his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: companions, and heaved a great sigh; and much grief and heaviness came
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon him.  “Alas, Almighty Heaven, woe is me,” he exclaimed, “there is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: none save myself without a resting-place this night.”  “Lord,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pryderi, “be not so sorrowful.  Thy cousin is king of the Island of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mighty, and though he should do thee wrong, thou hast never been a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: claimant of land or possessions.  Thou art the third disinherited
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prince.”  “Yea,” answered he, “but although this man is my cousin, it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grieveth me to see any one in the place of my brother Bendigeid Vran,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: neither can I be happy in the same dwelling with him.”  “Wilt thou follow
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the counsel of another?” said Pryderi.  “I stand in need of counsel,” he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered, “and what may that counsel be?”  “Seven Cantrevs remain unto
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me,” said Pryderi, “wherein Rhiannon my mother dwells.  I will bestow her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon thee and the seven Cantrevs with her, and though thou hadst no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: possessions but those Cantrevs only, thou couldst not have seven Cantrevs
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fairer than they.  Kicva, the daughter of Gwynn Gloyw, is my wife, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: since the inheritance of the Cantrevs belongs to me, do thou and Rhiannon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: enjoy them, and if thou ever desire any possessions thou wilt take
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: these.”  “I do not, Chieftain,” said he; “Heaven reward thee for thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: friendship.”  “I would show thee the best friendship in the world if thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wouldst let me.”  “I will, my friend,” said he, “and Heaven reward thee.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I will go with thee to seek Rhiannon and to look at thy possessions.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Thou wilt do well,” he answered.  “And I believe that thou didst never
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hear a lady discourse better than she, and when she was in her prime none
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was ever fairer.  Even now her aspect is not uncomely.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: They set forth, and, however long the journey, they came at length to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Dyved, and a feast was prepared for them against their coming to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Narberth, which Rhiannon and Kicva had provided.  Then began Manawyddan
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Rhiannon to sit and to talk together, and from their discourse his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mind and his thoughts became warmed towards her, and he thought in his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heart he had never beheld any lady more fulfilled of grace and beauty
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than she.  “Pryderi,” said he, “I will that it be as thou didst say.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “What saying was that?” asked Rhiannon.  “Lady,” said Pryderi, “I did
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: offer thee as a wife to Manawyddan the son of Llyr.”  “By that will I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gladly abide,” said Rhiannon.  “Right glad am I also,” said Manawyddan;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “may Heaven reward him who hath shown unto me friendship so perfect as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And before the feast was over she became his bride.  Said Pryderi, “Tarry
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ye here the rest of the feast, and I will go into Lloegyr to tender my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: homage unto Caswallawn the son of Beli.”  “Lord,” said Rhiannon,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Caswallawn is in Kent, thou mayest therefore tarry at the feast, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wait until he shall be nearer.”  “We will wait,” he answered.  So they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: finished the feast.  And they began to make the circuit of Dyved, and to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hunt, and to take their pleasure.  And as they went through the country,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they had never seen lands more pleasant to live in, nor better hunting
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grounds, nor greater plenty of honey and fish.  And such was the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: friendship between those four, that they would not be parted from each
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: other by night nor by day.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And in the midst of all this he went to Caswallawn at Oxford, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tendered his homage; and honourable was his reception there, and highly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was he praised for offering his homage.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And after his return, Pryderi and Manawyddan feasted and took their ease
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and pleasure.  And they began a feast at Narberth, for it was the chief
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: palace; and there originated all honour.  And when they had ended the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: first meal that night, while those who served them ate, they arose and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went forth, and proceeded all four to the Gorsedd of Narberth, and their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: retinue with them.  And as they sat thus, behold, a peal of thunder, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with the violence of the thunderstorm, lo there came a fall of mist, so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thick that not one of them could see the other.  And after the mist it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: became light all around.  And when they looked towards the place where
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they were wont to see cattle, and herds, and dwellings, they saw nothing
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: now, neither house, nor beast, nor smoke, nor fire, nor man, nor
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dwelling; but the houses of the Court empty, and desert, and uninhabited,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: without either man or beast within them.  And truly all their companions
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were lost to them, without their knowing aught of what had befallen them,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: save those four only.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “In the name of Heaven,” cried Manawyddan, “where are they of the Court,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and all my host beside these?  Let us go and see.”  So they came into the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hall, and there was no man; and they went on to the castle and to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sleeping-place, and they saw none; and in the mead-cellar and in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kitchen there was nought but desolation.  So they four feasted, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hunted, and took their pleasure.  Then they began to go through the land
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and all the possessions that they had, and they visited the houses and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dwellings, and found nothing but wild beasts.  And when they had consumed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their feast and all their provisions, they fed upon the prey they killed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in hunting, and the honey of the wild swarms.  And thus they passed the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: first year pleasantly, and the second; but at the last they began to be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: weary.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Verily,” said Manawyddan, “we must not bide thus.  Let us go into
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lloegyr, and seek some craft whereby we may gain our support.”  So they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went into Lloegyr, and came as far as Hereford.  And they betook
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: themselves to making saddles.  And Manawyddan began to make housings, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he gilded and coloured them with blue enamel, in the manner that he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seen it done by Llasar Llaesgywydd.  And he made the blue enamel as it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was made by the other man.  And therefore is it still called Calch Lasar
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: [blue enamel], because Llasar Llaesgywydd had wrought it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And as long as that workmanship could be had of Manawyddan, neither
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saddle nor housing was bought of a saddler throughout all Hereford; till
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: at length every one of the saddlers perceived that they were losing much
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of their gain, and that no man bought of them, but him who could not get
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: what he sought from Manawyddan.  Then they assembled together, and agreed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to slay him and his companions.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now they received warning of this, and took counsel whether they should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: leave the city.  “By Heaven,” said Pryderi, “it is not my counsel that we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should quit the town, but that we should slay these boors.”  “Not so,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Manawyddan, “for if we fight with them, we shall have evil fame, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shall be put in prison.  It were better for us to go to another town to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: maintain ourselves.”  So they four went to another city.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “What craft shall we take?” said Pryderi.  “We will make shields,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Manawyddan.  “Do we know anything about that craft?” said Pryderi.  “We
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will try,” answered he.  There they began to make shields, and fashioned
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them after the shape of the good shields they had seen; and they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: enamelled they, as them had done the saddles.  And they prospered in that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: place, so that not a shield was asked for in the whole town, but such as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was had of them.  Rapid therefore was their work, and numberless were the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shields they made.  But at last they were marked by the craftsmen, who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came together in haste, and their fellow-townsmen with them, and agreed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that they should seek to slay them.  But they received warning, and heard
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: how the men had resolved on their destruction.  “Pryderi,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Manawyddan, “these men desire to slay us.”  “Let us not endure this from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: these boors, but let us rather fall upon them and slay them.”  “Not so,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he answered; “Caswallawn and his men will hear of it, and we shall be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: undone.  Let us go to another town.”  So to another town they went.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “What craft shall we take?” said Manawyddan.  “Whatsoever thou wilt that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: we know,” said Pryderi.  “Not so,” he replied, “but let us take to making
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shoes, for there is not courage enough among cordwainers either to fight
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with us or to molest us.”  “I know nothing thereof,” said Pryderi.  “But
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I know,” answered Manawyddan; “and I will teach thee to stitch.  We will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not attempt to dress the leather, but we will buy it ready dressed and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will make the shoes from it.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So he began by buying the best cordwal that could be had in the town, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: none other would he buy except the leather for the soles; and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: associated himself with the best goldsmith in the town, and caused him to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: make clasps for the shoes, and to gild the clasps, and he marked how it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was done until he learnt the method.  And therefore was he called one of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the three makers of Gold Shoes; and, when they could be had from him, not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a shoe nor hose was bought of any of the cordwainers in the town.  But
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when the cordwainers perceived that their gains were failing (for as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Manawyddan shaped the work, so Pryderi stitched it), they came together
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and took counsel, and agreed that they would slay them.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Pryderi,” said Manawyddan, “these men are minded to slay us.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Wherefore should we bear this from the boorish thieves?” said Pryderi.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Rather let us slay them all.”  “Not so,” said Manawyddan, “we will not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slay them, neither will we remain in Lloegyr any longer.  Let us set
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forth to Dyved and go to see it.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they journeyed along until they came to Dyved, and they went forward
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Narberth.  And there they kindled fire and supported themselves by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hunting.  And thus they spent a month.  And they gathered their dogs
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: around them, and tarried there one year.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And one morning Pryderi and Manawyddan rose up to hunt, and they ranged
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their dogs and went forth from the palace.  And some of the dogs ran
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: before them and came to a small bush which was near at hand; but as soon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as they were come to the bush, they hastily drew back and returned to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: men, their hair bristling up greatly.  “Let us go near to the bush,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pryderi, “and see what is in it.”  And as they came near, behold, a wild
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boar of a pure white colour rose up from the bush.  Then the dogs, being
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: set on by the men, rushed towards him; but he left the bush and fell back
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a little way from the men, and made a stand against the dogs without
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: retreating from them, until the men had come near.  And when the men came
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: up, he fell back a second time, and betook him to flight.  Then they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: pursued the boar until they beheld a vast and lofty castle, all newly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: built, in a place where they had never before seen either stone or
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: building.  And the boar ran swiftly into the castle and the dogs after
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him.  Now when the boar and the dogs had gone into the castle, they began
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to wonder at finding a castle in a place where they had never before seen
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: any building whatsoever.  And from the top of the Gorsedd they looked and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: listened for the dogs.  But so long as they were there they heard not one
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the dogs nor aught concerning them.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Lord,” said Pryderi, “I will go into the castle to get tidings of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dogs.”  “Truly,” he replied, “thou wouldst be unwise to go into this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: castle, which thou hast never seen till now.  If thou wouldst follow my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsel, thou wouldst not enter therein.  Whosoever has cast a spell over
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this land has caused this castle to be here.”  “Of a truth,” answered
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pryderi, “I cannot thus give up my dogs.”  And for all the counsel that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Manawyddan gave him, yet to the castle he went.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When he came within the castle, neither man nor beast, nor boar nor dogs,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nor house nor dwelling saw he within it.  But in the centre of the castle
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: floor he beheld a fountain with marble work around it, and on the margin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the fountain a golden bowl upon a marble slab, and chains hanging from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the air, to which he saw no end.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he was greatly pleased with the beauty of the gold, and with the rich
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: workmanship of the bowl, and he went up to the bowl and laid hold of it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when he had taken hold of it his hands stuck to the bowl, and his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: feet to the slab on which the howl was placed, and all his joyousness
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forsook him, so that he could not utter a word.  And thus he stood.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Manawyddan waited for him till near the close of the day.  And late
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the evening, being certain that he should have no tidings of Pryderi
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: or of the dogs, he went back to the palace.  And as he entered, Rhiannon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: looked at him.  “Where,” said she, “are thy companion and thy dogs?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Behold,” he answered, “the adventure that has befallen me.”  And he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: related it all unto her.  “An evil companion hast thou been,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rhiannon, “and a good companion hast thou lost.”  And with that word she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went out, and proceeded towards the castle according to the direction
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which he gave her.  The gate of the castle she found open.  She was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nothing daunted, and she went in.  And as she went in, she perceived
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pryderi laying hold of the bowl, and she went towards him.  “Oh, my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lord,” said she, “what dust thou do here?”  And she took hold of the bowl
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with him; and as she did so her hands became fast to the bowl, and her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: feet to the slab, and she was not able to utter a word.  And with that,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as it became night, lo, there came thunder upon them, and a fall of mist,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and thereupon the castle vanished, and they with it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When Kicva the daughter of Gwynn Gloyw saw that there was no one in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: palace but herself and Manawyddan, she sorrowed so that she cared not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whether she lived or died.  And Manawyddan saw this.  “Thou art in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wrong,” said he, “if through fear of me thou grievest thus.  I call
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Heaven to witness that thou hast never seen friendship mere pure than
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that which I will bear thee, as long as Heaven will that thou shouldst be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thus.  I declare to thee that were I in the dawn of youth I would keep my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: faith unto Pryderi, and unto thee also will I keep it.  Be there no fear
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon thee, therefore,” said he, “for Heaven is my witness that thou shalt
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: meet with all the friendship thou canst wish, and that it is in my power
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to show thee, as long as it shall please Heaven to continue us in this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grief and woe.”  “Heaven reward thee,” she said, “and that is what I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: deemed of thee.”  And the damsel thereupon took courage and was glad.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Truly, lady,” said Manawyddan, “it is not fitting for us to stay here,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: we have lost our dogs, and we cannot get food.  Let us go into Lloegyr;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it is easiest for us to find support there.”  “Gladly, lord,” said she,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “we will do so.”  And they set forth together to Lloegyr.
title: The Mabinogion

text: “Lord,” said she, “what craft wilt thou follow?  Take up one that is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seemly.”  “None other will I take,” answered he, “save that of making
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So he began his craft, and he made all his work of the finest leather he
title: The Mabinogion

text: could get in the town, and, as he had done at the other place, he caused
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: could be had from him, neither shoes nor hose were bought elsewhere.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

text: forth.

text: Now Manawyddan, when he set out to return to Dyved, took with him a
title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lands where he had been wont to hunt with Pryderi and with Rhiannon.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he accustomed himself to fish, and to hunt the deer in their covert.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: then he began to prepare some ground, and he sowed a croft, and a second,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and a third.  And no wheat in the world ever sprung up better.  And the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wheat than it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thus passed the seasons of the year until the harvest came.  And he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went to look at one of his crofts, and behold it was ripe.  “I will reap
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this to-morrow,” said he.  And that night he went back to Narberth, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on the morrow in the grey dawn he went to reap the croft, and when he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: but the bare straw.  “Oh, gracious Heaven,” he exclaimed, “I know that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
