text: MATH THE SON OF MATHONWY
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: THIS IS THE FOURTH PORTION OF THE MABINOGI
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: MATH the son of Mathonwy was lord over Gwynedd, and Pryderi the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pwyll was lord over the one-and-twenty Cantrevs of the South; and these
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were the seven Cantrevs of Dyved, and the seven Cantrevs of Morganwc, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: four Cantrevs of Ceredigiawn, and the three of Ystrad Tywi.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: At that time, Math the son of Mathonwy could not exist unless his feet
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were in the lap of a maiden, except only when he was prevented by the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tumult of war.  Now the maiden who was with him was Goewin, the daughter
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Pebin of Dôl Pebin, in Arvon, and she was the fairest maiden of her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: time who was known there.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Math dwelt always at Caer Dathyl, in Arvon, and was not able to go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the circuit of the land, but Gilvaethwy the son of Don, and Eneyd the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Don, his nephews, the sons of his sisters, with his household, went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the circuit of the land in his stead.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now the maiden was with Math continually, and Gilvaethwy the son of Don
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: set his affections upon her, and loved her so that he knew not what he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should do because of her, and therefrom behold his hue, and his aspect,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and his spirits changed for love of her, so that it was not easy to know
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: One day his brother Gwydion gazed steadfastly upon him.  “Youth,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he, “what aileth thee?”  “Why,” replied he, “what seest thou in me?”  “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: see,” said he, “that thou hast lost thy aspect and thy hue; what,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: therefore, aileth thee?”  “My lord brother,” he answered, “that which
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: aileth me, it will not profit me that I should own to any.”  “What may it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be, my soul?” said he.  “Thou knowest,” he said, “that Math the son of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mathonwy has this property, that if men whisper together, in a tone how
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: low soever, if the wind meet it, it becomes known unto him.”  “Yes,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gwydion, “hold now thy peace, I know thy intent, thou lovest Goewin.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When he found that his brother knew his intent, he gave the heaviest sigh
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the world.  “Be silent, my soul, and sigh not,” he said.  “It is not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thereby that thou wilt succeed.  I will cause,” said he, “if it cannot be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: otherwise, the rising of Gwynedd, and Powys, and Deheubarth, to seek the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: maiden.  Be thou of glad cheer therefore, and I will compass it.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they went unto Math the son of Mathonwy.  “Lord,” said Gwydion, “I

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: years old.  And the second year he was a big child, and able to go to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

title: The Mabinogion

text: in.  Then he flew up in the form of an eagle and gave a fearful scream.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thenceforth was he no more seen.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: As soon as he departed Gronw and Blodeuwedd went together unto the palace
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that night.  And the next day Gronw arose and took possession of Ardudwy.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And after he had overcome the land, he ruled over it, so that Ardudwy and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Penllyn were both under his sway.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then these tidings reached Math the son of Mathonwy.  And heaviness and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grief came upon Math, and much more upon Gwydion than upon him.  “Lord,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Gwydion, “I shall never rest until I have tidings of my nephew.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Verily,” said Math, “may Heaven be thy strength.”  Then Gwydion set
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forth and began to go forward.  And he went through Gwynedd and Powys to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the confines.  And when he had done so, he went into Arvon, and came to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the house of a vassal, in Maenawr Penardd.  And he alighted at the house,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and stayed there that night.  The man of the house and his house-hold
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came in, and last of all came there the swineherd.  Said the man of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: house to the swineherd, “Well, youth, hath thy sow come in to-night?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “She hath,” said he, “and is this instant returned to the pigs.”  “Where
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: doth this sow go to?” said Gwydion.  “Every day, when the sty is opened,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: she goeth forth and none can catch sight of her, neither is it known
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whither she goeth more than if she sank into the earth.”  “Wilt thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grant unto me,” said Gwydion, “not to open the sty until I am beside the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sty with thee?”  “This will I do, right gladly,” he answered.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That night they went to rest; and as soon as the swineherd saw the light
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of day, he awoke Gwydion.  And Gwydion arose and dressed himself, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went with the swineherd, and stood beside the sty.  Then the swineherd
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: opened the sty.  And as soon as he opened it, behold she leaped forth,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and set off with great speed.  And Gwydion followed her, and she went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: against the course of a river, and made for a brook, which is now called
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Nant y Llew.  And there she halted and began feeding.  And Gwydion came
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: under the tree, and looked what it might be that the sow was feeding on.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he saw that she was eating putrid flesh and vermin.  Then looked he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: up to the top of the tree, and as he looked he beheld on the top of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tree an eagle, and when the eagle shook itself, there fell vermin and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: putrid flesh from off it, and these the sow devoured.  And it seemed to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him that the eagle was Llew.  And he sang an Englyn:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Oak that grows between the two banks;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Darkened is the sky and hill!
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Shall I not tell him by his wounds,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That this is Llew?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Upon this the eagle came down until he reached the centre of the tree.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Gwydion sang another Englyn:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Oak that grows in upland ground,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Is it not wetted by the rain?  Has it not been drenched
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: By nine score tempests?
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It bears in its branches Llew Llaw Gyffes!”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then the eagle came down until he was on the lowest branch of the tree,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and thereupon this Englyn did Gwydion sing:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Oak that grows beneath the steep;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Stately and majestic is its aspect!
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Shall I not speak it?
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That Llew will come to my lap?”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the eagle came down upon Gwydion’s knee.  And Gwydion struck him with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his magic wand, so that he returned to his own form.  No one ever saw a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more piteous sight, for he was nothing but skin and bone.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then he went unto Caer Dathyl, and there were brought unto him good
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: physicians that were in Gwynedd, and before the end of the year he was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: quite healed.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Lord,” said he unto Math the son of Mathonwy, “it is full time now that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have retribution of him by whom I have suffered all this woe.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Truly,” said Math, “he will never be able to maintain himself in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: possession of that which is thy right.”  “Well,” said Llew, “the sooner I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: have my right, the better shall I be pleased.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then they called together the whole of Gwynedd, and set forth to Ardudwy.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Gwydion went on before and proceeded to Mur y Castell.  And when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Blodeuwedd heard that he was coming, she took her maidens with her, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fled to the mountain.  And they passed through the river Cynvael, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went towards a court that there was upon the mountain, and through fear
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they could not proceed except with their faces looking backwards, so that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unawares they fell into the lake.  And they were all drowned except
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Blodeuwedd herself, and her Gwydion overtook.  And he said unto her, “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will not slay thee, but I will do unto thee worse than that.  For I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: turn thee into a bird; and because of the shame thou hast done unto Llew
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Llaw Gyffes, thou shalt never show thy face in the light of day
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: henceforth; and that through fear of all the other birds.  For it shall
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be their nature to attack thee, and to chase thee from wheresoever they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: may find thee.  And thou shalt not lose thy name, but shalt be always
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: called Blodeuwedd.”  Now Blodeuwedd is an owl in the language of this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: present time, and for this reason is the owl hateful unto all birds.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: even now the owl is called Blodeuwedd.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Gronw Pebyr withdrew unto Penllyn, and he dispatched thence an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: embassy.  And the messengers he sent asked Llew Llaw Gyffes if he would
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: take land, or domain, or gold, or silver, for the injury he had received.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “I will not, by my confession to Heaven,” said he.  “Behold this is the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: least that I will accept from him; that he come to the spot where I was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when he wounded me with the dart, and that I stand where he did, and that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with a dart I take my aim at him.  And this is the very least that I will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: accept.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And this was told unto Gronw Pebyr.  “Verily,” said he, “is it needful
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for me to do thus?  My faithful warriors, and my household, and my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: foster-brothers, is there not one among you who will stand the blow in my
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stead?”  “There is not, verily,” answered they.  And because of their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: refusal to suffer one stroke for their lord, they are called the third
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: disloyal tribe even unto this day.  “Well,” said he, “I will meet it.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then they two went forth to the banks of the river Cynvael, and Gronw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stood in the place where Llew Llaw Gyffes was when he struck him, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Llew in the place where Gronw was.  Then said Gronw Pebyr unto Llew,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Since it was through the wiles of a woman that I did unto thee as I have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: done, I adjure thee by Heaven to let me place between me and the blow,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the slab thou seest yonder on the river’s bank.”  “Verily,” said Llew, “I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: will not refuse thee this.”  “Ah,” said he, “may Heaven reward thee.”  So
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gronw took the slab and placed it between him and the blow.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Llew flung the dart at him, and it pierced the slab and went through
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Gronw likewise, so that it pierced through his back.  And thus was Gronw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Pebyr slain.  And there is still the slab on the bank of the river
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Cynvael, in Ardudwy, having the hole through it.  And therefore is it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: even now called Llech Gronw.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: A second time did Llew Llaw Gyffes take possession of the land, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prosperously did he govern it.  And, as the story relates, he was lord
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: after this over Gwynedd.  And thus ends this portion of the Mabinogi.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: THE DREAM OF MAXEN WLEDIG
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: MAXEN WLEDIG was emperor of Rome, and he was a comelier man, and a better
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and a wiser than any emperor that had been before him.  And one day he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: held a council of kings, and he said to his friends, “I desire to go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to-morrow to hunt.”  And the next day in the morning he set forth with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his retinue, and came to the valley of the river that flowed towards
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rome.  And he hunted through the valley until mid-day.  And with him also
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were two-and-thirty crowned kings, that were his vassals; not for the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: delight of hunting went the emperor with them, but to put himself on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: equal terms with those kings.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the sun was high in the sky over their heads and the heat was great.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And sleep came upon Maxen Wledig.  And his attendants stood and set up
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their shields around him upon the shafts of their spears to protect him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from the sun, and they placed a gold enamelled shield under his head; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so Maxen slept.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he saw a dream.  And this is the dream that he saw.  He was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: journeying along the valley of the river towards its source; and he came
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the highest mountain in the world.  And he thought that the mountain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was as high as the sky; and when he came over the mountain, it seemed to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him that he went through the fairest and most level regions that man ever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: yet beheld, on the other side of the mountain.  And he saw large and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mighty rivers descending from the mountain to the sea, and towards the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mouths of the rivers he proceeded.  And as he journeyed thus, he came to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the mouth of the largest river ever seen.  And he beheld a great city at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the entrance of the river, and a vast castle in the city, and he saw many
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: high towers of various colours in the castle.  And he saw a fleet at the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mouth of the river, the largest ever seen.  And he saw one ship among the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fleet; larger was it by far, and fairer than all the others.  Of such
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: part of the ship as he could see above the water, one plank was gilded
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and the other silvered over.  He saw a bridge of the bone of a whale from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the ship to the land, and he thought that he went along the bridge, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came into the ship.  And a sail was hoisted on the ship, and along the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sea and the ocean was it borne.  Then it seemed that he came to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fairest island in the whole world, and he traversed the island from sea
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to sea, even to the furthest shore of the island.  Valleys he saw, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: steeps, and rocks of wondrous height, and rugged precipices.  Never yet
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saw he the like.  And thence he beheld an island in the sea, facing this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: rugged land.  And between him and this island was a country of which the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: plain was as large as the sea, the mountain as vast as the wood.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from the mountain he saw a river that flowed through the land and fell
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: into the sea.  And at the mouth of the river he beheld a castle, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fairest that man ever saw, and the gate of the castle was open, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went into the castle.  And in the castle he saw a fair hall, of which the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: roof seemed to be all gold, the walls of the hall seemed to be entirely
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of glittering precious gems, the doors all seemed to be of gold.  Golden
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seats he saw in the hall, and silver tables.  And on a seat opposite to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him he beheld two auburn-haired youths playing at chess.  He saw a silver
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: board for the chess, and golden pieces thereon.  The garments of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: youths were of jet-black satin, and chaplets of ruddy gold bound their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hair, whereon were sparkling jewels of great price, rubies, and gems,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: alternately with imperial stones.  Buskins of new Cordovan leather on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their feet, fastened by slides of red gold.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And beside a pillar in the hall he saw a hoary-headed man, in a chair of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ivory, with the figures of two eagles of ruddy gold thereon.  Bracelets
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of gold were upon his arms, and many rings were on his hands, and a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: golden torque about his neck; and his hair was bound with a golden
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: diadem.  He was of powerful aspect.  A chessboard of gold was before him,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and a rod of gold, and a steel file in his hand.  And he was carving out
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chessmen.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he saw a maiden sitting before him in a chair of ruddy gold.  Not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more easy than to gaze upon the sun when brightest, was it to look upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her by reason of her beauty.  A vest of white silk was upon the maiden,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with clasps of red gold at the breast; and a surcoat of gold tissue upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her, and a frontlet of red gold upon her head, and rubies and gems were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the frontlet, alternating with pearls and imperial stones.  And a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: girdle of ruddy gold was around her.  She was the fairest sight that man
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ever beheld.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The maiden arose from her chair before him, and he threw his arms about
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the neck of the maiden, and they two sat down together in the chair of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gold: and the chair was not less roomy for them both, than for the maiden
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: alone.  And as he had his arms about the maiden’s neck, and his cheek by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: her cheek, behold, through the chafing of the dogs at their leashing, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the clashing of the shields as they struck against each other, and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beating together of the shafts of the spears, and the neighing of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: horses and their prancing, the emperor awoke.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when he awoke, nor spirit nor existence was left him, because of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: maiden whom he had seen in his sleep, for the love of the maiden pervaded
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his whole frame.  Then his household spake unto him.  “Lord,” said they,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “is it not past the time for thee to take thy food?”  Thereupon the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: emperor mounted his palfrey, the saddest man that mortal ever saw, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went forth towards Rome.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thus he was during the space of a week.  When they of the household
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went to drink wine and mead out of golden vessels, he went not with any
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of them.  When they went to listen to songs and tales, he went not with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them there; neither could he be persuaded to do anything but sleep.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as often as he slept, he beheld in his dreams the maiden he loved best;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: but except when he slept he saw nothing of her, for he knew not where in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the world she was.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: One day the page of the chamber spake unto him; now, although he was page
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the chamber, he was king of the Romans.  “Lord,” said he, “all the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: people revile thee.”  “Wherefore do they revile me?” asked the emperor.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Because they can get neither message nor answer from thee as men should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: have from their lord.  This is the cause why thou art spoken evil of.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Youth,” said the emperor, “do thou bring unto me the wise men of Rome,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and I will tell them wherefore I am sorrowful.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then the wise men of Rome were brought to the emperor, and he spake to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them.  “Sages of Rome,” said he, “I have seen a dream.  And in the dream
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I beheld a maiden, and because of the maiden is there neither life, nor
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: spirit, nor existence within me.”  “Lord,” they answered, “since thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: judgest us worthy to counsel thee, we will give thee counsel.  And this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: is our counsel; that thou send messengers for three years to the three
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: parts of the world to seek for thy dream.  And as thou knowest not what
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: day or what night good news may come to thee, the hope thereof will
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: support thee.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So the messengers journeyed for the space of a year, wandering about the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: world, and seeking tidings concerning his dream.  But when they came back
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: at the end of the year, they knew not one word more than they did the day
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they set forth.  And then was the emperor exceeding sorrowful, for he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thought that he should never have tidings of her whom best he loved.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then spoke the king of the Romans unto the emperor.  “Lord,” said he, “go
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forth to hunt by the way thou didst seem to go, whether it were to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: east, or to the west.”  So the emperor went forth to the hunt, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came to the bank of the river.  “Behold,” said he, “this is where I was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: when I saw the dream, and I went towards the source of the river
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: westward.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thereupon thirteen messengers of the emperor’s set forth, and before
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: them they saw a high mountain, which seemed to them to touch the sky.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now this was the guise in which the messengers journeyed; one sleeve was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on the cap of each of them in front, as a sign that they were messengers,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in order that through what hostile land soever they might pass no harm
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: might be done them.  And when they were come over this mountain, they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld vast plains, and large rivers flowing there through.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Behold,” said they, “the land which our master saw.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they went along the mouths of the rivers, until they came to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mighty river which they saw flowing to the sea, and the vast city, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the many-coloured high towers in the castle.  They saw the largest fleet
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the world, in the harbour of the river, and one ship that was larger
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than any of the others.  “Behold again,” said they, “the dream that our
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: master saw.”  And in the great ship they crossed the sea, and came to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Island of Britain.  And they traversed the island until they came to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Snowdon.  “Behold,” said they, “the rugged land that our master saw.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they went forward until they saw Anglesey before them, and until they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: saw Arvon likewise.  “Behold,” said they, “the land our master saw in his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sleep.”  And they saw Aber Sain, and a castle at the mouth of the river.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The portal of the castle saw they open, and into the castle they went,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and they saw a hall in the castle.  Then said they, “Behold, the hall
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: which he saw in his sleep.”  They went into the hall, and they beheld two
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: youths playing at chess on the golden bench.  And they beheld the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hoary-headed man beside the pillar, in the ivory chair, carving chessmen.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they beheld the maiden sitting on a chair of ruddy gold.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The messengers bent down upon their knees.  “Empress of Rome, all hail!”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Ha, gentles,” said the maiden, “ye bear the seeming of honourable men,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and the badge of envoys, what mockery is this ye do to me?”  “We mock
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee not, lady; but the Emperor of Rome hath seen thee in his sleep, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he has neither life nor spirit left because of thee.  Thou shalt have of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: us therefore the choice, lady, whether thou wilt go with us and be made
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: empress of Rome, or that the emperor come hither and take thee for his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wife?”  “Ha, lords,” said the maiden, “I will not deny what ye say,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: neither will I believe it too well.  If the emperor love me, let him come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: here to seek me.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And by day and night the messengers hied them back.  And when their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: horses failed, they bought other fresh ones.  And when they came to Rome,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they saluted the emperor, and asked their boon, which was given to them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: according as they named it.  “We will be thy guides, lord,” said they,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “over sea and over land, to the place where is the woman whom best thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lovest, for we know her name, and her kindred, and her race.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And immediately the emperor set forth with his army.  And these men were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his guides.  Towards the Island of Britain they went over the sea and the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: deep.  And he conquered the Island from Beli the son of Manogan, and his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sons, and drove them to the sea, and went forward even unto Arvon.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the emperor knew the land when he saw it.  And when he beheld the castle
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Aber Sain, “Look yonder,” said he, “there is the castle wherein I saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the damsel whom I best love.”  And he went forward into the castle and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: into the hall, and there he saw Kynan the son of Eudav, and Adeon the son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Eudav, playing at chess.  And he saw Eudav the son of Caradawc,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sitting on a chair of ivory carving chessmen.  And the maiden whom he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: beheld in his sleep, he saw sitting on a chair of gold.  “Empress of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Rome,” said he, “all hail!”  And the emperor threw his arms about her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: neck; and that night she became his bride.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next day in the morning, the damsel asked her maiden portion.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he told her to name what she would.  And she asked to have the Island
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Britain for her father, from the Channel to the Irish Sea, together
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with the three adjacent Islands, to hold under the empress of Rome; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to have three chief castles made for her, an whatever places she might
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: choose in the Island of Britain.  And she chose to have the highest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: castle made at Arvon.  And they brought thither earth from Rome that it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: might be more healthful for the emperor to sleep, and sit, and walk upon.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After that the two other castles were made for her, which were Caerlleon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and Caermarthen.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And one day the emperor went to hunt at Caermarthen, and he came so far
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as the top of Brevi Vawr, and there the emperor pitched his tent.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that encamping place is called Cadeir Maxen, even to this day.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: because that he built the castle with a myriad of men, he called it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Caervyrddin.  Then Helen bethought her to make high roads from one castle
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to another throughout the Island of Britain.  And the roads were made.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And for this cause are they called the roads of Helen Luyddawc, that she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was sprung from a native of this island, and the men of the Island of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Britain would not have made these great roads for any save for her.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Seven years did the emperor tarry in this Island.  Now, at that time, the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: men of Rome had a custom, that whatsoever emperor should remain in other
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lands more than seven years should remain to his own overthrow, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should never return to Rome again.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they made a new emperor.  And this one wrote a letter of threat to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Maxen.  There was nought in the letter but only this.  “If thou comest,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and if thou ever comest to Rome.”  And even unto Caerlleon came this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: letter to Maxen, and these tidings.  Then sent he a letter to the man who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: styled himself emperor in Rome.  There was nought in that letter also but
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: only this.  “If I come to Rome, and if I come.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thereupon Maxen set forth towards Rome with his army, and vanquished
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: France and Bugundy, and every land on the way, and sat down before the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: city of Rome.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: A year was the emperor before the city, and he was no nearer taking it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: than the first day.  And after him there came the brothers of Helen
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Luyddawc from the Island of Britain, and a small host with them, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: better warriors were in that small host than twice as many Romans.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the emperor was told that a host was seen, halting close to his army and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: encamping, and no man ever saw a fairer or better appointed host for its
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: size, nor more handsome standards.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Helen went to see the hosts, and she knew the standards of her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: brothers.  Then came Kynan the son of Eudav, and Adeon the son of Eudav,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to meet the emperor.  And the emperor was glad because of them, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: embraced them.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then they looked at the Romans as they attacked the city.  Said Kynan to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his brother, “We will try to attack the city more expertly than this.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they measured by night the height of the wall, and they sent their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: carpenters to the wood, and a ladder was made for every four men of their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: number.  Now when these were ready, every day at mid-day the emperors
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: went to meat, and they ceased to fight on both sides till all had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: finished eating.  And in the morning the men of Britain took their food
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and they drank until they were invigorated.  And while the two emperors
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: were at meat, the Britons came to the city, and placed their ladders
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: against it, and forthwith they came in through the city.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The new emperor had no time to arm himself when they fell upon him, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slew him, and many others with him.  And three nights and three days were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they subduing the men that were in the city and taking the castle.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: others of them kept the city, lest any of the host of Maxen should come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: therein, until they had subjected all to their will.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then spake Maxen to Helen Luyddawc.  “I marvel, lady,” said he, “that thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: brothers have not conquered this city for me.”  “Lord, emperor,” she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answered, “the wisest youths in the world are my brothers.  Go thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thither and ask the city of them, and if it be in their possession thou
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shalt have it gladly.”  So the emperor and Helen went and demanded the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: city.  And they told the emperor that none had taken the city, and that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: none could give it him, but the men of the Island of Britain.  Then the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gates of the city of Rome were opened, and the emperor sat on the throne,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and all the men of Rome submitted them selves unto him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The emperor then said unto Kynan and Adeon, “Lords,” said he, “I have now
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had possession of the whole of my empire.  This host give I unto you to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: vanquish whatever region ye may desire in the world.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So they set forth and conquered lands, and castles, and cities.  And they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slew all the men, but the women they kept alive.  And thus they continued
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: until the young men that had come with them were grown grey-headed, from
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the length of time they were upon this conquest.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then spoke Kynan unto Adeon his brother, “Whether wilt thou rather,” said
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he, “tarry in this land, or go back into the land whence thou didst come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forth?”  Now he chose to go back to his own land, and many with him.  But
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Kynan tarried there with the other part and dwelt there.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they took counsel and cut out the tongues of the women, lest they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should corrupt their speech.  And because of the silence of the women
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from their own speech, the men of Armorica are called Britons.  From that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: time there came frequently, and still comes, that language from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Island of Britain.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And this dream is called the Dream of Maxen Wledig, emperor of Rome.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: here it ends.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: HERE IS THE STORY OF LLUDD AND LLEVELYS
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: BELI THE GREAT, the son of Manogan, had three sons, Lludd, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Caswallawn, and Nynyaw; and according to the story he had a fourth son
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: called Llevelys.  And after the death of Beli, the kingdom of the Island
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Britain fell into the hands of Llud his eldest son; and Lludd ruled
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prosperously, and rebuilt the walls of London, and encompassed it about
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with numberless towers.  And after that he bade the citizens build houses
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: therein, such as no houses in the kingdoms could equal.  And moreover he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was a mighty warrior, and generous and liberal in giving meat and drink
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to all that sought them.  And though he had many castles and cities this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: one loved he more than any.  And he dwelt therein most part of the year,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and therefore was it called Caer Lludd, and at last Caer London.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: after the stranger-race came there, it was called London, or Lwndrys.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lludd loved Llevelys best of all his brothers, because he was a wise and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: discreet man.  Having heard that the king of France had died, leaving no
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heir except a daughter, and that he had left all his possessions in her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hands, he came to Lludd his brother, to beseech his counsel and aid.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that not so much for his own welfare, as to seek to add to the glory and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: honour and dignity of his kindred, if he might go to France to woo the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: maiden for his wife.  And forthwith his brother conferred with him, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this counsel was pleasing unto him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So he prepared ships and filled them with armed knights, and set forth
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: towards France.  And as soon as they had landed, they sent messengers to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: show the nobles of France the cause of the embassy.  And by the joint
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: counsel of the nobles of France and of the princes, the maiden was given
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to Llevelys, and the crown of the kingdom with her.  And thenceforth he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ruled the land discreetly, and wisely, and happily, as long as his life
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lasted.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After a space of time had passed, three plagues fell on the Island of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Britain, such as none in the islands had ever seen the like of.  The
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: first was a certain race that came, and was called the Coranians; and so
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: great was their knowledge, that there was no discourse upon the face of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the Island, however low it might be spoken, but what, if the wind met it,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it was known to them.  And through this they could not be injured. {4}
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The second plague was a shriek which came on every May-eve, over every
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hearth in the Island of Britain.  And this went through people’s hearts,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and so scared them, that the men lost their hue and their strength, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the women their children, and the young men and the maidens lost their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: senses, and all the animals and trees and the earth and the waters, were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: left barren.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The third plague was, that however much of provisions and food might be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prepared in the king’s courts, were there even so much as a year’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: provision of meat and drink, none of it could ever be found, except what
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was consumed in the first night.  And two of these plagues, no one ever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: knew their cause, therefore was there better hope of being freed from the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: first than from the second and third.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thereupon King Lludd felt great sorrow and care, because that he knew
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not how he might be freed from these plagues.  And he called to him all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the nobles of his kingdom, and asked counsel of them what they should do
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: against these afflictions.  And by the common counsel of the nobles,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Lludd the son of Beli went to Llevelys his brother, king of France, for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he was a man great of counsel and wisdom, to seek his advice.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And they made ready a fleet, and that in secret and in silence, lest that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: race should know the cause of their errand, or any besides the king and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his counsellors.  And when they were made ready, they went into their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ships, Lludd and those whom he chose with him.  And they began to cleave
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the seas towards France.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when these tidings came to Llevelys, seeing that he knew not the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cause of his brother’s ships, he came on the other side to meet him, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with him was a fleet vast of size.  And when Lludd saw this, he left all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the ships out upon the sea except one only; and in that one he came to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: meet his brother, and he likewise with a single ship came to meet him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when they were come together, each put his arms about the other’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: neck, and they welcomed each other with brotherly love.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After that Lludd had shown his brother the cause of his errand, Llevelys
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said that he himself knew the cause of the coming to those lands.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they took counsel together to discourse on the matter otherwise than
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thus, in order that the wind might not catch their words, nor the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Coranians know what they might say.  Then Llevelys caused a long horn to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be made of brass, and through this horn they discoursed.  But whatsoever
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: words they spoke through this horn, one to the other, neither of them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: could hear any other but harsh and hostile words.  And when Llevelys saw
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this, and that there was a demon thwarting them and disturbing through
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: this horn, he caused wine to be put therein to wash it.  And through the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: virtue of the wine the demon was driven out of the horn.  And when their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: discourse was unobstructed, Llevelys told his brother that he would give
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him some insects whereof he should keep some to breed, lest by chance the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: like affliction might come a second time.  And other of these insects he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: should take and bruise in water.  And he assured him that it would have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: power to destroy the race of the Coranians.  That is to say, that when he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came home to his kingdom he should call together all the people both of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his own race and of the race of the Coranians for a conference, as though
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with the intent of making peace between them; and that when they were all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: together, he should take this charmed water, and cast it over all alike.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And he assured him that the water would poison the race of the Coranians,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: but that it would not slay or harm those of his own race.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “And the second plague,” said he, “that is in thy dominion, behold it is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a dragon.  And another dragon of a foreign race is fighting with it, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: striving to overcome it.  And therefore does your dragon make a fearful
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: outcry.  And on this wise mayest thou come to know this.  After thou hast
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: returned home, cause the Island to be measured in its length and breadth,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and in the place where thou dost find the exact central point, there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cause a pit to be dug, and cause a cauldron full of the best mead that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: can be made to be put in the pit, with a covering of satin over the face
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the cauldron.  And then, in thine own person do thou remain there
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: watching, and thou wilt see the dragon fighting in the form of terrific
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: animals.  And at length they will take the form of dragons in the air.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And last of all, after wearying themselves with fierce and furious
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fighting, they will fall in the form of two pigs upon the covering, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they will sink in, and the covering with them, and they will draw it down
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the very bottom of the cauldron.  And they will drink up the whole of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the mead; and after that they will sleep.  Thereupon do thou immediately
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fold the covering around them, and bury them in a kistvaen, in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: strongest place thou hast in thy dominions, and hide them in the earth.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And as long as they shall bide in that strong place no plague shall come
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the Island of Britain from elsewhere.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “The cause of the third plague,” said he, “is a mighty man of magic, who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: take thy meat and thy drink and thy store.  And he through illusions and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: charms causes every one to sleep.  Therefore it is needful for thee in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thy own person to watch thy food and thy provisions.  And lest he should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: overcome thee with sleep, be there a cauldron of cold water by thy side,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and when thou art oppressed with sleep, plunge into the cauldron.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then Lludd returned back unto his land.  And immediately he summoned to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him the whole of his own race and of the Coranians.  And as Llevelys had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: taught him, he bruised the insects in water, the which he cast over them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: all together, and forthwith it destroyed the whole tribe of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Coranians, without hurt to any of the Britons.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And some time after this, Lludd caused the Island to be measured in its
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: length and in its breadth.  And in Oxford he found the central point, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in that place he caused the earth to be dug, and in that pit a cauldron
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to be set, full of the best mead that could be made, and a covering of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: satin over the face of it.  And he himself watched that night.  And while
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he was there, he beheld the dragons fighting.  And when they were weary
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they fell, and came down upon the top of the satin, and drew it with them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the bottom of the cauldron.  And when they had drunk the mead they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: slept.  And in their sleep, Lludd folded the covering around them, and in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the securest place he had in Snowdon, he hid them in a kistvaen.  Now
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: after that this spot was called Dinas Emreis, but before that, Dinas
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Ffaraon.  And thus the fierce outcry ceased in his dominions.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when this was ended, King Lludd caused an exceeding great banquet to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be prepared.  And when it was ready, he placed a vessel of cold water by
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his side, and he in his own proper person watched it.  And as he abode
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thus clad with arms, about the third watch of the night, lo, he heard
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: many surpassing fascinations and various songs.  And drowsiness urged him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to sleep.  Upon this, lest he should be hindered from his purpose and be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: overcome by sleep, he went often into the water.  And at last, behold, a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: man of vast size, clad in strong, heavy armour, came in, bearing a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hamper.  And, as he was wont, he put all the food and provisions of meat
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and drink into the hamper, and proceeded to go with it forth.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nothing was ever more wonderful to Lludd, than that the hamper should
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hold so much.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thereupon King Lludd went after him and spoke unto him thus.  “Stop,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stop,” said he, “though thou hast done many insults and much spoil
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: erewhile, thou shalt not do so any more, unless thy skill in arms and thy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prowess be greater than mine.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then he instantly put down the hamper on the floor, and awaited him.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: a fierce encounter was between them, so that the glittering fire flew out
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from their arms.  And at the last Lludd grappled with him, and fate
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bestowed the victory on Lludd.  And he threw the plague to the earth.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And after he had overcome him by strength and might, he besought his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: mercy.  “How can I grant thee mercy,” said the king, “after all the many
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: injuries and wrongs that thou hast done me?”  “All the losses that ever I
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: have caused thee,” said he, “I will make thee atonement for, equal to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: what I have taken.  And I will never do the like from this time forth.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: But thy faithful vassal will I be.”  And the king accepted this from him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And thus Lludd freed the Island of Britain from the three plagues.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: from thenceforth until the end of his life, in prosperous peace did Lludd
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the son of Beli rule the Island of Britain.  And this Tale is called the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Story of Lludd and Llevelys.  And thus it ends.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: TALIESIN
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: IN times past there lived in Penllyn a man of gentle lineage, named Tegid
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Voel, and his dwelling was in the midst of the lake Tegid, and his wife
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was called Caridwen.  And there was born to him of his wife a son named
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Morvran ab Tegid, and also a daughter named Creirwy, the fairest maiden
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the world was she; and they had a brother, the most ill-favoured man
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the world, Avagddu.  Now Caridwen his mother thought that he was not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: likely to be admitted among men of noble birth, by reason of his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ugliness, unless he had some exalted merits or knowledge.  For it was in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the beginning of Arthur’s time and of the Round Table.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: So she resolved, according to the arts of the books of the Fferyllt, to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boil a cauldron of Inspiration and Science for her son, that his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: reception might be honourable because of his knowledge of the mysteries
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the future state of the world.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then she began to boil the cauldron, which from the beginning of its
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: boiling might not cease to boil for a year and a day, until three blessed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: drops were obtained of the grace of Inspiration.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And she put Gwion Bach the son of Gwreang of Llanfair in Caereinion, in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Powys, to stir the cauldron, and a blind man named Morda to kindle the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fire beneath it, and she charged them that they should not suffer it to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cease boiling for the space of a year and a day.  And she herself,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: according to the books of the astronomers, and in planetary hours,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: gathered every day of all charm-bearing herbs.  And one day, towards the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: end of the year, as Caridwen was culling plants and making incantations,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: it chanced that three drops of the charmed liquor flew out of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cauldron and fell upon the finger of Gwion Bach.  And by reason of their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: great heat he put his finger to his mouth, and the instant he put those
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: marvel-working drops into his mouth, he foresaw everything that was to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: come, and perceived that his chief care must be to guard against the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wiles of Caridwen, for vast was her skill.  And in very great fear he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fled towards his own land.  And the cauldron burst in two, because all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the liquor within it except the three charm-bearing drops was poisonous,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: so that the horses of Gwyddno Garanhir were poisoned by the water of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: stream into which the liquor of the cauldron ran, and the confluence of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that stream was called the Poison of the Horses of Gwyddno from that time
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forth.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thereupon came in Caridwen and saw all the toil of the whole year lost.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And she seized a billet of wood and struck the blind Morda on the head
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: until one of his eyes fell out upon his cheek.  And he said, “Wrongfully
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hast thou disfigured me, for I am innocent.  Thy loss was not because of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me.”  “Thou speakest truth,” said Caridwen, “it was Gwion Bach who robbed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And she went forth after him, running.  And he saw her, and changed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: himself into a hare and fled.  But she changed herself into a greyhound
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and turned him.  And he ran towards a river, and became a fish.  And she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in the form of an otter-bitch chased him under the water, until he was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fain to turn himself into a bird of the air.  She, as a hawk, followed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him and gave him no rest in the sky.  And just as she was about to stoop
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon him, and he was in fear of death, he espied a heap of winnowed wheat
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: on the floor of a barn, and he dropped among the wheat, and turned
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: himself into one of the grains.  Then she transformed herself into a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: high-crested black hen, and went to the wheat and scratched it with her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: feet, and found him out and swallowed him.  And, as the story says, she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bore him nine months, and when she was delivered of him, she could not
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: find it in her heart to kill him, by reason of his beauty.  So she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wrapped him in a leathern bag, and cast him into the sea to the mercy of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: God, on the twenty-ninth day of April.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And at that time the weir of Gwyddno was on the strand between Dyvi and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Aberystwyth, near to his own castle, and the value of an hundred pounds
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was taken in that weir every May eve.  And in those days Gwyddno had an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: only son named Elphin, the most hapless of youths, and the most needy.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And it grieved his father sore, for he thought that he was born in an
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: evil hour.  And by the advice of his council, his father had granted him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the drawing of the weir that year, to see if good luck would ever befall
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him, and to give him something wherewith to begin the world.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the next day when Elphin went to look, there was nothing in the weir.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: But as he turned back he perceived the leathern bag upon a pole of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: weir.  Then said one of the weir-ward unto Elphin, “Thou wast never
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: unlucky until to-night, and now thou hast destroyed the virtues of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: weir, which always yielded the value of an hundred pounds every May eve,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and to-night there is nothing but this leathern skin within it.”  “How
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: now,” said Elphin, “there may be therein the value of an hundred pounds.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Well, they took up the leathern bag, and he who opened it saw the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: forehead of the boy, and said to Elphin, “Behold a radiant brow!” {6}
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Taliesin be he called,” said Elphin.  And he lifted the boy in his arms,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and lamenting his mischance, he placed him sorrowfully behind him.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: he made his horse amble gently, that before had been trotting, and he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: carried him as softly as if he had been sitting in the easiest chair in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the world.  And presently the boy made a Consolation and praise to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Elphin, and foretold honour to Elphin; and the Consolation was as you may
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: see:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Fair Elphin, cease to lament!
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Let no one be dissatisfied with his own,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To despair will bring no advantage.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: No man sees what supports him;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The prayer of Cynllo will not be in vain;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: God will not violate his promise.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Never in Gwyddno’s weir
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Was there such good luck as this night.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Fair Elphin, dry thy cheeks!
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Being too sad will not avail.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Although thou thinkest thou hast no gain,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Too much grief will bring thee no good;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Nor doubt the miracles of the Almighty:
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Although I am but little, I am highly gifted.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: From seas, and from mountains,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And from the depths of rivers,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: God brings wealth to the fortunate man.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Elphin of lively qualities,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thy resolution is unmanly;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thou must not be over sorrowful:
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Better to trust in God than to forbode ill.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Weak and small as I am,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On the foaming beach of the ocean,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the day of trouble I shall be
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Of more service to thee than three hundred salmon.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Elphin of notable qualities,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Be not displeased at thy misfortune;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Although reclined thus weak in my bag,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There lies a virtue in my tongue.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: While I continue thy protector
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Thou hast not much to fear;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Remembering the names of the Trinity,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: None shall be able to harm thee.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And this was the first poem that Taliesin ever sang, being to console
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Elphin in his grief for that the produce of the weir was lost, and, what
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: was worse, that all the world would consider that it was through his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fault and ill-luck.  And then Gwyddno Garanhir {7} asked him what he was,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whether man or spirit.  Whereupon he sang this tale, and said:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “First, I have been formed a comely person,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the court of Caridwen I have done penance;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Though little I was seen, placidly received,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was great on the floor of the place to where I was led;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been a prized defence, the sweet muse the cause,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And by law without speech I have been liberated
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: By a smiling black old hag, when irritated
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Dreadful her claim when pursued:
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled with vigour, I have fled as a frog,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled in the semblance of a crow, scarcely finding rest;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled vehemently, I have fled as a chain,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a roe into an entangled thicket;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a wolf cub, I have fled as a wolf in a wilderness,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a thrush of portending language;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a fox, used to concurrent bounds of quirks;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a martin, which did not avail;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a squirrel, that vainly hides,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a stag’s antler, of ruddy course,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as iron in a glowing fire,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a spear-head, of woe to such as has a wish for it;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a fierce hull bitterly fighting,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a bristly boar seen in a ravine,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have fled as a white grain of pure wheat,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On the skirt of a hempen sheet entangled,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That seemed of the size of a mare’s foal,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That is filling like a ship on the waters;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Into a dark leathern bag I was thrown,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And on a boundless sea I was sent adrift;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Which was to me an omen of being tenderly nursed,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And the Lord God then set me at liberty.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then came Elphin to the house or court of Gwyddno his father, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Taliesin with him.  And Gwyddno asked him if he had had a good haul at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the weir, and he told him that he had got that which was better than
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fish.  “What was that?” said Gwyddno.  “A Bard,” answered Elphin.  Then
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: said Gwyddno, “Alas, what will he profit thee?”  And Taliesin himself
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: replied and said, “He will profit him more than the weir ever profited
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: thee.”  Asked Gwyddno, “Art thou able to speak, and thou so little?”  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Taliesin answered him, “I am better able to speak than thou to question
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: me.”  “Let me hear what thou canst say,” quoth Gwyddno.  Then Taliesin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sang:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “In water there is a quality endowed with a blessing;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On God it is most just to meditate aright;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To God it is proper to supplicate with seriousness,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Since no obstacle can there be to obtain a reward from him.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Three times have I been born, I know by meditation;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It were miserable for a person not to come and obtain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: All the sciences of the world, collected together in my breast,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For I know what has been, what in future will occur.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I will supplicate my Lord that I get refuge in him,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: A regard I may obtain in his grace;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The Son of Mary is my trust, great in him is my delight,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For in him is the world continually upholden.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: God has been to instruct me and to raise my expectation,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The true Creator of heaven, who affords me protection;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: It is rightly intended that the saints should daily pray,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For God, the renovator, will bring them to him.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And forthwith Elphin gave his haul to his wife, and she nursed him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: tenderly and lovingly.  Thenceforward Elphin increased in riches more and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more day after day, and in love and favour with the king, and there abode
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Taliesin until he was thirteen years old, when Elphin son of Gwyddno went
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by a Christmas invitation to his uncle, Maelgwn Gwynedd, who some time
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: after this held open court at Christmastide in the castle of Dyganwy, for
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: all the number of his lords of both degrees, both spiritual and temporal,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: with a vast and thronged host of knights and squires.  And amongst them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: there arose a discourse and discussion.  And thus was it said.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Is there in the whole world a king so great as Maelgwn, or one on whom
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Heaven has bestowed so many spiritual gifts as upon him?  First, form,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and beauty, and meekness, and strength, besides all the powers of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: soul!”  And together with these they said that Heaven had given one gift
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that exceeded all the others, which was the beauty, and comeliness, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grace, and wisdom, and modesty of his queen; whose virtues surpassed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: those of all the ladies and noble maidens throughout the whole kingdom.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And with this they put questions one to another amongst themselves: Who
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had braver men?  Who had fairer or swifter horses or greyhounds?  Who had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more skilful or wiser bards—than Maelgwn?
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now at that time the bards were in great favour with the exalted of the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kingdom; and then none performed the office of those who are now called
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: heralds, unless they were learned men, not only expert in the service of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kings and princes, but studious and well versed in the lineage, and arms,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and exploits of princes and kings, and in discussions concerning foreign
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: kingdoms, and the ancient things of this kingdom, and chiefly in the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: annals of the first nobles; and also were prepared always with their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: answers in various languages, Latin, French, Welsh, and English.  And
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: together with this they were great chroniclers, and recorders, and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: skilful in framing verses, and ready in making englyns in every one of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA
