text: those languages.  Now of these there were at that feast within the palace
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Maelgwn as many as four-and-twenty, and chief of them all was one
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: named Heinin Vardd.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When they had all made an end of thus praising the king and his gifts, it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: befell that Elphin spoke in this wise.  “Of a truth none but a king may
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: vie with a king; but were he not a king, I would say that my wife was as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: virtuous as any lady in the kingdom, and also that I have a bard who is
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: more skilful than all the king’s bards.”  In a short space some of his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fellows showed the king all the boastings of Elphin; and the king ordered
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him to be thrown into a strong prison, until he might know the truth as
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the virtues of his wife, and the wisdom of his bard.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Now when Elphin had been put in a tower of the castle, with a thick chain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: about his feet (it is said that it was a silver chain, because he was of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: royal blood), the king, as the story relates, sent his son Rhun to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: inquire into the demeanour of Elphin’s wife.  Now Rhun was the most
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: graceless man in the world, and there was neither wife nor maiden with
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whom he had held converse, but was evil spoken of.  While Rhun went in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: haste towards Elphin’s dwelling, being fully minded to bring disgrace
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon his wife, Taliesin told his mistress how that the king had placed
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his master in durance in prison, and how that Rhun was coming in haste to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: strive to bring disgrace upon her.  Wherefore he caused his mistress to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: array one of the maids of her kitchen in her apparel; which the noble
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: lady gladly did; and she loaded her hands with the best rings that she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and her husband possessed.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In this guise Taliesin caused his mistress to put the maiden to sit at
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the board in her room at supper, and he made her to seem as her mistress,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and the mistress to seem as the maid.  And when they were in due time
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: seated at their supper in the manner that has been said, Rhun suddenly
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: arrived at Elphin’s dwelling, and was received with joy, for all the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: servants knew him plainly; and they brought him in haste to the room of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: their mistress, in the semblance of whom the maid rose up from supper and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: welcomed him gladly.  And afterwards she sat down to supper again the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: second time, and Rhun with her.  Then Rhun began jesting with the maid,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: who still kept the semblance of her mistress.  And verily this story
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: shows that the maiden became so intoxicated, that she fell asleep; and
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the story relates that it was a powder that Rhun put into the drink, that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: made her sleep so soundly that she never felt it when he cut from off her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hand her little finger, whereupon was the signet ring of Elphin, which he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had sent to his wife as a token, a short time before.  And Rhun returned
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to the king with the finger and the ring as a proof, to show that he had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: cut it from off her hand, without her awaking from her sleep of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: intemperance.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The king rejoiced greatly at these tidings, and he sent for his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: councillors, to whom he told the whole story from the beginning.  And he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: caused Elphin to be brought out of his prison, and he chided him because
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of his boast.  And he spake unto Elphin on this wise.  “Elphin, be it
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: known to thee beyond a doubt that it is but folly for a man to trust in
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the virtues of his wife further than he can see her; and that thou mayest
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: be certain of thy wife’s vileness, behold her finger, with thy signet
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: ring upon it, which was cut from her hand last night, while she slept the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sleep of intoxication.”  Then thus spake Elphin.  “With thy leave, mighty
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: king, I cannot deny my ring, for it is known of many; but verily I assert
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: strongly that the finger around which it is, was never attached to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hand of my wife, for in truth and certainty there are three notable
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: things pertaining to it, none of which ever belonged to any of my wife’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fingers.  The first of the three is, that it is certain, by your grace’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: leave, that wheresoever my wife is at this present hour, whether sitting,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: or standing, or lying down, this ring would never remain upon her thumb,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: whereas you can plainly see that it was hard to draw it over the joint of
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the little finger of the hand whence this was cut; the second thing is,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: that my wife has never let pass one Saturday since I have known her
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: without paring her nails before going to bed, and you can see fully that
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the nail of this little finger has not been pared for a month.  The third
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: is, truly, that the hand whence this finger came was kneading rye dough
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: within three days before the finger was cut therefrom, and I can assure
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: your goodness that my wife has never kneaded rye dough since my wife she
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: has been.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then the king was mightily wroth with Elphin for so stoutly withstanding
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: him, respecting the goodness of his wife, wherefore he ordered him to his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prison a second time, saying that he should not be loosed thence until he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: had proved the truth of his boast, as well concerning the wisdom of his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bard as the virtues of his wife.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the meantime his wife and Taliesin remained joyful at Elphin’s
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dwelling.  And Taliesin showed his mistress how that Elphin was in prison
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: because of them, but he bade her be glad, for that he would go to
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Maelgwn’s court to free his master.  Then she asked him in what manner he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: would set him free.  And he answered her:—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “A journey will I perform,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And to the gate I will come;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The hall I will enter,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And my song I will sing;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: My speech I will pronounce
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To silence royal bards,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In presence of their chief,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I will greet to deride,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Upon them I will break
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And Elphin I will free.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Should contention arise,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In presence of the prince,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: With summons to the bards,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For the sweet flowing song,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And wizards’ posing lore
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And wisdom of Druids,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the court of the sons of the Distributor
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Some are who did appear
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Intent on wily schemes,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: By craft and tricking means,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In pangs of affliction
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To wrong the innocent,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Let the fools be silent,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: As erst in Badon’s fight,—
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: With Arthur of liberal ones
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The head, with long red blades;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Through feats of testy men,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And a chief with his foes.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Woe be to them, the fools,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: When revenge comes on them.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I Taliesin, chief of bards,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: With a sapient Druid’s words,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Will set kind Elphin free
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: From haughty tyrant’s bonds.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To their fell and chilling cry,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: By the act of a surprising steed,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: From the far distant North,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There soon shall be an end.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Let neither grace nor health
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Be to Maelgwn Gwynedd,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For this force and this wrong;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And be extremes of ills
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And an avenged end
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To Rhun and all his race:
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Short be his course of life,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Be all his lands laid waste;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And long exile be assigned
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To Maelgwn Gwynedd!”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: After this he took leave of his mistress, and came at last to the Court
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of Maelgwn, who was going to sit in his hall and dine in his royal state,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: as it was the custom in those days for kings and princes to do at every
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: chief feast.  And as soon as Taliesin entered the hall, he placed himself
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: in a quiet corner, near the place where the bards and the minstrels were
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: wont to come in doing their service and duty to the king, as is the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: custom at the high festivals when the bounty is proclaimed.  And so, when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the bards and the heralds came to cry largess, and to proclaim the power
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of the king and his strength, at the moment that they passed by the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: corner wherein he was crouching, Taliesin pouted out his lips after them,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and played “Blerwm, blerwm,” with his finger upon his lips.  Neither took
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: they much notice of him as they went by, but proceeded forward till they
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came before the king, unto whom they made their obeisance with their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: bodies, as they were wont, without speaking a single word, but pouting
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: out their lips, and making mouths at the king, playing “Blerwm, blerwm,”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: upon their lips with their fingers, as they had seen the boy do
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: elsewhere.  This sight caused the king to wonder and to deem within
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: himself that they were drunk with many liquors.  Wherefore he commanded
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: one of his lords, who served at the board, to go to them and desire them
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to collect their wits, and to consider where they stood, and what it was
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fitting for them to do.  And this lord did so gladly.  But they ceased
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: not from their folly any more than before.  Whereupon he sent to them a
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: second time, and a third, desiring them to go forth from the hall.  At
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the last the king ordered one of his squires to give a blow to the chief
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of them named Heinin Vardd; and the squire took a broom and struck him on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the head, so that he fell back in his seat.  Then he arose and went on
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: his knees, and besought leave of the king’s grace to show that this their
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: fault was not through want of knowledge, neither through drunkenness, but
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: by the influence of some spirit that was in the hall.  And after this
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Heinin spoke on this wise.  “Oh, honourable king, be it known to your
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: grace, that not from the strength of drink, or of too much liquor, are we
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: dumb, without power of speech like drunken men, but through the influence
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: of a spirit that sits in the corner yonder in the form of a child.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Forthwith the king commanded the squire to fetch him; and he went to the
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: nook where Taliesin sat, and brought him before the king, who asked him
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: what he was, and whence he came.  And he answered the king in verse.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Primary chief bard am I to Elphin,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And my original country is the region of the summer stars;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Idno and Heinin called me Merddin,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: At length every king will call me Taliesin.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was with my Lord in the highest sphere,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On the fall of Lucifer into the depth of hell
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have borne a banner before Alexander;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I know the names of the stars from north to south;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been on the galaxy at the throne of the Distributor;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was in Canaan when Absalom was slain;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I conveyed the Divine Spirit to the level of the vale of Hebron;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was in the court of Don before the birth of Gwdion.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was instructor to Eli and Enoc;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been winged by the genius of the splendid crosier;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been loquacious prior to being gifted with speech;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was at the place of the crucifixion of the merciful Son of God;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been three periods in the prison of Arianrod;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been the chief director of the work of the tower of Nimrod;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I am a wonder whose origin is not known.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been in Asia with Noah in the ark,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have seen the destruction of Sodom and Gomorra;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been in India when Roma was built,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I am now come here to the remnant of Troia.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been with my Lord in the manger of the ass:
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I strengthened Moses through the water of Jordan;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been in the firmament with Mary Magdalene;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have obtained the muse from the cauldron of Caridwen;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been bard of the harp to Lleon of Lochlin.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been on the White Hill, in the court of Cynvelyn,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For a day and a year in stocks and fetters,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have suffered hunger for the Son of the Virgin,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been fostered in the land of the Deity,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I have been teacher to all intelligences,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I am able to instruct the whole universe.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I shall be until the day of doom on the face of the earth;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And it is not known whether my body is flesh or fish.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Then I was for nine months
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the womb of the hag Caridwen;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I was originally little Gwion,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And at length I am Taliesin.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And when the king and his nobles had heard the song, they wondered much,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: for they had never heard the like from a boy so young as he.  And when
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: the king knew that he was the bard of Elphin, he bade Heinin, his first
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and wisest bard, to answer Taliesin and to strive with him.  But when he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: came, he could do no other but play “blerwm” on his lips; and when he
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: sent for the others of the four-and-twenty bards they all did likewise,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: and could do no other.  And Maelgwn asked the boy Taliesin what was his
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: errand, and he answered him in song.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “Puny bards, I am trying
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To secure the prize, if I can;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: By a gentle prophetic strain
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: I am endeavouring to retrieve
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The loss I may have suffered;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Complete the attempt I hope,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Since Elphin endures trouble
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the fortress of Teganwy,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: On him may there not be laid
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Too many chains and fetters;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: The Chair of the fortress of Teganwy
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Will I again seek;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Strengthened by my muse I am powerful;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Mighty on my part is what I seek,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For three hundred songs and more
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Are combined in the spell I sing.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There ought not to stand where I am
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Neither stone, neither ring;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And there ought not to be about me
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Any bard who may not know
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That Elphin the son of Gwyddno
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Is in the land of Artro,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Secured by thirteen locks,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: For praising his instructor;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: And then I Taliesin,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Chief of the bards of the west,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Shall loosen Elphin
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Out of a golden fetter.”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: “If you be primary bards
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: To the master of sciences,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Declare ye mysteries
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: That relate to the inhabitants of the world;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There is a noxious creature,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: From the rampart of Satanas,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Which has overcome all
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Between the deep and the shallow;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Equally wide are his jaws
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: As the mountains of the Alps;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Him death will not subdue,
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Nor hand or blades;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There is the load of nine hundred wagons
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the hair of his two paws;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There is in his head an eye
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Green as the limpid sheet of icicle;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Three springs arise
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: In the nape of his neck;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Sea-roughs thereon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Swim through it;
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: There was the dissolution of the oxen
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Of Deivrdonwy the water-gifted.
title: The Mabinogion

text: {1}  It is also stated, that there is in the Hengwrt Library, a MS.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: containing the Graal in Welsh, as early as the time of Henry I.  I had
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: hoped to have added this to the present collection; but the death of Col.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: Vaughan, to whom I applied, and other subsequent circumstances, have
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: prevented me from obtaining access to it.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: {2}  Hades.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: {3}  The word “Pryder” or “Pryderi” means anxiety.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: {4}  The version in the Greal adds, “And their coin was fairy money;”
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: literally, dwarf’s money: that is, money which, when received, appeared
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: to be good coin, but which, if kept, turned into pieces of fungus, &c.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: {5}  This dialogue consists of a series of repartees with a play upon
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: words, which it is impossible to follow in the translation.
title: The Mabinogion
author: NA

text: {6}  Taliesin.

text: place is evidently an error of some transcriber of the MS.
